questions.text: All of the following instruments are sterilized using glutaraldehyde, except:
questions.solution:
All of the given instruments are sterilized by glutaraldehyde except for thermometers. Thermometers are sterilized using isopropyl alcohol.

Plastic endotracheal tubes, endoscopes, bronchoscopes, rubber anesthetic tubes, and cystoscopes are sterilized using glutaraldehyde. It is one of the most commonly used disinfectants and is highly effective against tubercle bacilli, viruses, and fungi.

questions.text: Which of the following arachidonic acid metabolites is a potent chemotactic factor causing leukocyte recruitment and activation?
questions.solution:
Leukotriene B4 is a potent chemotactic factor causing leukocyte recruitment and activation.

It is one of the main metabolites of arachidonic acid.


Other options: 

Option A: C5a is an endogenous chemoattractant. C5a induces the migration of leukocytes to the site of injury. 

Option B: Interleukin- 8 (IL-8) is an endogenous chemoattractant of the cytokine family 

Option D: Thromboxane A2 is also an arachidonic acid metabolite but it is an inducer of platelet aggregation and is a potent vasoconstrictor.

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. He says that he first noticed it around 4 months back and is worried about the new lesions that are appearing at sites of injury. The lesions appear white on Woods lamp examination. This condition occurs due to
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of localized depigmented macules showing Koebner phenomenon, which are indicative of vitiligo, a condition that occurs due to a lack of melanocytes in the basal layer of the epidermis.

Vitiligo presents with localized depigmentation that occurs due to a progressive loss in the melanocytes. It is classified into segmental vitiligo, which appears as unilateral maculae in a segmented or band-shaped pattern, or non-segmental vitiligo, which appears as bilateral maculae distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body. The lesions become apparent between 20-30 years of age. 

Hypopigmented macules in vitiligo are commonly found in the hips, dorsum of the hands/fingers, feet, elbows, knees, and ankle areas. These are the areas of repeated friction. Rarely there may be complete vitiligo or vitiligo universalis, or trichrome vitiligo where there are areas of depigmentation, and hyperpigmentation, along with the normal skin. Koebner phenomenon is the development of lesions at the site of trauma on the uninvolved skin.

Several autoimmune conditions can be associated with vitiligo. They are thyroid disease (hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism), pernicious anemia, Addison's disease, diabetes, and hypoparathyroidism.

Under the Wood's lamp examination, the depigmented areas emit a bright blue-white fluorescence and appear sharply demarcated.

Treatment involves cosmetic camouflage and sunscreen. Topical corticosteroids are the first line of treatment. Topical calcineurin inhibitors like pimecrolimus and tacrolimus are also used. Psoralen photochemotherapy, khellin, and selective ultraviolet B therapy are second-line treatments. Surgical grafting can be used in refractory cases, where melanocytes from a normal pigmented area are transferred to non-pigmented areas. In patients with extensive vitiligo where only a few pigmented areas are left, depigmentation can be done.

Other diseases with decreased pigmentation are:

Piebaldism: commonly presents with a white V-shaped forelock. It is caused due to the impaired migration of melanocytes to the skin.

Albinism is a genetic disorder characterized by generalized depigmentation of the skin, hair, and eye, caused by a deficiency in melanin biosynthesis.

Idiopathic guttate hypomelanosis (IGH) is an acquired leukoderma caused due to decreased melanocytes and melanin.

Postinflammatory hypomelanosis and pityriasis alba occur due to an impaired transfer of melanin to the keratinocytes.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A young myopic male presents with intermittent haloes.  Gonioscopy reveals an open angle and hyperpigmented trabecular meshwork. Slit-lamp examination is shown below. This finding is called as
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the slit lamp findings are suggestive of pigmentary glaucoma. The slit lamp image shows a pattern of pigment deposition on the back of the cornea called Krukenberg spindles. 

Pigmentary glaucoma is a type of secondary glaucoma more common in young myopic males and they usually have hyperpigmented trabecular meshwork and an open-angle on gonioscopy. It occurs due to the blockage of the trabecular meshwork by the pigment particles that are released from rubbing the iris pigment epithelium.

The patients are asymptomatic and usually presents for a routine ophthalmic check-up or may present with intermittent haloes at times. It has the following features:

  • The pigment particles are deposited on the corneal endothelium in a vertical spindle shape called Krukenberg spindles as seen in slit lamp examination. 
  • Radial transillumination defect on the illumination of the iris is a pathognomonic feature.
  • Gonioscopy shows pigment accumulation along the Schwalbe line inferiorly called the Sampaolesi line.
  • Pigment granules may be deposited on the anterior surface of the lens. There may be a Scheie line or Zentmayer ring of pigment on the peripheral/equatorial surface around the zonular insertions.
  • Some patients may exhibit higher levels of IOP(Intraocular pressure) than in POAG. Over time the control of IOP may become easier as pigment liberation decreases and occasionally the IOP may revert to normal. So, it is not always high. 
 

The image shows iris transillumination in the slit-lamp examination, clearly showing a pigmentary defect in the areas of chronic rubbing due to iridolenticular and intraocular lens haptic contact with the posterior face of the iris.

 

Other options:

Option A: Polychromatic lustre or breadcrumb appearance is characteristic of a complicated/secondary cataract which develops secondary to inflammatory and degenerative conditions of the lens of the eye. The given image shows a complicated cataract in a patient with uveitis. 

 

Option B: Aqueous flares occur due to the breakdown in the blood-aqueous barrier, and protein exudates escape into the anterior chamber. It seen in anterior uveitis. The below-given image shows the presence of cells and aqueous flare in a case of anterior uveitis.

 

Option C: Old healing keratic precipitates are seen in the healing stages of uveitis. The earliest sign of anterior uveitis is aqueous flare and the pathognomonic sign is keratic precipitate. The image below shows the slit-lamp photograph showing large old keratic precipitates.

questions.text: A girl who is _____  years old can give consent for general physical examination but neither can she be employed in a factory nor can she give consent for sexual intercourse.
questions.solution:
A girl who is 13 years old, can give consent for general physical examination but neither can she be employed in a factory nor can she give consent for sexual intercourse.

This is because the legal age for general physical examination is 12 years, for employment in a factory is 14 years and for consent for sexual intercourse is 18 years.

questions.text: A deficiency of the membrane attack complex leads to an increased risk of recurrent Neisseria infections. The membrane attack complex is composed of which of the following complement components?
questions.solution:
The complement components that form the membrane attack complex are C5b6789. 

The complement system is a collection of soluble proteins and their membrane receptors that help in host defense against microbes and pathologic inﬂammatory reactions. It consists of more than 20 proteins, some of which are numbered C1 to C9.

An important step in complement activation involves the proteolysis of the third component, C3, which is also the most abundant complement, by one of the following three pathways:

  1. The classical pathway, triggered by fixation of C1 to either an IgM or IgG antibody
  2. The alternative pathway, triggered by microbial surface molecules like endotoxins
  3. The lectin pathway, in which C1 is activated by binding of plasma lectin to carbohydrates on microbes

During inflammation, C5a, C3a, and C4a, which are all cleavage products of their corresponding complement components, stimulate mast cells to release histamine. They have effects similar to those of mast cell mediators involved in anaphylactic reactions and therefore, are called anaphylatoxins. Thereby increasing vascular permeability and vasodilatation.

C5a is also chemotactic for neutrophils, monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils. Additionally, it activates the lipooxygenase pathway of arachidonic acid metabolism in neutrophils and monocytes, resulting in the further release of inflammatory mediators.

Complement factor C5b binds to the late components C6-C9, resulting in the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC). Neisseria has thin cell walls, hence it is susceptible to lysis due to MAC. Hence, deficiency of this complex leads to an increased risk of recurrent Neisseria infections.

Related Pearl: Functions of Complement

  • Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.
  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

questions.text: A liver biopsy was done on a hepatitis C virus-infected person and a histopathological image with the cellular change is shown below. Which of the following is not a morphological feature of this type of cell injury?
questions.solution:
The above histopathological image shows Councilman bodies. These are acidophil bodies, which represent hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis. In this type of injury, cell membranes are intact and not disrupted.

Morphological features of Apoptosis:

  • The earliest change is cell shrinkage (option B)
  • The most characteristic is chromatin condensation (option C)
  • No inflammation due to intact cell membrane
  • Formation of cytoplasmic blebs and apoptotic bodies (option A)
  • Phagocytosis of apoptotic bodies by macrophages

Councilman bodies are seen mainly in acute viral hepatitis.

Apoptosis is a pathway of cell death that is induced by a closely regulated suicide program in which cells destined to die, activate intrinsic enzymes that degrade the nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins of the cell.

Mechanism of apoptosis: Two distinct pathways can lead to caspase activation and cause apoptosis of the cell.

  • The mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway
  • The death receptor or extrinsic pathway

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with fever, headache, myalgias, and a skin rash on the arm as shown below. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

choices.text: It is transmitted by the bite of Ixodid ticks
The causative organism is Borrelia recurrentis
It is associated with cranial nerve palsies

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever, headache, myalgias, and the characteristic bull’s eye rash (erythema migrans) is suggestive of Lyme disease. The causative organism is Borrelia burgdorferi. Hence, option B is the incorrect statement.

Lyme disease is transmitted by the bite of Ixodid ticks (hard tick). The disease occurs in 3 stages:

  • Primary stage - characterized by the characteristic bull’s eye rash. The rash starts as a small macule at the site of the tick bite and gradually expands with central clearing.
  • Secondary stage - characterized by secondary annular skin rashes, migratory arthritis, fever, and generalized lymphadenopathy. This stage can be associated with neurological abnormalities like aseptic meningitis and cranial nerve palsies. Patients may also develop myocarditis with associated AV block.
  • Tertiary stage - characterized by chronic arthritis, cranial nerve palsies, ataxia, and dermatitis. 

Doxycycline is the drug of choice in the initial stages of Lyme disease when there is no CNS involvement. If there is CNS involvement, i.v. ceftriaxone is used for treatment.

Borrelia recurrentis causes relapsing fever. It is characterized by alternating periods of fever followed by an afebrile period. The disease is transmitted by body lice.

questions.text: A 20-year-old motorcyclist was rushed to the emergency room following a penetrating injury to his chest. On examination, he is hypotensive and his JVP is raised. His heart sounds are muffled and breath sounds are equal bilaterally. A 2D echocardiography shows the following finding. What is the definitive management for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and raised jugular venous pressure is Beck’s triad with echocardiography showing a swinging heart is suggestive of pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade due to trauma. The definitive management of this condition is emergency thoracotomy.

Cardiac tamponade occurs due to the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial cavity that leads to impairment of ventricular filling. It needs to be differentiated from tension pneumothorax in which a patient presents with distended neck veins, shock, cyanosis, tachycardia, and decreased breath sounds.

eFAST is a reliable diagnostic tool and can detect fluid in the pericardial cavity. The most appropriate immediate and definitive management of traumatic cardiac tamponade is surgical - either through a subxiphoid window or by sternotomy or left anterolateral thoracotomy. 

Needle pericardiocentesis is done for emergency management but it has no role in case of traumatic cardiac tamponade. This is because, in penetrating myocardial injury, clot formation in the pericardium may hinder aspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of the drug interaction being demonstrated by the dose-response curve given below?

choices.text: Aspirin & paracetamol used together as an analgesic
Diazepam & flumazenil acting on the GABA-A receptor
Levodopa & carbidopa in the management of Parkinson's disease
Cortisol & adrenaline effect together on blood pressure

questions.solution:
The given dose-response curve shows potentiation. Of the given options, levodopa & carbidopa in the management of Parkinson's disease is an example of potentiation. 

Potentiation is a type of drug interaction where one drug given alone produces no effect, but enhances the effect of the other drug. This results in a left shift in the dose-response curve.

One of the best examples of drug potentiation is the effect of carbidopa in increasing the bioavailability of levodopa for the management of Parkinson's disease. The green curve represents levodopa alone and the blue curve represents the combination of levodopa with carbidopa. The left shift indicates potentiation of the drug effect.

Carbidopa is a peripheral dopa decarboxylase inhibitor that is given to prevent the peripheral breakdown of levodopa. This increases the levodopa available to cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and reach its site of action. Carbidopa in itself does not cross the BBB and only acts to potentiate the action of levodopa. 

Other options:
Aspirin & paracetamol used together as an analgesic (Option A) is an example of additive drug interaction where the combined effect of two drugs equals the sum of the effects of individual drugs given alone.

Diazepam & flumazenil acting on the GABA-A receptor (Option B) is an example of competitive antagonism. Competitive antagonism occurs when the agonist and antagonist compete for the same binding site on the receptor. The dose-response curve in such cases shows a parallel rightward shift.

Cortisol & adrenaline effect together on blood pressure (Option D) is an example of a permissive drug interaction. Permissive interaction means that the presence of one agent is required for the full effects of another agent. Cortisol in itself does not affect blood pressure but its presence is required for the vasopressor action of adrenaline.

questions.text: A female patient presenting with nasal obstruction from greenish dry crusts has been diagnosed with atrophic rhinitis. All of the following interventions can be used to manage this condition, except

choices.text: Dietary supplementation of vitamins A, D, and folic acid
Potassium iodide to improve nasal congestion
Coating the nasal cavity with glycerine in ringer lactate
Modified Young's operation to partially close the nostrils

questions.solution:
Nasal cavity is coated with 25% glucose in glycerine. It is not coated with glycerine in ringer lactate. 

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the nose which is characterized by atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinates. Management of the condition involves both medical and surgical interventions.

Medical management:

  • Dietary supplementation of vitamins A, D, folic acid (option A), iron, and proteins
  • Nasal irrigation with warm saline or an alkaline solution and crust removal 
  • Topical or systemic antibiotics for infections
  • Potassium iodide as a mucolytic to improve nasal congestion (option B)

Surgical management:

  • Young's operation - both the nostrils are completely closed for 6 months
  • Modified Young's operation (option D) - both the nostrils are partially closed. It avoids the discomfort of complete closure of the nostrils and is equally effective
  • Narrowing of the nasal cavity using submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or bone under the mucoperiosteum

Related Pearl: Etiology of atrophic rhinitis

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes when an individual with a mutant gene does not express the associated phenotype?
questions.solution:
Incomplete penetrance describes the situation where an individual with a mutant gene does not express the associated phenotype. This is usually expressed as a percentage; a 40% penetration rate indicates that 40% of the individuals with the particular genotype will express the phenotype. This is seen in autosomal dominant conditions like achondroplasia or osteogenesis imperfecta. 

Other options:

Option A: Gene expression and Mendelian traits are usually described as dominant or recessive; in some cases, both of the alleles of a gene pair contribute to the phenotype—a condition called codominance. Examples include histocompatibility and ABO blood group antigens.

Option B: In variable expressivity, a trait is seen in all individuals carrying the mutant gene but is expressed differently among them. 

Option D: Genomic imprinting is an epigenetic modification where DNA is methylated selectively inactivating either the maternal or the paternal allele. Maternal imprinting results in transcriptional silencing of the maternal allele, and paternal imprinting implies that the paternal allele is inactivated.

questions.text: To turn off the unpleasant and noisy alarm set by his mother in the bedroom, a boy started to wake up early in the morning. What is the type of operant conditioning in this example?
questions.solution:
In this given scenario, the boy wakes up early to turn off the unpleasant and noisy alarm set by his mother (unpleasant stimulus) which ultimately reinforces the habit of waking up early in the morning (desired behavior). The given phenomenon is negative reinforcement. 

Negative reinforcement is a phenomenon in which an unpleasant or uncomfortable stimulus is removed to increase the likelihood of the desired behavior. 

This is hence an example of negative reinforcement. Other examples are finishing the household chores to avoid the mother’s scolding, buckling up the seatbelt to stop the beeping sound, feeding the baby to stop them from crying, and leaving early from the house early to avoid traffic jams. 

Operant conditioning is a learning process in which a particular behavior is modified by either resulting in a reward or punishment. It deals with voluntary responses because the respondent is free to choose a behavior depending on the desired consequence.

Other options: 

Option A: Positive reinforcement is when a behavioral response is followed by a reward­ing event. 

Option B: Positive punishment is when a noxious stimuli is given in response to an action. An example would be giving a child extra homework when they misbehave in class. 

Option D: Negative punishment is when a pleasant stimulus is removed when they exhibit bad behaviour. An example would be when a child fails to do his homework, so he is not allowed to play. Next day onwards, he does his homework every day.

The image below shows Skinner's operant conditioning quadrant.

questions.text: Following chemotherapy for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, a 70-year-old man presents with blood in his urine and lower abdominal pain. What is the most appropriate therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient developing hematuria after chemotherapy suggests hemorrhagic cystitis following cyclophosphamide therapy for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Sodium 2-mercaptoethanesulfonate (MESNA) is the most appropriate therapy for cyclophosphamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis. 

Cyclophosphamide is a nitrogen mustard that acts by alkylating DNA. After oral administration, cyclophosphamide is converted into phosphoramide mustard and acrolein. Phosphoramide mustard is responsible for the anticancer effects, while acrolein is responsible for hemorrhagic cystitis.

MESNA is given along with cyclophosphamide to reduce the incidence of hemorrhagic cystitis. MESNA concentrates in the bladder and forms a conjugate with acrolein and other urotoxic metabolites. This conjugation reaction inactivates the urotoxic compounds to harmless metabolites which are excreted in the urine.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with chronic greenish discharge from her left nipple which is not responding to antibiotics. Mammography showing  broken needle calcification of multiple lactiferous ducts. What is the best method of management?
questions.solution:
The history of a perimenopausal woman with chronic greenish discharge and mammography showing broken needle calcification is suggestive of duct ectasia. As it is unresponsive to antibiotics and involves multiple lactiferous ducts, the best method of management is cone excision of involved ducts (Hadfield’s operation).

Duct ectasia is the focal dilatation of the lactiferous ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. This condition is strongly associated with smoking. 

The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green-colored secretions which is shown in the image below: 


In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, due to irritation, causing periductal mastitis. If the condition does not resolve, it can lead to the formation of a subareolar mass or abscess, and even mammary duct fistulas. The persistence of this condition eventually leads to fibrosis, which can cause slit-like retraction of the nipple.

Mammography showing the characteristic broken needle calcification which is shown in the image below:


Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation (cone Excision of the major ducts). This operation consists of the excision of all the major lactiferous ducts.  If a single duct is involved, then a microdochectomy is performed (Option C).

Webster operation (Option A) is a circum-areolar operation done for the excision of fibroadenoma.

questions.text: A patient has had chronic diarrhea since 2 months with 4-6 watery bowel movements per day. She underwent a cholecystectomy 3 months ago. CBC and metabolic panel are normal. Stool ova and parasite are negative. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of watery diarrhea with a past history of cholecystectomy suggests a diagnosis of bile acid malabsorption, commonly known as post-cholecystectomy diarrhea. Cholestyramine, a bile acid sequestrant, can be used to treat diarrhea caused by bile acid malabsorption

Patients post cholecystectomy are at increased risk of bile acid diarrhea. This is as a result of the lack of a negative feedback loop that normally suppresses the production of bile after removal of the gall bladder. Normally, the storage of bile in the gall bladder leads to reduced production of bile.  This inturn leads to increased bile entry and malabsorption in the colon. This can irritate the colonic mucosa and thus trigger an inflammatory response leading to diarrhea. Cholestyramine works by binding to bile acids in the intestine, thus preventing their reabsorption and the resultant diarrhea. 

Features  Bile acid diarrhea Fatty acid diarrhea
The extent of ileal disease Limited Extensive
Ileal bile acid absorption Reduced Reduced
Fecal bile acid loss compensated by hepatic synthesis Yes No
Faecal bile acid excretion Increased Increased
Steatorrhea None or mild >20gm
Response to cholestyramine Yes No 
Response to a low-fat diet No Yes

Other options:

Option A. Antibiotics: This patient's symptoms have lasted for more than 2 months and stool ova and parasites are negative. The cholecystectomy history makes bile acid diarrhea more likely than an infective aetiology. 

Option C: Loperamide is an anti-diarrheal agent that works by slowing the movement of the intestines. While it can provide symptomatic relief, it does not address the underlying cause of bile acid diarrhea in post-cholecystectomy patients. 

Option D: Psyllium is a bulk-forming laxative used to treat constipation. It would not be appropriate in the management of diarrhea and could potentially worsen the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: On ophthalmological examination of a patient, you observe tremulousness of the iris on ocular movement. All are causes of this finding except?
questions.solution:
Tremulousness of the iris on ocular movement refers to iridodonesis. It is not seen in mature senile cataract. It is seen in sclerotic type of hypermature cataract. 

Iridodonesis occurs when the eyes move rapidly and the lens fails to adequately maintain the iris tissue. Asking the patient to move his eye in a dark room with oblique illumination is the best way to observe iriododonesis. It can occur in the absence, shrinkage, or subluxation of the lens.

Causes of iridodonesis include -

  • Dislocation/subluxation of the lens. Eg; Ocular trauma and Marfan’s syndrome(Option A and B)
  • Aphakia
  • Hypermature shrunken cataract
  • Buphthalmos (Option C)

A cataract is called mature when the lens is totally opaque and appears pearly white in colour. Iris shadow is absent and red fundus glow is absent.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida is undergoing cordocentesis to obtain samples for fetal karyotyping. Identify the false statement regarding this procedure.

choices.text: Anti-D Ig is administered in Rh-ve women

questions.solution:
Fetal tachycardia is not seen as a side effect of cordocentesis.

Cordocentesis also known as percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS), was initially described for assessment of fetal anemia and as a method for fetal blood transfusion. It is also indicated for assessment and treatment of platelet alloimmunization and for fetal karyotyping. It is usually done at 18-20 weeks period of gestation.

A 22-23 gauge spinal needle is introduced into the umbilical vein under sonographic guidance under strict asepsis. Blood is slowly withdrawn in a heparinized syringe. The umbilical vein is preferred as it is larger in size, associated with lesser fetal bradycardia, and lesser hemorrhage. The umbilical vein is commonly pierced near the insertion of the cord to the placenta. 

Arterial puncture is associated with fetal bradycardia. Test results are usually obtained within 24-48 hours. After the procedure, anti-D Ig 300 μg is administered if the woman is Rh-negative.

Complications -

  • Higher risk of fetal loss as compared to amniocentesis and chorionic villous sampling
  • Cord-vessel bleeding
  • Feto-maternal bleeding
  • Fetal bradycardia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of atherosclerosis and dyslipidemia managed with atorvastatin, is scheduled for elective cholecystectomy. He is otherwise asymptomatic and has stable cardiac function. What should the patient be advised regarding his statin use before undergoing cholecystectomy?

choices.text: Discontinue statin therapy one week before surgery
Reduce the dose of statin therapy starting one week before surgery
Switch statin therapy to another lipid-lowering agent during the perioperative period

questions.solution:
Perioperative continuation of statin therapy is recommended for patients undergoing elective noncardiac surgery, especially those with a history of atherosclerosis and dyslipidemia as it reduces perioperative cardiac risk.

Perioperative statin use helps in reducing cardiac complications. Hence, for patients who are on chronic statin therapy, continuation is recommended for noncardiac surgery. Statin therapy can also be initiated in patients undergoing vascular surgery.

questions.text: A patient presents with an amoebic liver abscess. He does not have any diarrhea or blood in his stool. His only complaint is vague abdominal pain. On examination of stool, cysts of Entamoeba histolytica are present. How would you treat this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with an amoebic liver abscess and cysts in stool needs treatment with metronidazole (or tinidazole) + a luminal amoebicide like paromomycin, diloxanide furoate, or iodoquinone.

As metronidazole is so well absorbed in the gut, the levels may not be therapeutic in the colonic lumen. The drug is also less effective against cysts. Therefore, patients with amoebic colitis or amoebic liver abscess should receive a luminal agent in addition.

Note: Albendazole is an antihelmintic drug, used to treat hydatid cyst, roundworms, hookworm, etc.

questions.text: A biochemist is studying the transcription process. The sequence of the RNA he produced from a fragment of DNA is CAAGGU. Which one of the following will be the sequence of the coding strand in the DNA that gave rise to this sequence?
questions.solution:
The sequence of the coding strand in the DNA will be CAAGGT.

The non-template strand or coding strand in the DNA will have the same sequence of the RNA that is produced, except that the non-template or coding strand has T in place of U. 

As all sequences are written in the 5′ to 3′ direction, unless otherwise specified, an RNA sequence of CAAGGU would correspond to a DNA sequence, on the non-template strand, of CAAGGT.

Both the non-template strand and RNA produced will be a complementary sequence to the template strand. Therefore, the template strand would be GTTCCA (written 5′ to 3′).

questions.text: A 25-year-old man met with an accident and sustained a pelvic fracture. He developed haematuria. Retrograde cystourethrogram showed extraperitoneal bladder rupture. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The usual line of management of extraperitoneal bladder rupture is catheter drainage for 10 days.

Bladder injury can be intraperitoneal or extraperitoneal. Extraperitoneal injuries are more common and are usually associated with pelvic fractures. Intraperitoneal injuries are caused by penetrating injuries or rupture at the dome of a full bladder due to a blow or fall. The symptoms of extraperitoneal bladder injury are suprapubic pain with the inability to void.

CT cystography is the ideal investigation for bladder injury. Retrograde cystography confirms the diagnosis. On retrograde cystogram, a dense, flame-shaped pattern of extravasation of contrast in the pelvis is seen in extraperitoneal bladder rupture.

Management of extraperitoneal rupture of the bladder:

Uncomplicated extraperitoneal bladder injury is usually managed with urethral catheter drainage only. Emergency operative management of bladder injury is done in:

  • Intraperitoneal injury from external trauma
  • Penetrating or iatrogenic non-urologic injury
  • Inadequate bladder drainage or clots in urine
  • Bladder neck injury
  • Rectal or vaginal injury
  • Open pelvic fracture
  • Pelvic fracture requiring open reduction and internal fixation
  • Selected stable patients undergoing laparotomy for other reasons 
  • Bone fragments projecting into the bladder

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is not affected in cavernous sinus syndrome?
questions.solution:
The optic nerve is not involved in cavernous sinus syndrome.

Cavernous sinus syndrome (CSS) is a rare condition characterized by ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, ocular and conjunctival congestion, trigeminal sensory loss, and Horner’s syndrome. These signs and symptoms result from the involvement of the cranial nerves passing through the cavernous sinus. The cavernous sinus syndrome affects III, IV, V, and VI cranial nerves.

The cavernous sinuses are two large venous plexuses that lie on either side of the body of the sphenoid bone, extending from the superior orbital fissure to the apex of the petrous temporal bone.

Structures related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinuses are the oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. Within the cavernous sinus are the abducens nerve and the cavernous part of the internal carotid artery.

Image showing cavernous sinus and the structures related to it.

Orbital apex syndrome is a condition similar to cavernous sinus syndrome with retro-orbital pain and involvement of 2,3,4,5 and 6 cranial nerves. The differentiating feature is the optic nerve involvement leading to early visual loss and afferent pupillary defect.

questions.text: A researcher is using a systematic interactive forecasting method that is used to obtain a consensus forecast, i.e. to determine the degree of agreement on a topic. This method uses questionnaires that are answered by experts in two or more rounds. Identify the method.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option B-Delphi method.

Delphi method: It is a systematic interactive forecasting method that is used to obtain a consensus forecast, i.e. to determine the degree of agreement on a topic. This method uses questionnaires that are answered by experts in two or more rounds.

Other options:

Option A: The method of communication used for counseling, wherein a person is helped to make a decision about health is known as the "gather approach", e.g. contraceptive counseling. GATHER stands for:

  • G- Greet
  • A- Ask
  • T- Tell options or give answers
  • H- Help in making choices
  • E- Explain everything about the decision
  • R- Return for follow-up

Option C: A symposium is a series of lectures on a selected subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions (no discussion is involved).

Option D: In a panel discussion, 4 to 8 experts are allowed to have a discussion on a topic in front of an audience.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes judicial hanging?

choices.text: It is a type of incomplete and atypical hanging
It is a type of complete and atypical hanging
It is a type of incomplete and typical hanging
It is a type of complete and typical hanging

questions.solution:
Judicial hanging is a type of complete and atypical hanging.

Hanging is considered complete when the body is completely suspended with no parts touching the ground. Atypical hanging occurs when the knot is placed in a position other than the occiput. 

In judicial hanging, the rope is looped around the neck with the knot under the angle of the right jaw (atypical), and the person is allowed to drop for 5-7 meters according to weight, age, and build of the person without any part touching the ground (complete). Sudden stopage of the moving body causes fracture dislocation usually at the C2-C3 or C3-C4 vertebra level. Bilateral fractures of either the pedicles or laminae of the arch of the second, third, or fourth cervical vertebrae occur (hangman's fracture). 

With proper judicial hanging, the brain stem ruptures between the pons and the medulla, destroying the reticular formation and resulting in an irreversible loss of consciousness. Destruction of respiratory centers also results in irreversible apnea. Death is instantaneous but heartbeat may continue for 15-20 minutes and spasmodic muscle jerking may occur for a considerable time.

Note: In typical hanging, the ligature extends symmetrically upward from the midline above the thyroid cartilage on both sides of the neck to the occipital region, with the knot situated over the nape of the neck.

questions.text: A G3A2 pregnant woman with a history of two previous second-trimester abortions presents at 13 weeks of gestation. USG shows funneling of the cervix, with the length of the cervix being 20 mm. The following procedure is performed. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cervical incompetence, and McDonald's cerclage is the procedure shown in the image.

In McDonald's stitch, the nonabsorbable suture material is placed as a purse-string suture as high as possible (level of internal os), at the junction of the rugose vaginal epithelium and the smooth vaginal part of the cervix below the level of the bladder. The stitch should be removed at the 37th week or earlier if labor pain starts or features of abortion appear.

In cervical incompetence, the retentive power of the cervix (internal os) may be impaired functionally and/or anatomically. Repeated mid-trimester painless cervical dilatation (without apparent cause) and escape of liquor amnii, followed by painless expulsion of the products of conception are highly suggestive of cervical incompetence.

Diagnosis in pregnancy

  • Clinical examination (speculum): Painless cervical shortening and dilatation
  • Sonography: Short cervix with length <25 mm; funneling of the internal os with width >1 cm
  • Speculum examination: Detection of dilatation of internal os with herniation of the membranes

Prophylactic cerclage is done around 14 weeks of pregnancy or 2 weeks earlier than the previous fetal loss. Rescue or emergency cerclage is done anytime within 24 weeks of gestation. It should only be done when there is a bulging of membranes through the dilated cervix. 

Commonly used types of procedures for cervical cerclage during pregnancy:

  • McDonald's procedure - Non-absorbable (mersilene) material is placed as a purse-string suture at the level of the internal os.

 

  • Modified Shirodkar's procedure - Non-absorbable (mersilene) tape is passed subcutaneously through a transverse anterior incision and tied posteriorly.

 

Fothergill operation (also known Manchester operation) - Anterior colporrhaphy with the amputation of the cervix is done. 

Abdominal wall cervicopexy (modified by Purandare and Mathre) - A sling is attached to the cervix posteriorly, near uterosacral ligaments. Both these surgeries are done to manage genital prolapse.

questions.text: A man complains of fatigue and numbness in his hands and feet. On examination, he looked pale and his reflexes were poor. The peripheral smear showed a megaloblastic picture. Which of the following tests can differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency?

choices.text: Methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine
Hypersegmented neutrophils in peripheral blood smear

questions.solution:
Measurement of methylmalonic acid (MMA) excretion in urine can be used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency. 

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is a vitamin B12–dependent enzyme. The activity of methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to the accumulation of methylmalonic acid in serum and its excretion in urine.

The test for MMA excretion is also used to assess the nutritional status of vitamin B12.

There are two vitamin B12–dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase): This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine. This requires both vitamin B12 and folate.
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: Methylmalonyl-CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine, and propionyl CoA, is converted to succinyl CoA.

Homocysteine will be elevated in both vitamin B12 deficiency and folate deficiency. 

The figure below shows vitamin B12 serving as a cofactor of methionine synthase.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 40 children in rural and 30 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

In this question,

  • Nutritional status (nourished or malnourished) is a qualitative measure.
  • Residence (Urban or rural) is again a qualitative measure.
  • Further, only these two variables are being compared. Therefore, the chi-square test is the most appropriate test of significance.

The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric (non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

Other options:

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: Standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with measure of central tendency as mean.

Option D: The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman presented with complaints of passing grape-like vesicles vaginally. She also had frequent episodes of vomiting. A USG scan was done and is shown below. Which of the following is not recommended post-evacuation for this condition?

hCG - Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

choices.text: Allowing pregnancy after 6 months of monitoring
Initial hCG levels checked within 48 hours of evacuation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of molar pregnancy and intrauterine devices are not recommended during the period of surveillance, post evacuation.

Molar pregnancy may present with bleeding per vaginum or an acute discharge of vesicular mass per vaginum. On examination, the uterine size is more than the corresponding period of amenorrhea. It shows a characteristic snowstorm appearance on USG.  

Suction and evacuation is the treatment of choice. Here post evacuation, Intrauterine devices are not recommended during the period of surveillance. This is because there is increased risk of perforation during this period if an invasive mole is present.

Post-evacuation recommendations:

  • Anti-D immune globulin if Rh D-negative
  • Initiate effective contraception (IUD contraindicated)
  • Review pathology report
  • Serum hCG levels: within 48 h of evacuation, weekly until undetectable, then monthly for 6 months.

Pregnancy is allowed after 6 months following a negative hCG titer. However, it is advised to avoid pregnancy for 1 year, preferably 2 years, as a fresh pregnancy will interfere with the hCG titres.

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

questions.text: An elderly male patient with a history of chronic kidney disease presents with acute onset of severe right knee pain. Arthrocentesis sample under polarized light shows the following finding. Which of the following is the preferred management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Oral prednisone is the preferred choice for managing gout flare in patients with chronic kidney disease, as it provides effective anti-inflammatory effects with minimal renal toxicity.

This patient with chronic kidney disease is presenting with a gout flare which is characterized by acute onset of severe right knee pain and negatively birefringent needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals under polarized light microscopy.

Gout is characterized by episodic inflammatory arthritis due to the formation and deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals within the joints. It occurs due to an increased pool of uric acid in the body due to chronic hyperuricemia. 

An acute episode of gout flare is characterized by painful, warm, red, tender, and swollen joints. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe is involved in 70–90% of cases (podagra), followed by tarsal joints, ankles, and knees. Triggers of such flares include purine-rich food, alcohol, diuretic use, local trauma, and medical illnesses such as congestive heart failure and respiratory conditions.

Diagnosis is made by synovial fluid examination, which may show needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals. These crystals show bright, negative birefringence under polarized light.

Management of acute gout includes the application of ice packs, rest, NSAIDS, colchicine, and glucocorticoids. In patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), particularly those with reduced renal function, the use of oral colchicine (Option A) and NSAIDs (Option B) for the management of acute gout flares can be associated with an increased risk of adverse effects, including nephrotoxicity. 

Other options: 

Option D: Allopurinol should not be used for the treatment of acute episodes because it can worsen the symptoms.

questions.text: A young woman presented with a history of falling on a partially flexed thumb of the right hand. On X-ray, a diagnosis of Bennett’s fracture was made. The joint that is present at the location of this fracture is a type of:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient has Bennett's fracture which is an intra-articular fracture of the base of the 1st metacarpal. The joint that is present at this location is the 1st carpometacarpal joint which is a saddle type of synovial joint. 

The saddle joint is a biaxial joint that has both concave and convex regions as their articular surfaces. The convexity of one articular surface is opposed to the concavity of the other articular surface and vice versa.

The movements across this type of joint occur mainly in 2 axes i.e. flexion and extension, abduction and adduction. Due to the articular shape, it results in axial rotation. Examples are 1st carpometacarpal joint and the calcaneocuboid joint. 

Other options:

Option A: The ball and socket joint is a type of synovial joint where the articular surfaces include a globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket. These joints are multi-axial and movements occur around many axes. Flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, medial rotation, lateral rotation, and circumduction, all occur quite freely. Examples are the shoulder joint, hip joint, talocalcaneonavicular joint, and incudostapedial joint.

Option B: The hinge joint is a type of synovial joint where the movements occur in a single stationary axis, i.e., flexion/extension. Examples are the elbow joint, and interphalangeal joint.

Option D: A pivot joint is a type of synovial joint where an osseous pivot is present inside an osteocartilaginous ring allowing movement only around the axis of the pivot. Examples of this type of joint are atlantoaxial joint and superior and inferior radioulnar joint.

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the gastrointestinal tract is not supplied by the superior mesenteric artery?

choices.text: Distal part of the ascending colon

questions.solution:
The superior mesenteric artery does not supply the proximal duodenum. The coeliac trunk supplies the proximal duodenum (till ampulla of Vater).

The superior mesenteric artery supplies the distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum, appendix, cecum, ascending colon, and proximal 2/3rd of the transverse colon. 

The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) is a branch of the abdominal aorta and originates at the level of the lower border of the L1 vertebra in the transpyloric plane. It descends anterior to the uncinate process of the pancreas and the third part of the duodenum and posterior to the body of the pancreas and the splenic vein. The left renal vein separates it from the aorta posteriorly.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate presents with persistent bleeding from the umbilical cord stump for more than 24 hours. The baby was delivered at home. Which of the following biochemical reactions is most likely to be affected in this neonate?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of persistent bleeding from the umbilical cord stump is classically seen in hemorrhagic disease of the newborn that occurs because of vitamin K deficiency. Vitamin K is required as a cofactor in the post-translational carboxylation of glutamate residues of factors II, VII, IX, and X. Calcium binds to γ-­carboxylated glutamic acid residues that are present in these factors during clotting.

Vitamin K deficiency is common in neonates as breast milk is a poor source of vitamin K and the sterile gastrointestinal tract of the newborn lacks the required bacterial intestinal flora normally responsible for the synthesis of vitamin K.

All newborn infants are to be administered vitamin K at a dose of 0.5–1 mg intramuscularly, to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn.

Other options:

Option A: Cross-linking of collagen and elastin requires copper as a cofactor. Deficiency in this process can lead to connective tissue disorders like Menkes syndrome or Ehlers Danlos Syndrome.

Option B: Hydroxylation of proline occurs during collagen synthesis and requires vitamin C as a cofactor. Deficiency can present as scurvy in which easy bruising can occur but is not common in the neonatal period.

Option D: Synthesis of thymidylate occurs during DNA synthesis and requires folate as a cofactor. Deficiency of folate may present as megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with type II diabetes presents with dysuria, frequency, and urgency. Urinalysis reveals pyuria and yeast cells and urine culture confirms candiduria. Which of the following is the first-line treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of symptomatic cystitis due to candida sp. Fluconazole is indicated as the first-line treatment for this condition.

Candiduria, the presence of Candida species in the urine, is commonly associated with indwelling catheterization, broad-spectrum antimicrobial use, and conditions such as diabetes mellitus. 

While asymptomatic candiduria may not require treatment, symptomatic cases, especially those with cystitis or pyelonephritis, warrant intervention. Factors that put patients at high risk of disseminated disease, such as neutropenia and urologic manipulation also warrants treatment. Fluconazole is the first-line treatment for Candida urinary tract infections due to its high urinary concentration and efficacy.

Removal of indwelling urethral catheters is indicated in asymptomatic candiduria.

Other options: 

Options A and C: Flucytosine and amphotericin B may be considered in cases of fluconazole-resistant strains and are not recommended as first-line therapy.

Option D: Echinocandins such as caspofungin have been used to treat candiduria, but due to its low-level urine excretion, it is not usually recommended.

questions.text: Which of the following conversions requires pantothenic acid as an essential cofactor?
questions.solution:
Pantothenic acid is an essential cofactor of coenzyme A which is required for the reaction involving the transfer of acyl group such as oxaloacetate to citrate.

In the first step of the TCA cycle, acetyl CoA combines with oxaloacetate to form citrate involving the transfer of acetyl group to oxaloacetate. Also in the same cycle, succinyl CoA synthesis from alpha-ketoglutarate requires coenzyme A.

There are a variety of biochemical reactions that require CoA such as fatty acid synthesis and beta-oxidation.

Deficiency of pantothenic acid (vitamin B5) causes peripheral nerve damage also known as burning foot syndrome.


Other options: 

Option A: Conversion of glucose to pyruvate in aerobic glycolysis requires the coenzyme NAD+ (vitamin B3). This reaction does not require coenzyme A.

Option B: Glutamate dehydrogenase which converts glutamate to alpha-ketoglutarate utilizes NAD+ or NADP+ as a coenzyme.

Option C: Conversion of glucose to ribose-5-phosphate in the hexose monophosphate shunt requires the coenzyme NADP+ (vitamin B3).

questions.text: The Yuzpe method is a type of emergency post-coital contraception. It consists of

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida came for a routine check-up at 33+6 weeks gestation. USG was done which revealed that the foetus is in a transverse lie. What is the most appropriate step to be done?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate step to be done at 33+6 weeks of gestation is to monitor the patient till 37 weeks and repeat USG at 37 weeks to determine if the fetus has naturally rotated into a head-down (vertex) position. However, if the fetus remains in a transverse lie at 37 weeks, additional interventions such as external cephalic version (ECV) may be done. 

A transverse lie diagnosed at 34 weeks gestation is quite common, and the fetus may still change position before delivery. It is common for spontaneous cephalic conversion to occur without the need for external interventions, particularly if the fetus is still in a transverse lie near term. 

The external cephalic version (ECV) is done to bring the favorable cephalic pole to the lower pole of the uterus.

Prerequisites for ECV include:

  • Gestational age of 37 weeks
  • Liquor should be adequate (normal AFI of 5–25 cm)
  • The membranes should be intact
  • No contraindications for vaginal delivery
  • Single fetal pregnancy

Indications:

  • Breech presentation
  • Transverse lie

Contraindications:

  • Antepartum hemorrhage (due to risk of placental separation), Rh alloimmunization, multiple pregnancy, congenital malformations of the uterus, contracted pelvis, severe pre-eclampsia, obesity
  • Fetal causes- hyperextension of the neck ("star-gazing" position), large fetus (>3.5 kg), congenital abnormalities, dead fetus, fetal compromise

Other Options:

Option A: There is no indication to perform weekly USG; instead, wait until 37 weeks for the fetus to naturally rotate into a head-down (vertex) position. This allows the fetus more time to potentially move into a more favorable position for vaginal delivery. 

Option C: External cephalic version (ECV) is done in non-cephalic presentations like breech and transverse lie, to bring the favorable cephalic pole to the lower pole of the uterus. The ideal time to do the external cephalic version is 37 weeks.

Option D: The internal podalic version is an obstetric procedure in which the baby is turned inside the uterus such that the feet are present through the cervix. Upward pressure is applied by the abdominal hand on the head while downward traction is exerted on the feet and the baby is then delivered by breech extraction. It is indicated when the second twin is in a transverse lie, not breech. This procedure is always done under general or epidural anesthesia.

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with a swelling shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the examination findings?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a swelling with punctum suggestive of a sebaceous cyst. They are usually transillumination negative and Paget’s test positive.  

Paget test determines the presence of fluid or gas in a small swelling. It is a type of fluctuation test. It involves pressing the centre of the swelling and observing the response. A positive Paget test signifies the presence of liquid or gas.

Transillumination test determines if a swelling contains clear fluid by transmitting light through it. Positive results indicate the presence of water, serum, lymph, or plasma. 

Sebaceous cysts, also known as epidermoid cysts, are painless retention cysts that arise from a blocked infundibulum of the sebaceous gland. They are encapsulated, adherent to the skin, filled with keratin, yellowish-white cheesy material, and lined by true stratified squamous epithelium. A punctum (denuded keratin) is a common identifying feature, and it can occur anywhere on the body except for the palms and soles. They are most commonly found in the postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule.

The complications include sebaceous horn, cock’s peculiar tumor, and abscess formation. The treatment involves the excision of the cyst along with normal skin using an elliptical incision.

questions.text: The National Air Quality Monitoring Programme (NAMP) involves regular monitoring of the following air pollutants, except?
questions.solution:
Under the National Air Quality Monitoring Programme (NAMP), a nationwide program of ambient air quality monitoring run by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), four air pollutants are regularly monitored: sulfur dioxide (SO2), oxides of nitrogen such as NO2, respirable suspended particulate matter (RSPM/ PM10) and fine particulate matter (PM2.5).

Meteorological parameters such as wind speed and direction, relative humidity, and temperature are all monitored alongside air quality. This monitoring is conducted twice a week.  

Air pollution is the presence of gases and particulate matter in the atmosphere that affect human health and safety. It is also injurious to animals and vegetation. Indicators of air pollution:

  • Sulfur dioxide
  • Smoke or soiling index
  • Grit and dust measurement (suspended particles)
  • Co-efficient of haze
  • Air pollution index

The health effects of air pollution can be immediate or delayed. Immediate effects include acute bronchitis and suffocation. Delayed adverse effects are carcinoma of the lung and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.

Effects of indoor air pollution:

  • Stroke
  • Ischemic heart disease
  • COPD
  • Lung, laryngeal, nasopharyngeal cancers
  • Pregnancy problems like low birth weight

Indicators of air pollution:

  • Smoke or soiling index: A known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter

  • Air pollution index - measure of pollution severity
  • Suspended particle matter (SPM) 

In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child presented with left-sided undescended testis and hypospadias. Ultrasonography showed the presence of an ovary on the left side and fully descended testes on the right side. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of true hermaphroditism.

It is a rare disorder characterized by the presence of both ovaries and testes in the same individual. It is also known as ovo-testicular disorder of sexual differentiation. 

Morphologically, the presence of both gonads can be asymmetrical having both ovarian and testicular differentiation on either side separately or combined as ovotestis within the same gonad or symmetrical with normal testes and ovary on both sides.

These gonads can vary in location from the abdomen to the inguinoscrotal region. The amount of anti-Mullerian hormone and testosterone determines the degree of masculinization or feminization of the internal ductal system.

Clinical presentation includes ambiguous external genitalia, chordee, hypospadias, cryptorchidism, amenorrhea, lower abdominal pain, and inguinal hernias. The phallus size usually helps to determine the choice of rearing hermaphrodite as male or female sex. Adequately sized phallus can be retained with meticulous surgical excision of the female genital organs.

Other options:

Option A: Male pseudohermaphroditism is an association of male gonads with female external genitalia due to the absence of 5 alpha-reductase enzyme. 5 alpha-reductase is responsible for the development of the male phenotype. There is a failure of the testis to descend to the scrotum and ill development of the penis, thereby resulting in the female phenotype.

Option B: Female pseudohermaphrodites are genetic females (XX genotype) with male/ambiguous external genitalia due to the deficiency of 21 alpha-hydroxylase enzymes resulting in an excess of androgens. This causes clitoromegaly resembling the penis, and the fused labioscrotal folds resemble a rudimentary scrotum. 

Option D: Concealed sex refers to the deliberate concealment of sex usually done by criminals by changing dress or by other methods to avoid detection. This can be detected by physical examination.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female who is a contestant in a beauty pageant has a BMI of 15.5 and has been restricting her food intake for a while to maintain her shape. Despite suffering from severe fatigue, she refuses to eat because of fear of gaining weight. Which of the following hormones is increased considering her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The young female in the scenario has a low BMI with restricted food intake, aiming to maintain her shape for the beauty pageant which are all the indicators for anorexia nervosa. In this condition, among the given options, corticotropin-releasing hormone is found to be increased.

Anorexia nervosa is a type of eating disorder in which the patient has an intense fear of gaining weight. This fear leads to restriction of calorie intake resulting in significantly reduced body weight.

Diagnosis is based on the presence of 3 essential criteria: Poor eating habits leading to significant weight loss for age, fear of gaining weight, a distorted perception of body weight, and the presence of medical signs and symptoms of starvation. The SCOFF (Sick, Control, One, Fat, Food) questionnaire is a screening tool for eating disorders (anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa).

Types include:

Restrictive type - patients restrict their intake of food by aggressive dieting as well as relentless overactivity to reduce their weight. Overuse athletic injuries may be seen due to this reason. There are no binge episodes seen in this subtype.

Purge/Binge-eating type - history of binging episodes which are followed by purging behavior (self-induced vomiting).

If a patient's weight is 20% less than the expected weight for their height, they should be considered for hospitalization. Psychotherapy is an effective treatment for anorexia and can include cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), dynamic psychotherapy, and family therapy. While pharmacological agents are not the first-line treatment, medications like cyproheptadine, amitriptyline, clomipramine, pimozide, and chlorpromazine have shown some improvement in anorexia patients.

questions.text: A newborn was found to have chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and diffuse intracranial calcifications upon evaluation. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this newborn?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a newborn having chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and diffuse intracranial calcifications on evaluation is suggestive of congenital toxoplasmosis. The most appropriate treatment is pyrimethamine + sulfadiazine for one year.

Congenital toxoplasmosis is characterized by calcifications all over the brain. These calcifications occur in areas like the caudate nucleus, basal ganglia, subependyma, and the choroid plexus. Other signs that might be present include jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, and a blueberry muffin rash.

Transmission to the fetus is transplacental. The risk of transmission is high in the third trimester. The mother can acquire this infection through exposure to cat feces containing oocysts or consumption of undercooked meat. 

Diagnosis is confirmed using serological tests like ELISA and PCR analysis. Newborns are treated with sulfadiazine + pyrimethamine + leucovorin combination for one year. 

Other options:

Option A: Spiramycin is used for the management of acute toxoplasmosis during pregnancy. It prevents vertical transmission to the fetus during acute infection. Pregnant women in the second or third trimesters whose fetus has a high likelihood of congenital infection are treated with sulfadiazine, pyrimethamine, and leucovorin. 

Option C: Intravenous ganciclovir is used in the management of congenital cytomegalovirus infection if the baby has progressive neurological disease or sensorineural hearing loss. Unlike the diffuse calcifications seen in congenital toxoplasmosis, periventricular calcifications are seen in congenital cytomegalovirus infection. 

Option D: Sulfadiazine alone is not recommended. The combination of pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine synergistically acts against Toxoplasma and thus combination therapy is indicated for better outcomes.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man was admitted with a large wound on his leg for the past 3 months. Cultures from the wound margin revealed an MRSA infection. He was given linezolid. What is the mechanism of action of the above drug?

MRSA- Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus

choices.text: Binds to 30s subunit and inhibits protein synthesis
Binds to 50s subunit and inhibits protein synthesis
Disrupts the structure of cell membrane

questions.solution:
The drug linezolid binds to the P site of the 50s ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It is an oxazolidinone that is active against various gram-positive organisms including methicillin-resistant staphylococci, and vancomycin-resistant staphylococci. 

Staphylococci become resistant by acquiring penicillin-binding protein (PBP) to become methicillin-resistant staphylococci. 

Linezolid and tedizolid are FDA-approved for the treatment of skin and soft tissue infections caused by streptococci and staphylococcus aureus (MSSA and MRSA). Linezolid is also approved for the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia due to S. pneumoniae and nosocomial pneumonia due to S. aureus.

Adverse effects include:

  • myelosuppression (anemia, leukopenia, pancytopenia)
  • thrombocytopenia (most common side effect)
  • serotonin syndrome if given along with serotonergic drugs due to monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibition
  • peripheral neuropathy, optic neuropathy, lactic acidosis

Other options:

Option A - Aminoglycoside antibiotics act by binding to the 30s ribosome and interfere with the initiation of protein synthesis. These bactericidal agents are mainly used to treat gram-negative bacterial infections. Ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity, and neuromuscular blockade are the most important adverse effects.

 Option C- Polymyxins act by interacting with the phospholipids and disrupting the structure of the cell membrane. It can be used systemically for bacteremia, pneumonia, bone/joint infections, burns, cellulitis, cystic fibrosis, endocarditis, gynecologic infections, meningitis, and ventriculitis. Polymyxin B is used topically for corneal ulcers, and eye and skin infections. Side effects include dose-related nephrotoxicity, muscle weakness, vertigo, and slurring of speech.

Option D - Glycopeptides inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding with D-alanyl-D-alanine and the class originator drug is vancomycin. It is used in the treatment of MRSA, clostridium difficile, meningitis and staphylococcal endocarditis. Redman syndrome (erythema, flushing, tachycardia and hypotension), ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity are the most important adverse effects.

questions.text: An infant was brought for routine evaluation. On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly. Examination of the fundus revealed a cherry-red spot in the macula. Histopathological examination of splenic tissue is shown below. Electron microscopy shows the presence of zebra bodies. Which of the following lipids is accumulated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathological examination showing lipid-laden foam cells and electron microscopy showing zebra bodies are suggestive of Niemann-Pick disease. Due to the deficiency of sphingomyelinase enzyme, sphingomyelin accumulates in the cells.

Niemann-Pick disease is an autosomal recessive inborn error of lipid metabolism. It results due to the deficiency of the sphingomyelinase enzyme. This results in the accumulation of sphingomyelin in the brain, lung, liver, and spleen.

The clinical features include a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, failure to thrive, severe psychomotor regression, interstitial lung disease, and a cherry-red spot in the macula. 

On histopathology, the affected cells are enlarged due to the deposition of sphingomyelin and cholesterol. They are described as 'foam cells' due to the presence of multiple small vacuoles. Electron microscopy reveals these vacuoles to be engorged lysosomes. They contain characteristic membranous cytoplasmic bodies called zebra bodies. 

Treatment includes dietary restriction of cholesterol. It is fatal in early life.
