questions.text: Which of the following WHO strategies to control trachoma is considered as primordial prevention?
questions.solution:
Environmental cleanliness is considered as primordial prevention in the WHO strategies to control trachoma.

WHO programme for prophylaxis against trachoma infection and prevention of blindness is SAFE strategy. It includes:

  • Surgery - Tertiary prevention.
  • Antibiotic use - Secondary prevention.
  • Facial hygiene - Primary prevention.
  • Environmental changes - Primordial prevention.

Trachoma is chronic keratoconjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and is one of the leading causes of preventable blindness in the world. Features are foreign body sensation, lacrimation, mucoid discharge etc. On examination, conjunctival follicles resembling boiled sago grains are seen. The follicles if present on the bulbar conjunctiva, is pathognomic. Herbert's follicles may be seen at the limbus. The cornea may get infiltrated and vascularized leading to progressive pannus.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures 

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

Related Pearl: Trachoma Staging

The four stages of trachoma according to McCallan are as follows:

Stage 1: Incipient 

  • Immature follicles are present, but clinical symptoms are not obvious.

Stage 2: Established

  • Typical trachomatous lesions without scarring.

Stage 3: Cicatrising

  • Scarring along with active infection.

Stage 4: Healed

  • Only scarring, the disease is either cured or quiet.

questions.text: A man sustained a crush injury and presented with severe pain, soft tissue crepitus, discoloration, and bullae in the affected area. The discharge from the affected site was positive for Nagler's reaction. Which of the following toxins produced by the causative organism is the basis of Nagler's reaction?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens. α-toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens forms the basis of Nagler's reaction.

The α-toxin of C. perfringens has lecithinase activity. When C. perfringens is grown on a media containing egg yolk with the α-antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralization of α-toxin. This is known as Nagler's reaction.

questions.text: You are asked to opine on the age of an adolescent boy allegedly involved in a crime. He claims to be a juvenile and pleads for a trial in the juvenile court. Based on the X-ray shown below, the likely age of the boy is:
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the appearance of pisiform but no fusion of base of 1st metacarpal. Therefore, the age is more than 10 years and less than 17 years. Among the given options, the age of the boy is likely to be <17 years.

The base of all metacarpals appears at 2-3 years of age and fuses at 15 -17 years of age. Since it is not fused in this case, the age is less than 17 years. If it has fused the likely age is more than 15 years.

Pisiform ossification center appears at 10-12 years of age (options C and D). Since it is present in this case, the age of the child is more than 10 years. If it had not appeared, the likely age is <12 years

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18-19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5-6 years of age and fuses at 17-18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be less than 18.

  • Hamate – 3 months (2-4 months)
  • Triquetrum – 3 years
  • Lunate, Scaphoid, trapezoid, Trapezium – 4 years in females and 5 years in males
  • Pisiform – 9 or 10 years in females and 12 years in males

questions.text: In an experiment, the highest recorded value was 39. While calculating the results, it was incorrectly entered as 93. What is the expected change in mean and median as compared to the correct values?

choices.text: Mean will increase & median will remain the same

questions.solution:
Since only the highest number has changed in the given scenario, the median remains unchanged, but the mean will increase.

The mean is calculated by dividing the total number of observations by the sum of the individual observations. As the sum of the total values has increased in this scenario, the mean will also increase.

The median is a measure of the central tendency of data. It is obtained by arranging the data in an ascending or descending order of magnitude and then recording the value of the middle observation. If there is an even number of values, then the median is estimated by taking the average of the two middle values. The median is unaffected by outliers, such as in the given scenario.

questions.text: Transmembrane proteins that contribute to tight junctions include all, except ______.
questions.solution:
Hemidesmosomes attach cells to the underlying basal lamina and are not part of the transmembrane proteins that contribute to tight junction formation. They are connected intracellularly to intermediate filaments. However, unlike desmosomes, they contain integrins rather than cadherins.

Three families of transmembrane proteins are involved in the formation of tight junctions/ zonula occludens:

  1. Occludin
  2. Junctional adhesion molecule
  3. Claudins

Zonula occludens are also known as tight junctions and characteristically surround the apical margins of the cells in epithelia such as the intestinal mucosa, the walls of the renal tubules, and the choroid plexus. Also important to the endothelial barrier function and endothelium-dependent vasodilation. They are made up of ridges- half from one cell and half from another cell- which adhere so strongly that there is no space between the cells. These tight junctions permit the passage of ions, solutes, and intracellular signaling molecules between adjacent cells via the paracellular pathway.

Other intercellular junctions -

Gap junctions:

The gap between the two cells is about 4nm. These junctions are formed by units called connexons, which are present in the membrane of each cell. Each connexon is made up of six protein subunits called connexions. They permit substances to pass between the cells, without entering the ECF.

The pore diameter is around 0.8 to 1.4  nm, which permits the passage of ions, sugars, amino acids, and other solutes which weigh up to 1000 Da. They also permit rapid propagation of electrical activity from cell to cell and the exchange of various chemical messengers and intracellular signalling molecules.

Adherent junctions:

  • Adherent junction or zonula adherens is a continuous structure on the basal side of the zonula occludens.
  • It contains cadherins.

The image below shows adherent junctions.

questions.text: A child diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia develops tumor lysis syndrome after induction chemotherapy. Which of the following serum electrolyte levels will be decreased in this child?
questions.solution:
Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is associated with decreased serum calcium. 

TLS is a potentially life-threatening emergency that happens when tumor cells break down quickly, releasing potassium, phosphate, and uric acid into the bloodstream. It usually occurs 12-48 hours after initiating chemotherapy. It can also happen before starting chemotherapy in patients with a heavy tumor burden.

Hypocalcemia in TLS primarily occurs due to the binding with phosphorus, leading to reduced calcium levels. Possible complications of hypocalcemia include arrhythmia, tetany, and seizures.

TLS is associated with hyperkalemia (option A), hyperphosphatemia (option B), and hyperuricemia (option C). These metabolic abnormalities can also cause arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, and acute kidney injury.  

Treatment chiefly involves adequate hydration to increase the glomerular filtration rate. This allows the excretion of the metabolites associated with tumor lysis. Allopurinol is given to prevent hyperuricemia. In patients with already high serum uric acid levels, rasburicase is preferred to allopurinol.

questions.text: Which of the following structural proteins mediates forward axonal movement in neurons?
questions.solution:
Forward axonal movement is mediated by the structural protein kinesin.

Cytoskeletal filaments are considered the skeletal structure of cells. They provide strength and support to the cell and also help in cellular movements. They are of three types based on size: microtubules, microfilaments, and intermediate filaments.

Microtubules are long, hollow structures that form the dynamic portion of the cytoskeleton due to their constant assembly and disassembly. The structural proteins of microtubules are kinesin, dynein, and tubulin. Kinesin mediates forward axonal movement (cell body to synapse). Dynein mediates reverse axonal movement (synapse to cell body). 

Dynein is involved in the movement of cilia in the lungs, sperm movement, and fallopian tubes. Kartagener’s syndrome is associated with the absence of dynein. Tubulin is involved in the mitosis of cell division. (Options B and C)

Several drugs disrupt cellular function through their interaction with microtubules. Colchicine and vinblastine prevent microtubule assembly. Whereas, Paclitaxel hyper-stabilizes the polymerized microtubules and prevents mitotic cell breakdown. The mitotic spindles cannot form, leading to cell death. 

Other options:

Option D: Vimentin is an intermediate filament that maintains cell structure. It is commonly expressed in connective tissue cells, the majority of which are mesenchymal in origin.

questions.text: Which of the following is a long-acting beta 2 agonist?
questions.solution:
Formoterol is a long-acting beta 2 agonist (LABA).

Long-acting β2-selective agonists (LABA) have a 12-hour duration of action. These drugs have a high lipid solubility and hence dissolve in the smooth muscle cell membrane in high concentrations. Due to their lack of anti-inflammatory action, they are always used in combination with inhalational corticosteroids and are not effective as monotherapy.

β2 receptor agonists are used in the treatment of asthma and COPD. They relax bronchial smooth muscle and decrease airway resistance by acting on the pulmonary receptors. They also reduce the release of leukotrienes and histamine from mast cells in lung tissue, increase mucociliary function, decrease microvascular permeability, and inhibit phospholipase A2. 

Beta 2 agonists are classified based on their duration of action into short-acting, long-acting and very long-acting beta 2 agonists.

Short-acting beta 2 agonists (SABA) are:

  • Salbutamol
  • Terbutaline 
  • Pirbuterol
  • Metaproterenol

Long-acting beta 2 agonists (LABA) are:

  • Salmeterol
  • Formoterol

Very long-acting beta 2 agonists (V-LABA) are:

  • Indacaterol
  • Olodaterol
  • Vilanterol

questions.text: Which of the following tests will not be useful in a patient with nerve injury that is managed as shown below:
questions.solution:
The given image is that of a Knuckle bender splint, which is useful in treating ulnar nerve injuries. Of all the given tests, the pen test is not useful to diagnose ulnar nerve injury/palsy. The pen test is useful in identifying median nerve injuries.

Knuckle bender splint is used in cases of ulnar claw hand where ulnar nerve recovery is anticipated. The splint can be used to correct and prevent metacarpophalangeal hyperextension.

The pen test detects median nerve injury, which helps assess the weakness of the abductor pollicis brevis muscle.

To perform the pen test, the hand is held flat with the palm facing upwards. A pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb. If the patient is unable to touch the pen, it signifies a positive pen test.

Other options: 

Option B: Egawa's test is for the dorsal interossei (abductors) of the middle finger supplied by the ulnar nerve. With palm kept flat on a table, the patient is asked to move his middle finger sideways. Due to the weakness of the dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger are weak.

Book test or Froment's sign (Option C) - Due to weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle, adduction of the thumb is lost. When asked to hold a book, the patient tries to hold the book by using the flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at the interphalangeal joint while holding the book.

Card test (Option D): The examiner inserts a card between two extended fingers of the patient. He asks to hold it as tightly as possible while he tries to pull the card back. Due to loss of adduction by palmar interossei muscles, the patient is unable to hold a card between the fingers.

questions.text: A 30-year-old term primigravida in the second stage of labor was diagnosed with persistent direct occipito-posterior position. What is the most likely type of pelvis?
questions.solution:
The most common type of pelvis associated with persistent direct occipito-posterior position is an anthropoid pelvis. 

Pelvis and their most common associations:

  • Direct occipito-posterior / persistent occipito-posterior : Anthropoid
  • Deep transverse arrest: Android
  • Face-to-pubis delivery: Anthropoid
  • Oblique occipito- posterior position: Android

Occipito-posterior (OP) position of the fetus is when the occiput is situated posteriorly over the sacroiliac joint, or directly over the sacrum. The fetus is in vertex presentation.

In the anthropoid pelvis, the anteroposterior diameter is more than the transverse diameter. As the anthropoid pelvis is wider posteriorly, the fetal occiput occupies the posterior segment of the pelvis. Thus, the fetus is present in the occipito-posterior position which leads to a high chance of face-to-pubis delivery.

Other options:

Option A: The gynaecoid pelvis is the most common type of pelvis which is characterized by a well-rounded inlet, where the posterior sagittal diameter is shorter than the anterior sagittal diameter. 

Option B: The android pelvis typically has a triangular inlet with a narrow anterior segment. It is seen in deep transverse arrest. This type of pelvis increases the risk of perineal injuries. 

Option D: The platypelloid pelvis is characterized by a flattened shape with a widened transverse diameter and reduced anteroposterior diameter. It is associated with brow and face presentation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice. Investigations reveal elevated alkaline phosphatase, elevated bilirubin, and positive antimitochondrial antibodies. Histologic findings show destructive cholangitis and florid duct lesions. Which of the following will help in slowing the progression of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), characterized by fatigue, pruritis, jaundice, and lab findings of elevated alkaline phosphatase, elevated bilirubin, positive antimitochondrial antibodies and biopsy findings of destructive cholangitis and florid duct lesions. Ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) is the first-line treatment for PBC, and it has been shown to slow disease progression.

Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is a chronic autoimmune liver disease characterized by the destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts. It is commonly seen in women aged 40-50 years. Clinical features of PBC include fatigue, debilitating pruritus, and hyperpigmentation. GGT and ALP are significantly elevated with only mild elevation of AST and ALT enzymes. About 90% of the patients will have anti-mitochondrial antibodies. 

Biopsy of the liver shows a florid duct lesion (as given in the image). This is due to the destruction of interlobular bile ducts with lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with or without granuloma formation.

UDCA helps to decrease cholestasis and hepatocellular injury, thus reducing the risk of liver failure and complications. 

Other options: 

Option A: Prednisone is not recommended as monotherapy for PBC.

Option C: Cholestyramine may alleviate pruritus, but it does not slow disease progression.

Option D: Plasmapheresis is not a standard treatment for PBC and is usually reserved for the treatment of pruritis in refractory cases.

questions.text: A patient with Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection was prescribed a parenteral cephalosporin. Within 2 hours of administering the drug, he developed an allergic reaction. The drug was stopped and later aztreonam was administered. The allergic reaction aggravated after aztreonam administration. Which cephalosporin was likely administered at first?
questions.solution:
Ceftazidime was the cephalosporin that was likely to be administered at first. Aztreonam is generally safe for penicillin-allergic patients as there is no allergic cross-reactivity with beta-lactam antibiotics, except when it comes to ceftazidime due to its structural similarities.

Other exceptions also include ceftolozane and cefiderocol, with which aztreonam is structurally similar.

Cephalosporins and cephamycins inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis. They are classified as:

Generation  Uses
First
  • Skin and soft tissue infections
  • Serious infections due to MSSA
  • Perioperative surgical prophylaxis
Second
  • Upper respiratory tract infections (sinusitis, otitis media)
  • Cefoxitin/cefotetan: Gynecologic infections, perioperative surgical prophylaxis
Third
  • Community-acquired pneumonia, meningitis, urinary tract infections
  • Streptococcal endocarditis
  • Gonorrhea
  • Severe Lyme disease
Anti-pseudomonal
  • Nosocomial infections: Pneumonia, meningitis, urinary tract infections, intra-abdominal infections (with metronidazole)
Anti-MRSA
  • Community-acquired pneumonia
  • Skin and soft tissue infections

questions.text: A patient presents with pain at the back of the neck. His x-ray is given below. Identify the fracture.
questions.solution:
The x-ray and the clinical features identify the fracture as clay-shoveller's fracture.

Clay-shoveller’s fracture refers to the avulsion fracture of the C7 spinous process.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with pain during defecation along with the presence of blood-streaked stools. He has had a history of constipation for 5 months. On examination, a sentinel tag is present at the anal orifice. Due to extreme pain, a digital rectal examination is avoided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This case scenario with a history of chronic constipation, and the presence of sentinel tags on examination, suggests a diagnosis of anal fissure.

An anal fissure is a longitudinal split in the anoderm of the distal anal canal. A chronic anal fissure is frequently associated with:

  • Sentinel tag externally
  • Hypertrophied anal papillae internally
  • Anal ulcer overlying the internal sphincter

Anal fissures are usually seen in the young but they can occur at any age with equal sex predilection. Severe pain associated with defecation resolves spontaneously and reappears during the next evacuation. It may even be associated with the passage of fresh blood. 

Most of the fissures are located in the posterior midline followed by the anterior midline. Fissures located anywhere around the anal circumference can be possible due to other diseases like HIV, tuberculosis, syphilis, Crohn's disease, or carcinoma.

Treatment of anal fissure:

  • The focus is to normalize bowel habits. Bowel softeners, dietary fibers, and adequate water should be recommended.
  • Medical therapy involves the topical application of glyceryl trinitrate. It releases nitric oxide and relaxes the internal anal sphincter. This reduces spasms, and pain and improves vasculature to promote healing.
  • Surgical therapy is recommended for chronic fissures that have failed medical therapy. Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice where a portion of the internal sphincter is divided away from the fissure. 

Other options:

Option A: Anal fistula is usually associated with pain and intermittent purulent discharge. On examination, an external opening in the perineum can be found which opens internally in the anal canal.

Option C: Internal hemorrhoids are located proximal to the dentate line. They present with painless bleeding which is separate from the stool, and with a mass near the anal orifice. Pain is not a common feature and is present if hemorrhoids are prolapsed. 

Option D: External hemorrhoids are distal to the dentate line; these may engorge, causing pain. Pain is present throughout the day and is not only associated with defecation or rectal examination. Thrombosis of these external hemorrhoids causes severe pain.

questions.text: A construction worker with prolonged exposure to cement presented with erythema, swelling, and pruritus over his body. Which pair correctly indicates the patient's condition?

choices.text: Chromate exposure & T cell antibody-mediated reaction
Nickel exposure & T cell antibody-mediated reaction
Chromate exposure & B cell antibody-mediated reaction
Nickel exposure & B cell antibody-mediated reaction

questions.solution:
The correct pair among the options is chromate exposure & T cell antibody-mediated reaction.

Based on the history of a construction worker with prolonged cement exposure, occupational allergic contact dermatitis is suspected. Chromate is the most frequent allergen in cement causing occupational contact dermatitis which is due to a type IV hypersensitivity reaction (T cell-mediated). 

Allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) is an inflammatory condition caused by a delayed hypersensitivity reaction (type 4 hypersensitivity - T cell-mediated reaction) to a specific allergen that comes into direct contact with the skin. Some common allergens include nickel (found in artificial jewelry), PPD/Para phenylene diamine (in hair dye), chromate (in cement), rubber or latex, cosmetics, etc. Patch test is used for the diagnosis of ACD.

The image below shows the patch test.

Acute management of the flare can be done with topical corticosteroids and topical calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus, pimecrolimus). For severe, extensive involvement, systemic corticosteroids can be used. 

Long-term treatment of allergic contact dermatitis involves avoidance of the allergen. The allergen International Nomenclature Cosmetic Ingredient (INCI) name can be provided to the patient as this is the name that will be used on product labels.

questions.text: What is the most common hematological manifestation that you would expect to see in patients with SLE?
questions.solution:
The most common hematologic manifestation of SLE is anemia of chronic disease.

Hematologic complications in decreasing order of incidence:

  • Anemia of chronic disease
  • Leukopenia (<4000/μL)
  • Lymphopenia (<1500/μL)
  • Thrombocytopenia (<100,000/μL)
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Splenomegaly
  • Hemolytic anemia

Most common manifestations of different systems involved in SLE:

  • Musculoskeletal: arthritis and arthralgia
  • Dermatologic: photosensitivity
  • Renal: proteinuria
  • Neurologic: cognitive impairment
  • Cardiac: pericarditis
  • Pulmonary: pleuritis
  • Hematologic: anemia

questions.text: Which of the following are the components of Nigro regimen used for the management of anal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Nigro regimen is the primary therapy for squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the anal canal. It includes a combination of chemotherapy and radiation therapy (combined modality therapy).

A combination of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) with mitomycin C/ cisplatin is followed by external beam radiation to the pelvis with a minimum dose of 45 Gy.

If any residual tumour is left behind after chemoradiation, abdominoperineal resection (APR) is performed.

The most common type of anal canal carcinoma is SCC followed by adenocarcinoma. The patient presents with perianal mass, pain, anal discharge, and bleeding. The most common site of metastasis is the liver. The nodal metastasis is seen in peri-rectal and inguinal lymph nodes. Risk factors for carcinoma anal canal include HPV infection (16, 18, 31, 33), HIV or immunosuppression, and anal receptive intercourse.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with acute onset of pain in his right scrotum. Physical examination shows a swollen erythematous scrotum with an absent cremasteric reflex. On Doppler ultrasound, there is an absence of arterial flow to the right testis. Surgical exploration is done and the testis was not necrotic. What is to be done for the testis in the contralateral scrotum?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a boy presenting with acute pain in the scrotum, absent cremasteric reflex, and absent arterial flow on doppler is suggestive of testicular torsion. During surgical management of testicular torsion, orchiopexy at the same sitting is to be done for the contralateral testis which is viable.

Testicular torsion is a condition where the blood supply to the testis is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord resulting in ischemia of epididymis and testis. The condition is most common in adolescent males. The risk factors for torsion testis are undescended testis, testicular tumor, and bell-clapper deformity of the gubernaculum.

Clinical features of testicular torsion are painful scrotal swelling, erythema, nausea, and vomiting, apyrexia. Testis seems to be high in the scrotum and the tender, twisted spermatic cord can sometimes be palpated. The cremasteric reflex is lost on the side of the affected testis.

A diagnosis is arrived at primarily on clinical grounds. Doppler ultrasound scanning shows absent or decreased intratesticular blood flow compared to the contralateral side.

Immediate scrotal exploration is indicated even if there is a doubt regarding the diagnosis. An incision is taken along the midline (median raphe) or bilateral scrotal incisions are taken.

Surgical placement of the testicle in the scrotum is called orchidopexy (or orchiopexy). It is primarily used as a procedure to correct undescended testis but it is also used in testicular torsion.

Initially, the testis is detorsed and an intraoperative Doppler ultrasound is done. If the testis is found to be viable, a three-point fixation with non-absorbable sutures between the tunica albuginea and dartos fascia of the testis is done to prevent recurrence. 

In the same exploration, orchiopexy should be done to the contralateral testes to prevent future contralateral torsion as there is a chance for the same anatomical deformity to be present in the contralateral side.

Other options:

Options A and D: Contralateral testis will be at high risk of torsion in the future. Hence, orchidopexy has to be done in the same surgical exploration.

Option B: Orchidectomy is preferred in non-viable or necrotic testes.

questions.text: A child with sickle cell anemia presents with fever and fatigue for 1 week. Blood tests revealed a hemoglobin level of 5 g/dL, reticulocytopenia, and normal platelet and leukocyte counts. Parvovirus B19 serology test is positive. What is the pathophysiology behind the patient’s condition?

choices.text: Bone marrow infiltration by malignant cells

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with sickle cell anemia presenting with fever, fatigue, and investigations revealing hemoglobin of 5 g/dL, reticulocytopenia, and a positive parvovirus B19 serology test is suggestive of aplastic crisis. It is due to erythroid progenitor cell destruction.

Aplastic crisis may be seen in patients with underlying chronic hemolytic anemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, or hereditary spherocytosis. Dysmorphic erythrocytes in sickle cell disease are susceptible to parvovirus B19 infection. The P antigen on erythroid and endothelial cells is the receptor for the virus. 

Patients with aplastic crisis present with fever, malaise, tachycardia, and dyspnea due to profound anemia. There is an acute, severe drop in hemoglobin and associated reticulocytopenia due to progenitor cell destruction. 

Parvovirus B19 is a small, single-stranded DNA virus. Infection can be transmitted via respiratory droplets, or by vertical transmission. It can cause erythema infectiosum in children presenting with fever, erythematous facial flushing (“slapped cheek” appearance), and a diffuse rash over the trunk and extremities as shown below:


Congenital parvovirus B19 infection can cause hydrops fetalis and death of the fetus. In adults, it can cause infectious arthritis or pure red cell aplasia (especially in immunocompromised).

Other options:

Option B: Autoantibody mediated hemolysis is seen in patients with conditions chronic lymphocytic leukemia and viral infections which precipitate autoimmune hemolytic anemia. It is not seen in parvovirus infection. 

Option C and D: Suppression of erythropoietin production and malignant infiltration are not the mechanism of aplastic crisis in parvovirus B19 patients.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders has an impaired thermoregulatory mechanism?
questions.solution:
Heat stroke is a severe heat disorder that occurs when the body's thermoregulatory mechanism fails. Sweating is absent in this condition. 

Heat stroke is likely to occur when the body temperature rises to 106-108 °F (normal 98.6 °F).

Heatstroke symptoms indicate a complete loss of thermoregulatory function. Common vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, various tachycardias, hypotension, and a widened pulse pressure. 

The patients present with three main symptoms: hot, dry skin, dilated pupils, and a rectal temperature > 106°F. At these high temperatures, the body's temperature-regulating mechanisms often fail.

Heat stroke can occur in two forms:

  • Classic heat stroke (CHS) is seen in elderly individuals with chronic diseases who are predisposed to heat-related illnesses.
  • Exertional heat stroke (EHS) is seen in young, previously healthy people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures. 

Heat stroke is a medical emergency, and the patient should receive treatment as soon as possible to decrease their temperature. The management involves actively cooling the patient by moving them to a cool place, applying a cold cloth, and giving them a cold water bath. Fluid replacement should also be done.

Other options: 

Option A: Heat syncope is caused by prolonged standing and working in a hot environment. The intact thermoregulatory mechanism causes vasodilation and venous pooling, which reduces blood flow to the heart and brain. This results in a syncopal attack and unconsciousness. Treatment involves recovery by lying down.

Option B: Heat cramps are a mild heat disorder caused by working in a hot environment. The intact thermoregulatory mechanism causes profuse sweating and loss of electrolytes, resulting in muscle pain and cramps. Treatment includes the replacement of electrolyte fluids.

Option D: Heat exhaustion/ heat collapse is due to excess vasodilation due to intact thermoregulatory mechanism which leads to reduced diastolic filling of the heart. The patient presents with dilated pupils and loss of consciousness. Treatment involves making the patient lie down and replacing fluids.

questions.text: A patient who has been on theophylline for several weeks has complaints of gastric discomfort and increased urinary frequency.  He has recently been prescribed a drug for the management of chronic gout. The symptoms were attributed to theophylline toxicity caused by an interaction with the newly prescribed drug. Identify the prescribed drug.
questions.solution:
The drug that was prescribed for gout in this case is most likely to be allopurinol. 

Allopurinol decreases the clearance of theophylline. It inhibits CYP1A2 in the liver, and theophylline is mainly metabolized by CYP1A2 in the liver. This leads to plasma concentration–dependent side effects of theophylline. 

The toxicity and side effects of theophylline are mostly dose-related and generally tend to occur at plasma concentrations greater than 15 mg/L. The adverse effects and their mechanism are summarized below:

       Side effect         Mechanism
Nausea, vomiting, gastric discomfort    PDE4 inhibition
Headaches    PDE4 inhibition
Diuresis / increased urinary frequency     A1 receptor antagonism
Cardiac arrhythmias     PDE3 and A1 receptor antagonism
Epileptic seizures     A1 receptor antagonism

Theophylline belongs to a class of drugs called methylxanthines. It can be given intravenously or orally as tablets or elixirs. Its therapeutic range is 5–15 mg/L and has antiasthma effects (besides bronchodilatation) below 10 mg/L.

Once administered, it is rapidly and completely absorbed, but there are large interindividual variations in clearance due to differences in hepatic metabolism. Theophylline is metabolized in the liver, mainly by CYP1A2 and many factors influence hepatic metabolism and clearance of theophylline.

Factors that decrease the clearance of theophylline:

  • Drugs that cause CYP inhibition - erythromycin, cimetidine, ciprofloxacin, allopurinol, fluvoxamine, zileuton, zafirlukast
  • Congestive heart failure, liver disease, pneumonia
  • Viral infection and vaccination
  • High-carbohydrate diet
  • Old age

Factors increasing its clearance:

  • Drugs like rifampin and ethanol, which are inducers of enzymes such as CYP1A2
  • Tobacco and marijuana smoking, by CYP1A2 induction
  • High-protein, low-carbohydrate diet
  • Barbequed meat

It has been used as a controller in the management of mild persistent asthma and is also used as a bronchodilator in COPD.

questions.text: A neonate presented with gasping and cyanosis after an episode of vigorous crying in the morning. Chest x-ray showed the following finding. Which cardiac valve is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of a neonate having cyanosis after an episode of vigorous crying, and chest X-ray showing a "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, are suggestive of a cyanotic heart disease called Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). The pulmonary valve is affected in this condition.

TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease with the following four components:

  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)
  • Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta), and
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

The severity of symptoms depends on the degree of the right ventricular outflow obstruction. In mild degrees, the symptoms become pronounced as the baby grows due to RV infundibular hypertrophy and may present with heart failure. In severe degrees, pulmonary blood flow predominantly depends on the ductus arteriosus. As soon as the duct closes, the baby presents with cyanosis and circulatory collapse in the neonatal period.

The image given below shows the cardinal features seen in TOF:


Clinical features include significant hypercyanotic spells in infants which are characterized by hyperpnea, cyanosis, and gasping followed by syncope. The spells occur most frequently in the morning on initial awakening or after episodes of vigorous crying. These spells are due to a prolonged reduction of pulmonary blood flow resulting in severe systemic hypoxia and metabolic acidosis.

Older children present with exertional dyspnea and assume a squatting position to relieve the dyspneic episode after which the child can resume activity.

The boot-shaped cardiac silhouette is seen due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex. The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively oligemic due to diminished pulmonary blood flow. The below image shows the chest X-ray findings:

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient came with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and drowsiness after consuming infested grains, as shown in the image below. Which of the following methods is employed in removing the contaminated grains?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 24-year-old male patient presenting with nausea, vomiting, and drowsiness after consuming wheat grains infested with a blackish fungal mass as shown in the image is suggestive of ergotism. Floatation in 20% salt water is employed to remove the Ergot-infested grains. 

Ergot or Claviceps purpurae is a field fungus. Food grains like bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat tend to get contaminated with this ergot fungus. It grows as a blackish mass and the seeds become black and irregular. These get harvested along with the food grains and consumption of this ergot-infested grain leads to ergotism.  

Acute cases present with nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness for a period of up to 24 to 48 hours after the ingestion of ergot grain. In cases of chronic consumption, they present with painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries. 

Ergot-infested grains can be removed easily by floating them in 20% saltwater. Air floatation and handpicking can also be done. 0.05 mg per 100 grams of food material is the upper safe limit for ergot alkaloids.

Options B and C: Parboiling and Steeping are methods employed in removing the Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) toxin from the lathyrus seeds (Khesari dhal)  responsible for neurolathyrism. 

Parboiling involves soaking the dal in limewater overnight and then boiling it.

Steeping involves soaking the dal in hot water for 2 hours. The dal is then washed with cleaned water and dried before consumption.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient comes for a prenatal exam at 27 weeks of gestation. USG shows a monochorionic multifetal pregnancy with the largest vertical pocket of 10 cm in one twin and 1 cm in the other twin. Both twins appear morphologically normal although growth discordance is identified. What is the likely underlying cause of this finding?

choices.text: Single uterine artery in the small fetus

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with monochorionic multifetal gestations and growth discordance with the largest vertical pocket (LVP) of 10 cm in one twin, indicated polyhydramnios, and 1 cm in the other twin, indicating oligohydramnios, should raise concerns for interfetal transfusion syndrome also known as twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS). 

TTTS is a clinicopathological condition found only in monozygotic twins in which one twin appears to bleed into the other via a placental vascular anastomosis.

Clinical signs of twin transfusion syndrome appear when there is a hemodynamic imbalance brought on by unidirectional deep arteriovenous anastomoses. As a result, the donor twin shrinks with oligohydramnios, anemia, hypotension, and hypovolemia, while the receptor twin grows larger with polyhydramnios, polycythemic, hypertensive, and hypervolemic characteristics. Due to severe oligohydramnios, the donor twin may seem "stuck". The hemoglobin concentration differential between the two is typically greater than 5 g%, and the estimated fetal weight discrepancy is at least 25%.

The diagnosis of TTTS is based on two sonographic criteria. First is the identification of a monochorionic pregnancy, and second is the identification of polyhydramnios (LVP > 8 cm) in one fetus and oligohydramnios (LVP < 2 cm) in the other. Growth discordance is seen but is not a diagnostic criterion. 

Management of this condition is usually with obliteration of some of the shared vessels as it can lead to heart failure in the hyperperfused twin.

Other options:

Option B: Twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP) is a complication seen in monochorionic multifetal gestation. It is caused by a large artery-to-artery or vein-to-vein placental shunt. Unlike TTTS, there is no arteriovenous anastomosis. The recipient twin lacks a cardiac system, while the donor twin does the work of supplying blood for both twins. Blood from the donor twin reaches the iliac vessels of the recipient twin through the umbilical arteries. Therefore the recipient twin appears malformed, as only the lower body is developed, while the upper body is poorly developed. The donor twin may show signs of heart failure.

Option C: Single uterine artery is a malformation seen in some fetuses with an associated genetic condition. However, the presence of a small and large fetus should raise concerns about interfetal transfusion syndrome.

Option D: Twin anemia–polycythemia sequence (TAPS) is similar to TTTS, where the donor twin is anemic and smaller than the recipient twin, which is polycythemic. However, unlike TTTS, the amniotic fluid volumes in TAPS are similar for both fetuses.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the prevention of surgical site infection concerning surgical care improvement project performance measures?

choices.text: Hair removal with razors from the operative site done before the surgery
Prophylactic antibiotics are given 4 hours before the surgery
Blood glucose is maintained < 200 mg/dl for 48 hours after surgery
Prophylactic antibiotics can be given up to 5 days

questions.solution:
According to the surgical care improvement project performance (SCIP) measure guidelines, blood glucose is maintained < 200 mg/dl for 48 hours (2 days) after surgery. Other guidelines include:

  • Antibiotic prophylaxis - 1 hour before surgery (2 hours for vancomycin or fluoroquinolone) (Option B)
  • Antibiotic prophylaxis - discontinued in 24 hours after surgery (48 hours after cardiac surgery) (Option D)
  • Blood glucose should be maintained at < 200mg/dl for the first 2 days after surgery.
  • Hair removal must never be done, however, if needed, only clippers or depilatory agents have to be used. Razors should never be used. (Option A)
  • For colorectal surgeries, normothermia (96.8 F to 100.4 F) must be maintained in the first hour after surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of cholecystokinin?

choices.text: Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi

questions.solution:
Cholecystokinin(CCK) inhibits gastric emptying, it does not stimulate it.

CCK is secreted by I cells in the mucosa of the upper small intestine. It is also found in nerves in the distal ileum and colon, and neurons in the cerebral cortex. Its functions include:

  • Stimulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion (option A)
  • Gallbladder contraction
  • Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi to allow the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the intestinal lumen (option D)
  • Inhibits gastric emptying
  • Increases the synthesis of enterokinase
  • Enhances the motility of the small intestine and colon (option C)
  • Increases the action of secretin, alkalizing the pancreatic juice
  • Trophic effect on the pancreas

The secretion of CCK is increased by:

  • Products of digestion like peptides and amino acids coming in contact with the intestinal mucosa
  • Presence of fatty acids containing >10 C atoms in the duodenum
  • CCK-releasing peptide and monitor peptide

Bile and pancreatic juice enter the duodenum in response to CCK, enhancing the digestion of protein and fat. The products of this digestion stimulate further CCK secretion, as positive feedback. However, this positive feedback is terminated when the products of digestion move further down the GI tract.

Related Pearl: Stimuli for gastric secretion

Stimuli

Mechanism

Applied aspects

Vagal stimulation

Direct pathway

Vagus nerve innervates parietal cells and stimulates H+ secretion directly.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is Ach, the receptor on the parietal cells is muscarinic (M3)

The second messengers for CCK are IP3 and increased intracellular [Ca2+].

Atropine, a cholinergic muscarinic antagonist, inhibits H+ secretion by blocking the direct pathway, which uses ACh as a neurotransmitter. However, it does not block H+ secretion completely because it does not inhibit the indirect pathway, which uses GRP as a neurotransmitter

Indirect pathway

Vagus nerve innervates G cells and stimulates gastrin secretion, which then stimulates H+ secretion.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is GRP (not ACh).

Vagotomy eliminates both direct and indirect pathways.

Gastrin

Released in response to eating a meal (small peptides, distension of the stomach, vagal stimulation).

Stimulates H+ secretion by interacting with the cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on the parietal cells.

The second messenger for gastrin on the parietal cell is IP3/Ca2+.

  

Histamine

Released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa and diffuses to the nearby parietal cells.

Stimulates H+ secretion by activating H2 receptors on the parietal cell membrane.

The H2 receptor is coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gs protein.

The second messenger for histamine is cAMP.

H2 receptor–blocking drugs, such as cimetidine, inhibit H+ secretion by blocking the stimulatory effect of histamine.

questions.text: A term newborn delivered from a cesarean delivery has tachypnea and expiratory grunting. On examination, lung fields are clear. Chest X-ray shows fluid in interlobar fissures. What is the likely outcome for this newborn?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a term newborn having tachypnea, expiratory grunting, and chest X-ray showing fluid in interlobar fissures is suggestive of transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN). The likely outcome of the condition is resolution without any sequelae.

TTN is caused due to delayed resorption of fetal lung fluid. Risk factors for the condition include twin pregnancy, asthma in the mother, precipitous delivery, gestational diabetes, and a cesarean delivery.

Presenting symptoms such as tachypnea, expiratory grunting, and retractions are relieved with minimal oxygen supplementation. Chest X-ray shows fluid in the intralobar fissures and prominent perihilar pulmonary vascular markings. 

Most infants recover with supportive care. The condition is self-limited and there are no long-term complications.

Other options:

Option A: Recurrent pulmonary infections can be seen in patients with cystic fibrosis. Cystic fibrosis usually presents with meconium ileus in newborns.

Option B: Persistent pulmonary hypertension is a complication of meconium aspiration syndrome. It occurs in post-term infants with the presence of meconium-stained fluid.

Option C: Bronchopulmonary dysplasia is a complication of respiratory distress syndrome. It usually occurs in preterm infants due to surfactant deficiency. Chest X-ray findings include ground glass opacities and air bronchogram.

questions.text: An agglutination test was done to identify blood groups in several people. Subjects with which of the following findings are called universal blood recipients?
questions.solution:
The agglutination test in image 2 corresponds to the AB-positive blood group. The AB-positive blood group is the universal recipient type. 

Blood typing or blood matching is done before transfusions to avoid incompatibility. Red blood cells (RBC) are first separated from plasma and diluted with saline solution for an agglutination test. Anti-A and anti-B agglutinins are added to different portions. If RBCs are clumped/agglutinated, then an antigen-antibody reaction has occurred.

Antigens A and B are seen on the surfaces of the red blood cells. Depending on inheritance, people have one or both on the surface of their cells. When neither of them is present, the blood type is O. Based on the antigens present, blood is classified into four main types: O (OO), A (OA/AA), B (OB/BB), and AB. 

When the A or B agglutinins are absent in the body, corresponding anti-agglutinins (anti-A or anti-B) are found in the plasma. Those with AB blood group have no circulating anti-agglutinins and do not develop transfusion reactions due to ABO incompatibility. Therefore, people with type AB blood are called universal recipients. They are also considered universal plasma donors.

Rh type system is also essential for blood transfusion. The difference with the A-B-O system is that the antibodies to Rh antigen in people without Rh antigen occur after exposure and not spontaneously. 

Other options:

Option A: The given agglutination test is suggestive of O positive blood type. 

Option C: The test result shows agglutination with anti-A agglutinin and suggests blood type A negative.

Option D: The given test result shows no agglutination and suggests blood type O negative. People with blood type O negative are considered as universal donors.

questions.text:
How many of the seeds in the image below are considered fatal if ingested, and what disease do the symptoms closely resemble in a case of poisoning from consuming these 
seeds?
questions.solution:
The image shows seeds of Strychnos-nux vomica which contains strychnine. The fatal dose is one crushed seed or 15-30 mg of strychnine and strychnine poisoning produces symptoms that resemble tetanus.

If swallowed uncrushed, the seeds of nux vomica have no poisonous action as they are not dissolved in the gastrointestinal tract, and are passed entirely in the feces.

Strychnine is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postganglionic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to increased activity in the motor neurons. 

Patients typically present with symptoms similar to tetanus such as

  • Convulsions are clonic initially but eventually become tonic. The anti-gravity muscles experience the most severe convulsions, causing the body to typically arch in hyperextension—a position called opisthotonus.
  • Risus sardonicus which results from the contraction of the jaws and facial muscles in which the corners of the mouth are drawn back.
  • If the spasm involves the abdominal muscles, the body bends forward (emprosthotonos), or to the side (pleurosthotonus).
  • If death is preceded by a severe convulsion, as in strychnine poisoning, it causes an increase in the body temperature known as postmortem caloricity.

The first step in the management of strychnine poisoning is to control convulsions with benzodiazepines or barbiturates and the patients should be placed in a dark room to avoid triggering further convulsions. Activated charcoal can be used to adsorb unabsorbed poison after a thorough stomach wash. Acidification of urine can be done to increase the excretion of strychnine.

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

The clinical features of strychnine poisoning are:

  • Convulsions - clonic-tonic type
  • Reflex increased
  • Awful taste
  • Mind is conscious
  • Pupils dilated
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus - fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Although a poison, in relatively low doses it can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who underwent abdominal surgery under general anesthesia developed lung atelectasis. Reduction in which of the following parameters is primarily responsible for this patient's respiratory failure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of perioperative lung atelectasis is indicative of type III respiratory failure. This is caused by decreased functional residual capacity due to the effects of general anesthesia.

Following general anesthesia, there is a decline in functional residual capacity attributed to diminished muscular tone. Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a regular tidal expiration, serving as the balance point between lung and chest wall recoil forces. The reduction in FRC leads to airway closure and collapse of dependent lung units, leading to atelectasis.

Type III respiratory failure arises from lung atelectasis, a condition commonly observed in the perioperative phase, and is therefore termed perioperative respiratory failure. 

Management involves frequent repositioning, chest physiotherapy, maintaining an upright posture, and ensuring adequate pain control. Additionally, noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation can be employed to reverse regional atelectasis.

Forced expiratory volume (FEV) is a measure of the volume of air forcibly exhaled in one second during a pulmonary function test. While reduced FEV may indicate airway obstruction in conditions like chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), it is not the primary parameter responsible for type III respiratory failure.

questions.solution:
The correctly matched set is 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B (option A), as shown in the table below:

Systemic Mycoses Histopathological features

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with chronic pancreatitis was referred to a surgeon who plans to perform the following procedure on him. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The image shows a distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy indicative of the Duval procedure.

It is a drainage procedure for chronic pancreatitis. It was developed on the basis of a presumption that a single stricture of the duct of Wirsung near the ampulla was responsible for the obstructive pathology and terminal drainage would treat the condition. It consists of distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy. But it almost invariably failed due to restenosis and segmental obstruction of the pancreas due to progressive scarring.

Chronic pancreatitis is associated with multiple strictures and stones in the pancreatic duct. This leads to the alternate stenosis and dilatation of the pancreatic duct leading to the chain of lakes appearance.

The etiology of chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency can be classified based on the TIGAR-O classification system:

  • Toxic-metabolic -alcohol, smoking, hypercalcemia, hyperlipidemia
  • Idiopathic
  • Genetic- PRSS1, CFTR, and SPINK1 genes
  • Autoimmune- autoimmune chronic pancreatitis, IgG4-related disease
  • Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis
  • Obstructive- pancreas divisum, duct obstruction, malignancy

The diagnosis can be made using Rosemont criteria. It is based on endoscopic ultrasonographic (EUS) findings. It is explained in the pearl attached below. 

Treatment:

Resection or hybrid surgical procedures as attached in the pearl below. 

Related Pearl: Surgical procedures for chronic pancreatitis

Duval procedure: Distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy

Puestow procedure: Resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

Partington and Rochelle modification of Puestow procedure: Elimination of resection of the pancreatic tail

A longitudinal pancreatotomy shows segmental stenosis of the pancreatic duct and the presence of intraductal calculi in a patient with chronic calcific pancreatitis. Following mobilization of a Roux limb of the jejunum, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is performed to permit extensive drainage of the pancreatic duct system.

Related Pearl: Resection and Hybrid Surgical Procedures for Chronic Pancreatitis

Beger’s procedure: Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (DPPHR)

  • The completed resection after transection of the pancreatic neck and subtotal removal of the pancreatic head, with preservation of the distal common bile duct and duodenum (Marked A).
  • Completion of the reconstruction of the anastomosis to the distal pancreas and to the proximal pancreatic rim by the same Roux limb of the jejunum.

Frey’s procedure:

  • The local resection of the pancreatic head with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LR-LPJ) provides complete decompression of the entire pancreatic ductal system. Reconstruction is performed with a side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy.

Warren’s modification of Beger’s procedure:

Berne modification (Beger + Frey) involves excavation of the central portion of the head without formal division of the neck.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presents with severe joint pain in her left knee and an inability to move the distal interphalangeal joints of her hand. She has a family history of psoriasis. Which of the following is the classical radiological finding in such cases?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette mentions left knee involvement (asymmetrical joint involvement) with the inability to move the distal joint (arthritis of small joints in the finger), and a family history of psoriasis, suggesting the diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. Pencil-in-cup deformity with subluxation of the thumb is a classical radiological finding in psoriatic arthritis. 

These changes occur due to periarticular erosion and bony resorption. The image below shows the pencil-in-cup deformity in psoriatic arthritis:


Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory musculoskeletal disease characteristically occurring in individuals with psoriasis. It usually develops before 40 years of age. In the hands, the most common joint involved is the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP). It also involves the PIP and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP).

The image below shows psoriatic arthritis of the hands:


Clinical features include asymmetric joint involvement, early morning stiffness, enthesitis, dactylitis, and nail changes (hyperkeratosis and onycholysis). Inflammatory markers like CRP and ESR are elevated. Plain X-rays of the hands and feet in erosive disease show:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity of distal interphalangeal joint
  • Marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation 'whiskering'

NSAIDs, steroid injections, methotrexate, and cyclosporin/ biologicals can be used for the management of this condition. Tofacitinib is a novel, oral JAK 1/3 - Inhibitor that has been approved for the treatment of psoriatic arthritis.

Other options:

Option A- Boutonnière deformity- It is a flexion deformity of the fingers. It presents as flexion deformity at the PIP joint and extension of the DIP joint. It is caused by disruption of the extensor tendon due to trauma or rheumatic disease.

Option B- Swan-neck deformity- It presents as hyperextension of the PIP joint and flexion of the DIP joint (the reverse of Boutonnière deformity). It can occur due to an imbalance of the action of flexors and extensors at the PIP joint and failure of the palmar plate of PIP in conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis or lax joints.


Option C- Z-thumb deformity- It is seen in rheumatoid arthritis. It presents with hyperextension of the interphalangeal joint and flexion of the metacarpophalangeal joint.

questions.text:
According to the IMNCI guidelines, what is the appropriate rate of rehydration for a two-year-old child suffering from severe dehydration using intravenous fluids?

[IMNCI- Integrated Management of Neonatal & Childhood Illnesses]

choices.text: 30 ml/kg in the first hour, followed by 70 ml/kg in the next five hours
50 ml/kg in the first hour, followed by 50 ml/kg in the next five hours
30 ml/kg in the first 30 minutes, followed by 70 ml/kg in the next 2 ½ hours
50 ml/kg in the first 30 minutes, followed by 50 ml/kg in the next 2 ½ hours

questions.solution:
For a child above 1 year of age, the appropriate rate of rehydration for treating severe dehydration is 30 ml/kg in the first 30 minutes, followed by 70 ml/kg in the next 2 ½ hours.

Children presenting with severe dehydration are started immediately on intravenous fluids preferably Ringer lactate with 5% dextrose. Alternatively, normal saline or plain Ringer solution can also be used.

Children are given a total of 100 ml/kg of fluid for severe dehydration. Children below 1 year of age are administered that amount over 6 hours. Children above 1 year of age are given that amount over 3 hours.

questions.text: An asthmatic patient presents with bilateral nasal stuffiness. On rhinoscopy, multiple grape-like masses were seen. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

choices.text: It can be associated with aspirin intolerance
It originates from the ethmoidal sinus and uncinate process
The masses grow anteriorly and can present at the nares
They are sensitive to probing and bleed on touch

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an asthmatic patient presenting with bilateral nasal stuffiness and rhinoscopy showing multiple grape-like masses is suggestive of ethmoidal polyps. They are insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch. Hence, option D is incorrect.

Ethmoidal polyps can be seen in patients with asthma. The condition can be associated with aspirin intolerance (option A). They may present with the Samter triad which consists of:

  • Nasal polyps
  • Asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

Ethmoidal polyps are bilateral, and more common in adults. They originate from the ethmoidal sinus, uncinate process (option B), middle turbinate, and middle meatus. The polyps grow anteriorly and can present at the nares (option C).

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

Related Pearl: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation: Nasal endoscopy: Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated. NonContrast CT scan: Gives exquisite bony detail of the paranasal sinus anatomy. It is the primary diagnostic imaging modality.
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: A young man was brought unconscious to casualty following a road traffic accident. CT scan appeared normal. MRI showed multiple small hemorrhages in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain with no midline shift. The most probable cause is -
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a high-impact injury (road traffic accident) with a normal CT scan and microhemorrhages on MRI points toward the diagnosis of Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI).

Diffuse axonal injury (white matter shearing) is the result of shearing forces, typically from a rotational acceleration of the brain within the rigid cranium. This causes damage to microvasculature and also leads to disruption of axons in the subcortical parasagittal white matter, cerebellum, fornix, and internal and external capsule. Most commonly it occurs in automobile accidents. Patients are usually unconscious from the moment of impact and remain the same until death.

Diffuse axonal injury is characterized by multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution:

  • CT may be normal.
  • MRI is the modality of choice for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury even in patients with entirely normal CT of the brain.
  • MRI, especially SWI (susceptibility-weighted imaging) demonstrates small regions of susceptibility artefact or hemorrhage.

The image below shows an SWI in DAI.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

  • Changes in permeability of the axolemma
  • Axonal swelling
  • Intracellular calcium accumulation
  • Proteolysis
  • The collapse of the cytoskeleton
  • 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.
  • Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presented with complaints of bloody urine mostly during the night time. Laboratory investigations show pancytopenia and elevated LDH levels. Ham test was found to be positive. What is the gold standard investigation done for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of bloody urine during the night, pancytopenia, elevated LDH levels, and positive Ham test are suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) and flow cytometry is the gold standard investigation.

PNH is a chronic acquired hemolytic anemia that occurs due to mutations in the PIGA gene. PIGA is an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of certain membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins.

Thus, PNH blood cells are deficient in three glycosylphosphatidylinositols (GPI) linked proteins that regulate complement activity:

  • Decay accelerating factors or CD55
  • Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis or CD59
  • C8 binding protein

Clinically, the patient would have hemolysis, pancytopenia, and a tendency for venous thrombosis. Intravascular hemolysis may be nocturnal and paroxysmal or chronic hemolysis without the dramatic hemoglobinuria. Blood investigations reveal iron deficiency anemia (due to chronic hemoglobinuria) and elevated LDH levels.

Investigations in PNH include:

  • Flow cytometry (gold standard) - deficiency of CD59 and CD55
  • Ham test (acidified serum lysis) - lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH due to complement fixation
  • Bone marrow biopsy -
    • Hypercellularity with erythroid hyperplasia is seen in classical presentations
    • Patients who develop pancytopenia will have hypocellular bone marrow
  • Imaging - to evaluate venous thrombosis

Treatment involves the use of eculizumab, a monoclonal antibody that prevents the conversion of the complement C5 to C5a.

Other options:

Option B: Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is obtained by assessing the staining intensity in 100 consecutive neutrophils, with each neutrophil scored on a scale of 1–4. Conditions that result in an increase in leukocytes in all stages of maturity will reflect a corresponding increase in LAP. LAP is increased in leukemoid reaction and decreased in CML, and hence helps to differentiate the two.

Option C: Coombs test detects antibodies against blood components, and is positive in autoimmune causes of anemia.

Option D: Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH) helps in the detection of specific genetic information on morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes. FISH can be performed on prenatal samples, peripheral blood cells, touch preparations from cancer biopsies, and even fixed archival tissue sections. It is used to detect chromosomal aneuploidy, subtle microdeletions and rearrangements, complex translocations, and gene amplification.

questions.text: What is the use of the following instrument?

choices.text: To fix a chalazion during incision and drainage
To separate uveal tissue from sclera during evisceration
To engage the optic nerve during enucleation
To enlarge the bony opening during dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)

questions.solution:
The given image is an image of a chalazion clamp. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and drainage operation (Option A).

The chalazion clamp consists of two limbs like forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. Excessive tightening of the screw can lead to pressure necrosis. The solid blade is placed externally on the skin and the ring-shaped blade is on the inner conjunctival surface.

Other options:

Option B: An evisceration spatula is used to separate the uveal tissue from the sclera during the evisceration operation. It consists of a small but stout rectangular blade with a slightly convex surface and blunt edges attached to a handle.

Option C: An enucleation spoon is used to engage the optic nerve in enucleation. It is identified by the central cleavage present to accommodate the optic nerve.

Option D - A bone punch is used to enlarge the bony opening during dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening. It consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle.

questions.solution:

Note: The FDA has approved cefepime-enmetazobactam, a combination of a fourth-generation cephalosporin and beta-lactamase inhibitor for use in complicated UTIs (including pyelonephritis).

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy was brought with complaints of a fishy smell in his hands, feet, saliva, and urine. A urinalysis revealed the substance responsible for the odor, and a diagnosis of Fish odor syndrome was made. Which is the substance responsible for this characteristic body odor?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of fish odor syndrome, the characteristic odor is due to trimethylamine (TMA), which is released in sweat, urine, and breath.

Fish odor syndrome (trimethylaminuria) is an autosomal recessive disease. It is due to a deficiency of flavin-containing monooxygenase 3 (FMO3) which converts the amino acid, TMA (trimethylamine) to TMA-N-oxide (which is non-odorous) in the liver. TMA thus builds up in the body and is released in sweat, urine, and breath, giving off a strong odor of rotting fish from the body.

Patients present in childhood or early adulthood with halitosis or body odor (distinctive fishy odor). Patients suffer from psychosocial problems such as shame, anxiety, depression, etc. Diagnosis is based on high levels of excreted trimethylamine (TMA) in the patient's urine. 

Treatment involves avoiding foods containing choline such as egg, liver, peas, and soy products. A short course of antibiotics such as neomycin and metronidazole can be given which reduce the production of trimethylamine by the gut bacteria.
