questions.text:
A patient is seated one meter away from the light source and is asked to fixate on a distant object as the retinoscopy is performed. With respect to the movement of the plane mirror in the retinoscope, the red reflex in the eye exhibits the following finding. Putting a -1.0 D lens in front of the eye neutralizes the reflex. What is the likely refractive error of the patient? (No cycloplegics were used).

D - diopters
questions.solution:
The most likely refractive error in the patient is myopia of 2.0 D.

Here the red reflex is against the movement. To neutralize it, a concave lens with negative power will be required. So the patient has myopia. Now here -1.0 D lens is used, along with the distance correction of 1 meter. Thus subtracting 1 from -1 gives us the final value of 2.0 D.

When a plane mirror retinoscope is used at a distance of 1 meter, based upon the movement of the red reflex, the results can be interpreted as:

  • No movement of red reflex: myopia of 1D
  • Movement of red reflex with the plane mirror retinoscope: Emmetropia, hypermetropia, or myopia < 1D
  • Movement of red reflex against the plane mirror retinoscope: Myopia >1D
  • Oblique movement is seen in astigmatism.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs can be used to treat nightmares in patients with PTSD already on SSRIs?

PTSD - Post-traumatic stress disorder
questions.solution:
Prazosin is indicated for the treatment of nightmares in patients suffering from PTSD.

Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist. It acts by blocking the alpha-1 receptors in the arterioles and veins, thereby decreasing peripheral vascular resistance and venous return to the heart. It has been shown to effectively reduce nightmares and improve sleep quality in patients with PTSD. By blocking the noradrenergic activation associated with the stress response, prazosin helps diminish the intensity and frequency of nightmares, thereby promoting better sleep. While SSRIs are the first line for the treatment of PTSD, prazosin is specifically approved for the treatment of intractable nightmares in PTSD.

It is also used in the treatment of Raynaud's disease, hypertension, congestive heart failure, and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Adverse effects include the first-dose phenomenon, which is characterized by marked orthostatic hypotension or syncope within 30-90 minutes of the initial dose of prazosin or when the dosage is increased. After a few initial doses, tolerance develops to this side effect. Initiating low doses at bedtime is recommended to minimize this phenomenon. Orthostatic hypotension can be a problem with long-term therapy. Other side effects are headache, dizziness, and asthenia.

Other options: 

Option B: Clonazepam is a benzodiazepine medication with sedative properties. While it may help reduce anxiety and promote sleep, it is not recommended for the treatment of PTSD-related nightmares. 

Options A and C: Venlafaxine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) and propranolol is a nonselective beta blocker. They are commonly used in the treatment of depression and social anxiety disorders, including PTSD. While they may alleviate some symptoms of PTSD, such as depression and anxiety, they are not specifically indicated for the treatment of nightmares.

questions.text: A mother presents with foul-smelling reddish vaginal discharge on her second-day postpartum. Her vitals are stable. What is the next best step in managing this case?

choices.text: Start her on high dose antibiotics
Examine for retained bits of conceptus

questions.solution:
The presence of foul-smelling reddish vaginal discharge in a second-day postpartum mother with stable vitals is suggestive of lochia rubra. This is a normal finding in the early puerperal period which does not require any intervention.

Lochia refers to the vaginal discharge resulting from the sloughing of decidual tissue in the early puerperal period. The discharge has a peculiar offensive fishy smell and originates from the uterine body, cervix and vagina. Its reaction is alkaline at first but tends to become acidic towards the end.

Name Colour Timings after delivery Contents
Lochia Rubra Red First few days  Blood, decidua, fetal membranes, Vernix, lanugo, meconium
Lochia Serosa Yellowish/pink After 3 to 4 days WBCs, cervical mucus, micro-organisms
Lochia Alba Pale White After 10th day Decidua, cells, WBC, mucin, cholesterin crystals and fat cells 

The average amount of discharge for the first week is 250 mL and may persist for about 3 weeks. The average duration of lochial discharge ranges from 24 to 36 days.

The persistence of lochia rubra beyond the normal limit may signify subinvolution or retained bits of conceptus. Prolonged discharge of lochia alba for more than 3 weeks may signify local genital lesion.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder is brought with complaints of slowed growth and decreased appetite. The child has been on medication for the past year. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Methylphenidate is a commonly prescribed stimulant medication for ADHD, but it can have adverse effects such as slowed growth and decreased appetite. 

Methylphenidate primarily functions by blocking the reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine, leading to increased levels of these neurotransmitters in the brain. While this mechanism is effective for managing ADHD symptoms, it can also suppress appetite and interfere with normal growth processes, particularly in children who are still developing.

CNS stimulants are the first-choice agents in the treatment of ADHD as they have shown the greatest efficacy with mild tolerable side effects. The CNS stimulants used are dopamine agonists like methylphenidate, amphetamine salts, and dextroamphetamine. Non-stimulant medications used in the treatment of ADHD include atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), clonidine, and guanfacine (alpha agonists). 

Other drugs that can cause appetite suppression and growth retardation are atomoxetine and lisdexamfetamine.

Other options: 

Options A and B: Guanfacine and clonidine are alpha-2 adrenergic agonists used in ADHD treatment, but they are not associated with significant growth suppression or decreased appetite.

Option C: Modafinil, a wakefulness-promoting agent is not used to treat ADHD, and is not typically associated with growth retardation or decreased appetite.

questions.text: Which of the following lifestyle modification to treat hypertension is not recommended?

choices.text: Attain and maintain a BMI of <25 kg/sq m
Diet rich in fruits, vegetables and high-fat dairy products
For those who drink alcohol, 2 or less drinks/day for men and 1 or less drink/day for women

questions.solution:
The correct answer is option B-Diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and high-fat dairy products.

Lifestyle modifications to manage hypertension:

  • Attain and maintain a BMI of <25 kg/sq m
  • Diet rich in fruits, vegetables and low-fat dairy products with reduced content of saturated and total fat. Diet rich in potassium, calcium and magnesium. 
  • Dietary salt <6 grams/day
  • For those who drink alcohol, 2 or less drinks/day for men and 1 or less drink/day for women
  • Physical activity: Regular aerobic activity, eg, brisk waking for 30 min/day.

questions.text: You had ordered to centrifuge a tissue sample and separate the mitochondria out to extract mitochondrial DNA for genetic evaluation. Which of the following is an enzyme marker to identify the mitochondria?
questions.solution:
ATP synthase is the enzyme marker used to identify the mitochondria. It is present in the inner mitochondrial membrane.

The membranes of cell organelles contain various proteins, some of which are enzymes. Certain enzymes are located only in particular membranes. These enzymes may be used as markers following the purification of these membranes. 

The mitochondrial matrix is enclosed by an outer membrane and a selectively permeable inner membrane. The inner membrane contains the respiratory chain enzymes, ATP synthase, and membrane transporters. 

A cytogenetic study involving mitochondrial DNA is generally done when you suspect a genetic disease inherited through the mt-DNA. 

Human mitochondria contain dsDNA that makes up approximately 1% of total cellular DNA. This mitochondrial DNA codes for mt-specific ribosomal and tRNAs as well as for 13 proteins that play roles in the respiratory chain.

Mitochondrial DNA has a high mutation rate, 5-10 times that of nuclear DNA. It is transmitted by maternal non-mendelian inheritance because all mitochondria are contributed by the ovum during the formation of the zygote.

questions.text:
Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Hurthle Cell Carcinoma?

 RAI - Radioactive iodine

choices.text: This tumour has better prognosis than follicular thyroid carcinoma
The tumour cells are derived from the basophilic cells of the thyroid gland
The effective treatment for this tumour is RAI therapy
FNAC is not used for diagnosis

questions.solution:
FNAC is not used to diagnose Hurthle cell carcinoma as it cannot differentiate between an adenoma and carcinoma due to vascular or capsular invasion.

Hurthle cell Carcinoma is a type of differentiated thyroid carcinoma. It was earlier considered as a variant of Follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC). It is derived from the oxyphilic Hurthle cells of the thyroid gland, also known as oncocytes or Askanazy cells having eosinophilic cytoplasm and densely packed mitochondria. (Option B)

The diagnosis can only be made by histopathological evaluation after a surgical resection by thyroid lobectomy or thyroidectomy where more than 75% of the tumor consists of Hurthle cells.

These tumours usually do not take up RAI (Option C) unlike FTC and it has a poorer prognosis than FTC (Option A)

questions.text: The nucleus indicated by the arrow shown in the longitudinal section of the nerve fibers in the image belongs to ______
questions.solution:
The image shows the nucleus of Schwann cells.

Nerve fibers (axons) in the peripheral nervous system may be myelinated or unmyelinated. The myelin sheath surrounding the myelinated nerve fibers is provided by the Schwann cells. The cytoplasm and the nucleus of the Schwann cells are pushed to the periphery. Since each axon is surrounded by myelin sheaths provided by several axons, on H&E staining, several nuclei of these Schwann cells appear as basophilic structures on either side of the axon along its length.

Other options:

  • In the question, it is already mentioned that the given section is of the nerve fiber. However, in case it is not mentioned, on H&E stain the smooth muscle cells appear spindle-shaped, with a centrally placed, elongated nucleus.
  • The fibroblasts may be seen in the perineurium or endoneurium surrounding the bundles of nerve fibers. They are elongated and stain denser than the nuclei of Schwann cells.
  • The dorsal root ganglion consists of cell bodies of the neurons, with satellite cells.

questions.text: What kind of suturing is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a subcuticular suture.

The subcuticular suture technique is performed by taking a bite alternatively on either side of the wound and gently pulling until the end. This is used in the skin where a cosmetic appearance is important and where the skin edges may be approximated easily.

Either an absorbable or non-absorbable suture material can be used.

Frequently used suture techniques are as follows:

Interrupted suture (Option B): Here, the needle is inserted perpendicular to the incision. It then passes through both sides of the suture line and exits again at a right angle. The distance from the needle's entry point to the edge of the wound (x) should be approximately the same as the depth of the tissue (x) being sutured. The next suture should be placed twice the distance away from the first suture (2x). Interrupted sutures are shown below.

 

Continuous suture (Option C): The first suture is placed in the same way as an interrupted suture, but the remaining sutures are inserted in a continuous manner till the far end of the wound. It is shown below.

 

Mattress suture (Option D): Mattress sutures may be either vertical or horizontal. They result in either eversion or inversion of the wound edge. The first suture is inserted like in an interrupted suture. After that, the needle is moved either horizontally or vertically, traversing both edges of the wound. It is shown below.

questions.text: A mother brings her 7-year-old daughter with the complaint that the child wakes up at night screaming, sweating, and terrified. She does not respond to the comforting efforts by her parents. She does not recall the episode in the morning. In which stage of sleep do the episodes experienced by the daughter occur?
questions.solution:
The child who wakes up with intense fear and signs of arousal such as sweating, and does not recall the event in the morning is experiencing sleep terrors or night terrors. Night terrors occur in deep sleep (stages 3 and 4 of NREM sleep).

Sleep terror or night terror is an NREM sleep arousal disorder. In this condition, the patient experiences sudden arousal with intense fearfulness. They may have a piercing scream or cry with manifestations of intense anxiety.

On arousal, they sit up in bed, are unresponsive to stimuli, and are confused and disoriented on awakening. Autonomic disturbances may be present. If vocal, they are incoherent. The patient cannot generally be awakened and efforts to calm them are not successful.  

Sleep terrors only have brief frightening or vivid images, or may not have imagery at all. It can be provoked by sleep deprivation, fever, and central nervous system depressant withdrawal. 

Nightmares have elaborate dream sequences without autonomic disturbances. They occur in REM sleep. The patient can be aroused and typically remembers the dream.

The various stages of sleep and their appearance on EEG are summarized in the image below.

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a healthy baby at 39 weeks of gestation. The mother is positive for HBsAg and negative for HBeAg. What is the next most appropriate step for the infant?

choices.text: Both active and passive immunization right after birth
Passive immunization soon after birth and active immunization at 1 year
Only passive immunization soon after birth
Only active immunization soon after birth

questions.solution:
Infants born to HbsAg-positive mothers should receive both Hepatitis B immunoglobulin and HB vaccine.

These have to be administered intramuscularly at separate sites within 12 hours of birth, followed by 2nd and 3rd dose of vaccine at 1 and 6 months respectively.

Mothers with an HBV DNA viral load >200,000 IU/mL should receive an anti-viral such as telbivudine, lamivudine, or tenofovir during the 3rd trimester, especially if they had a previous child who developed chronic HBV after receiving HBIG and the hepatitis B vaccine.

As per the updated recommendations by WHO, pregnant women testing positive for HBV infection (HBsAg+ve) with HBV DNA ≥ 200,000 IU/mL should receive Tenofovir prophylaxis from the 28th week of pregnancy until birth, to prevent mother-to-child transmission of HBV. This is in addition to three-dose hepatitis B vaccination in all infants.

questions.text: All of the following are indications for surgical excision of fibroadenomas, except:
questions.solution:
Intralobular stromal proliferation on biopsy is a characteristic finding in fibroadenoma but surgery is indicated only when atypia is detected on histology.

In patients with fibroadenoma, the indications for surgical excision include:

  • Age > 30 years
  • Suspicious imaging- microlobulation
  • Atypia on histology
  • Size > 5 cm
  • Family history of breast cancer
  • Patient requesting for surgical removal

Fibroadenoma is one of the aberrations of normal development and involution of the breast (ANDI). The most common age group affected is 15-25 years (early reproductive period). It arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth, firm, non-tender, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). It is a biphasic tumor consisting of fibroblastic stroma and epithelium-lined gland. 

Fibroadenomas can be classified into 2 types:

  • Without complex features - classified as a non-proliferative condition
  • With complex features-
    • Associated with cysts > 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillary apocrine change
    • Classified as proliferative changes without atypia

Fibroadenomas are benign tumours, although neoplasia may develop in the epithelial elements within them. Cancer in a newly discovered fibroadenoma is exceedingly rare; 50% of neoplasias that involve fibroadenomas are LCIS, 35% are invasive carcinomas, and 15% are intraductal carcinomas.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has had complaints of right hip pain for 2 weeks. He has pain in passive movement of the hip and restricted abduction and internal rotation. His hip X-ray is shown below. What is the likely management?
questions.solution:
In this 9-year-old patient complaining of hip pain with abduction and internal rotation, and x-ray findings of flattening of the femoral head epiphysis, the most likely diagnosis is Perthes disease. The treatment of choice in a child who is older than 8 years is pelvic osteotomy.

The radiograph shown in the question shows the remodeling stage of Legg-Calve-Perthe's disease in the right hip joint with signs of bony necrosis and flattening of the femoral head epiphysis. The remodeling stage occurs after the epiphysis has completely reossified and regained normal strength and density. 

Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-8 years. The incidence is more in boys than girls. It is usually a unilateral disease but can occur bilaterally in 10% of the cases. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Perthes disease is associated with thrombophilia, protein C and S deficiencies.

Disruption of blood flow to the femoral head leads to osteonecrosis and cessation of growth. The lateral epiphyseal artery, a branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery is involved. Over time, healing and fibrosis occur by new blood vessels infiltrating the dead bone and removing the necrotic bone which leads to a loss of bone mass and weakening of the femoral head. 

Clinical features include limping and hip pain, which aggravates with activity and is relieved by rest. Examination reveals pain on passive movement of the hip and abduction with internal rotation movement is limited. Children can also present with referred knee pain.

X-ray findings observed depend on the stage of the disease:

  • Initial phase: Medial joint space widening and increased density in the ossific nucleus
  • Fragmentation phase: Alternating patches of sclerosis and fibrosis
  • Re-ossification phase: Complete removal of necrotic bone. Epiphyseal density is regained in this phase
  • Remodeling phase: Remodeling occurs until skeletal maturity is attained

Management of Legg-Calve-Perthe Disease:

  • In children <8 years of age:
    • Non-operative management: This is usually reserved for children younger than 6 years. The child is managed with protected weight-bearing exercises and bisphosphonates.
    • Operative management: Proximal femur varus osteotomy
  • In children >8 years of age:
    • Pelvic osteotomy
    • Valgus subtrochanteric osteotomy is a salvage procedure in very advanced disease with joint deformity

Other Options: 

Option A: A hip spica is the treatment for an impacted fracture of the neck of femur in children. It is not used in Perthe's disease

Option B: Conservative management is done in children less than 8 years old. This patient is >8 years old with advanced disease, as the x-ray indicates it to be in the remodeling phase. Thus operative management is indicated.

Option D: Arthrodesis is a procedure where two bones are fused to form a single one. This is done in advanced cases of Congenital talipes equino varus. It has no role in the management of Perthe's disease.

questions.text: A patient with cirrhosis and ascites presents to you. The gross appearance of his liver is as shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the likely characteristic microscopic appearance?

choices.text: Pericentral hepatocytes will be atrophic/necrotic, and periportal hepatocytes will be viable.
Periportal hepatocytes will be atrophic/necrotic, and pericentral hepatocytes will be viable.
Both periportal and pericentral hepatocytes are equally necrotic/atrophic.
Neither periportal, nor pericentral hepatocytes are affected.

questions.solution:
The gross image of the liver shows a nutmeg appearance, which is seen in heart failure. Microscopic findings would be that pericentral hepatocytes are atrophic/necrotic and periportal hepatocytes are viable.

Nutmeg liver refers to the mottled appearance of the liver, resembling the cut section of nutmeg. This appearance occurs as a result of hepatic venous congestion following right heart failure. The dark centrilobular zones reflect sinusoidal congestion. Congestion is seen around the central veins, usually from right-sided heart failure. The pale periportal zones reflect normal or fatty liver tissue.

The liver derives its blood supply from the portal venous system and the hepatic artery. The portal triad constitutes the following:

  • Branches of the hepatic artery
  • Portal vein 
  • Bile duct

The blood from the portal vein and the hepatic artery flow through the intervening sinusoids and drains into the central vein. The central veins from adjacent lobules form interlobular veins, which then unite as hepatic veins and finally drain into the inferior vena cava. 

The hepatic lobule is divided into three zones:

  • Zone 1 is the periportal area 
  • Zone 2 is the intermediate zone
  • Zone 3 is the area closest to the central vein

Right-sided cardiac failure leads to passive congestion of the liver. Left-sided cardiac failure leads to hypoperfusion and hypoxia of hepatocytes around central veins. The combination of hypoperfusion and retrograde congestion causes centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis, leading to this mottled appearance of the liver, which is known as nutmeg liver.

questions.text: Which of the following alterations in chromosome 15 is not seen in Prader-Willi syndrome?
questions.solution:
Maternal deletion is not seen in Prader-Willi syndrome. It is seen in Angelman syndrome.

Prader-Willi syndrome is a type of non-Mendelian mode of inheritance and genomic imprinting disorder. It occurs due to the deletion of band 15q12 on the paternal chromosome and the silencing of the same set of genes derived from maternal chromosomes. It is characterized by mental retardation, obesity, hyperphagia, hypogonadism, short stature, small hands and feet, and abnormal facial features like a small upturned nose, narrow bifrontal distance and thin upper lip.

Angelman syndrome is characterized by the deletion of the ubiquitin ligase gene (UBE3A) on maternal chromosome 15q12 and the silencing of the paternal chromosomal counterpart. It is characterized by intellectual disability, microcephaly, ataxic gait, seizures, inappropriate laughter and so is also known as the 'happy puppet syndrome'.

Prader Willi syndrome Angelman syndrome
Chromosome 15 Chromosome 15
Maternal imprinting Paternal imprinting
Paternal deletion Maternal deletion
Maternal disomy Paternal disomy
SNORP gene UBE3A gene
Hyperphagia, obesity, mental retardation Happy puppet syndrome

questions.text: What is the infective form of the organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows male and female worms of Ascaris lumbricoides (roundworm). The infective form of Ascaris is the embryonated egg. 

Ascaris lumbricoides is a type of intestinal nematode responsible for causing ascariasis. Infection typically arises from consuming food or water contaminated with embryonated eggs. These eggs harbor the rhabditiform larva. Humans serve as the sole natural host for this parasite.

Patients can be asymptomatic or present with gastrointestinal symptoms of anorexia, abdominal discomfort, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Patients can also have a hypersensitivity reaction to the worm and present with fever, urticaria, and wheezing. 

Adult worms can be occasionally detected in the stool or sputum of the patient. Ascaris are large and cylindrical worms with tapering ends. They are pale pink or flesh colored when passed in stools. The female worms are larger than the male worms. A definitive diagnosis is made by demonstration of eggs in feces.

Treatment options include pyrantel pamoate, albendazole, mebendazole, or ivermectin.

questions.text: A neonate presents with facial dysmorphism as well as the characteristic findings shown in the image below. What is the chromosomal abnormality affecting this newborn?
questions.solution:
The newborn with features of facial dysmorphism, index finger overlapping other fingers, and rocker bottom feet are suggestive of Edward’s syndrome. Edward's syndrome is caused due to trisomy 18.

Clinical features of Edward’s syndrome: (Remember the mnemonic: Hi Mr EDWARDS)

  • Hypertonia
  • Microcephaly
  • Eighteen trisomy/ Elongated skull
  • Digit overlapping with a closed fist
  • Webbing of 2nd and 3rd toes
  • Absent intellect (severe developmental delay)/ Absent radii/ Arthrogryposis
  • Rocker bottom feet
  • Cardiac Disorders (ventricular septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, atrial septal defect) and kidney, death.
  • Small lower jaw (micrognathia), short sternum, small nipples

Other options: 

Option B: Trisomy 13 causes Patau syndrome. It is characterized by forebrain and midline facial abnormalities including cleft lip, cleft palate, nasal defects, and a single central eye (“cyclops”). Other defects include polydactyly, renal defects, and congenital heart diseases.

The image below shows the facial abnormalities seen in Patau syndrome:


Option C: Trisomy 21 causes Down syndrome. It is the most common chromosomal abnormality. Children with Down syndrome have severe mental retardation. They have characteristic facial features, including a flat profile, oblique palpebral fissures, and prominent epicanthic folds. There is a horizontal palmar crease and decreased muscle tone at birth that leads to a “floppy baby."


Option D: FGFR2 mutations are associated with craniosynostosis. FGFR2 mutation on chromosome 10q can cause Apert syndrome. It is the most severe form of craniosynostosis, involving premature closure of multiple cranial sutures, along with syndactyly/ mitten hand deformity.

questions.text: What can be the likely cause of ascites if the serum ascites-to-albumin gradient (SAAG ) is 1.5g/dl and the ascitic protein level is 3g/dl?
questions.solution:
The cause of ascites when the serum ascites-to-albumin gradient (SAAG) is 1.5g/dl and the ascitic protein level is 3g/dl is Congestive heart failure.

Serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG):

  • Calculated by subtracting the ascitic albumin concentration from the serum albumin level.
  • Reflects the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids
  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

Ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the etiology, in cases with high-SAAG (≥1.1):

  • ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing passage of protein into the ascites. eg. cardiac ascites
  • <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein. Eg. cirrhosis

The serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is the most reli­able method to differentiate causes of ascites due to portal hyper­tension from those not due to portal hypertension.

questions.text: A middle-aged chronic smoker has recently been discharged from the hospital after being admitted for an acute exacerbation of chronic bronchitis. He is now motivated to quit smoking and wants to know about medications that will help him with quitting. All of the following can be used in him, except ______.
questions.solution:
Mirtazapine is not used in smoking cessation.

Mirtazapine is a serotonin receptor antagonist, used in the treatment of major depression.

Pharmacological methods to quit smoking:

1. Nicotine replacement therapy - is highly effective, because it reduces withdrawal symptoms. It is available as - 

  • Nicotine gum - available over the counter and releases nicotine via buccal absorption. One to two pieces of gum per hour up to a maximum of 24 pieces per day can be used
  • Nicotine lozenges - useful for patients who smoke a cigarette immediately on awakening
  • Nicotine patches - administered every morning and produce blood concentrations of nicotine about half those of smoking
  • Nicotine nasal spray - available only by prescription, produces nicotine concentrations in the blood comparable to smoking a cigarette and is helpful for heavily dependent smokers However, adverse effects like rhinitis, watering eyes, and coughing are experienced by most patients
  • Nicotine inhalers deliver 4 mg per cartridge and resultant nicotine levels are low

2. Non-nicotine medications:

1st line:

  • Bupropion - both dopaminergic and adrenergic actions. 
  • Varenicline - a partial agonist for nicotinic Ach receptor. Side effects include sleep disturbances, depression, and increased suicidal tendencies.

2nd line:

  • Nortriptyline - tricyclic antidepressant which appears to be effective for smoking cessation.
  • Clonidine - alpha-agonist which decreases sympathetic activity and thus decreases withdrawal symptoms.

It is recommended to offer nicotine patches or varenicline along with counselling and behavior therapy as a part of the cessation attempt. Acute exacerbations of chronic bronchitis are valuable "teachable moments" for the patient and can help reaffirm the smoking cessation message serving as a springboard for a cessation attempt.

questions.text: A 29 yr old G2P1, comes to the physician at 36 weeks of gestation. At 28 weeks, she was diagnosed with gestational diabetes. Since then, she has been able to control her blood sugar levels with an improved meal plan. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?

choices.text: Start oral hypoglycemics at 6 weeks postpartum
Perform a glucose tolerance test at 6 weeks postpartum

questions.solution:
A patient of gestational diabetes mellitus is at an increased risk for developing overt diabetes and should undergo a glucose tolerance test at 6 weeks postpartum to determine whether they have developed overt diabetes.

50% of women with gestational diabetes develop overt diabetes within 20 years. Hence, they are recommended to undergo screening & revaluation from time to time. To start oral hypoglycemics would be incorrect as not all women will progress to overt diabetes.

Overt diabetes is a term used for pre-existing diabetes mellitus in pregnancy or diabetes mellitus detected for the first time during the first trimester of pregnancy. According to the American Diabetic Association diagnosis of overt diabetes is made if:

  • The fasting plasma glucose exceeds 126 mg/dl
  • The 2 hours post glucose (75 gm) value exceeds 200 mg/dl
  • HbA1C ≥ 6.5%

OGTT (Oral glucose tolerance test) is done twice during antenatal care. Once in the first trimester and then between 24-28 weeks POG. It is done in the first trimester to detect overt diabetes, and in the second trimester to detect gestational diabetes. Glucose tolerance test at 6 weeks postpartum to determine whether they have developed overt diabetes.

DIPSI ( Diabetes In Pregnancy Study Group India) criteria is followed in India. DIPSI is a single-step test that does not require prior fasting and is done irrespective of the meal intake. 75g of glucose is given to the patient orally and the blood glucose level is checked after 2 hours. The diagnostic criteria are given below:

Blood glucose level (mg/dL) Diagnosis
< 140 Normal
>= 140 Gestational Diabetes
>=200 Overt Diabetes

Once diagnosed with gestational diabetes, the patient is advised diabetic diet for 2 weeks. At the end of 2 weeks of modified diet intake, blood glucose levels are checked. If the 2-hr postprandial blood glucose level is-

  •  <120mg/dL - continue diabetic diet
  • >=120mg/dL - start on insulin therapy

Regular insulin after meals and NPH at bedtime is the most common combination prescribed.

questions.text: What is the most common genetic alteration of this thyroid tumor?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of empty nuclei, also called Orphan Annie eye nuclei which is characteristic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. The most common is the BRAF V600E mutation.

BRAF V600E mutation is also seen in

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Hairy cell leukemia
  • Colon adenocarcinoma
  • Melanoma

Other chromosomal rearrangements in papillary thyroid carcinoma:

  • RET-PTC fusion (option A) - seen in sporadic papillary cancers; uncommon
  • NTRK1 mutation

Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma include:

  • Branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk
  • Covering epithelium is simple or stratified cuboidal
  • Orphan Annie eye nuclei -

  • Psammoma bodies - concentric calcified structures
  • Foci of lymphatic invasion

Option D: RAS mutation is seen in follicular thyroid cancer.

questions.text: In healthy and acclimatized young men who are exposed to high environmental temperatures, what is the maximum allowable sweat rate that is compatible with their normal physiology?
questions.solution:
A sweat excretion rate of 4.5 L/4 hours in acclimatized, healthy young men is indicative of intolerable air temperature. This is known as McArdle’s maximum allowable sweat rate.

This is the maximum allowable sweat rate that is compatible with the normal physiological reaction of acclimatized, healthy young men who are exposed to heat. The predicted four-hour sweat rate (P4SR) is obtained from readings of air and mean radiant temperature and air velocity under different work intensities. Based on this value, the zone of comfort can be determined.

Zone of comfort    Predicted P4SR
Comfort zone 1–3 liters
Just tolerable 3–4.5 liters
Intolerable 4.5+ liters

questions.text: You are a 3rd-year medical student posted in surgery clinics. A patient presents with fever and sharply demarcated skin lesions on the face as shown below. What is the most common causative organism of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever and the clinical image showing edema and sharply demarcated erythema over the face and nose are suggestive of erysipelas. Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A beta-hemolytic Streptococcus) is the most common cause of erysipelas.

The given clinical picture shows a sharply demarcated involvement of superficial skin lymphatics. It is usually associated with a breach of skin continuity. The skin may be tender, erythematous, and swollen.

Ear involvement is called Milian's ear sign. This sign helps to differentiate cellulitis from erysipelas. Cellulitis is an infection of the deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissues. The pinna does not have a deeper dermis or subcutaneous tissue. Hence, ear involvement points to a diagnosis of erysipelas.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas-

  • Infection of the superficial epidermis.
    • It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin.
      • The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

The given image shows necrotizing myositis:

questions.text: The instruments shown in the image below are used in the management of:
questions.solution:
The image shows trans obturator tape with a Stamey's needle. It is used for the treatment of stress urinary incontinence (SUI).

Stamey’s needle is used to do a colposuspension and the transobturator tape is used to maintain a transobturator sling. Both these procedures are done to manage patients with stress incontinence.

Tension-free trans obturator tape (TOT) is better as compared to Tension-free transvaginal tape (TVT) as there is no need to enter the space of Retzius (retropubic space). So it is associated with fewer complications.

The best surgery for SUI is TOT > TVT > Burch colposuspension.

Other options:

Option B: The treatment options for uterovaginal prolapse may include pessary, pelvic floor exercises, or surgery depending on the severity of the prolapse.

Option C: Vesicovaginal fistulas are repaired per vaginally. The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF are the Latzko procedure, Chassar-Moir technique, and ureteric implantation into the sigmoid colon. 

Option D: Ureterovaginal fistulas occur from iatrogenic causes due to damage of the ureter during pelvic surgeries like hysterectomy. It is managed surgically.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male came with findings shown in the image below. He previously came with complaints of tortuous swellings in both legs.  Which additional characteristic finding is included under the same CEAP clinical classification as this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image in a patient with a known case of varicose veins is atrophie blanche. It is classified as C4b under CEAP guidelines where inverted champagne bottle legs are also a characteristic finding due to lipodermatosclerosis. 

Lipodermatosclerosis is changes in the skin of the lower legs due to chronic venous insufficiency. It is a form of panniculitis (inflammation of the layer of fat under the skin). There is swelling and a tapering of the legs above the ankles, leading to inverted champagne bottle appearance which is shown in the image below

 

Atrophie blanche is a localized white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and pigmentation, usually seen around the ankle. This is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology (CEAP) classification system is used to classify chronic lower extremity venous disease.

The clinical class of C4 under CEAP includes changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease. It is further classified as follows:

  • C4a-Pigmentation or eczema
  • C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
  • C4c-Corona phlebectatica

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, he has papilledema and signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP). Which of the following conditions would warrant the use of glucocorticoids to reduce ICP?
questions.solution:
Among the following conditions, the use of glucocorticoids is warranted to reduce elevated ICP in patients with brain abscesses.

Glucocorticoids may be used to reduce intracranial pressure in conditions associated with cerebral edema, such as brain abscess. In brain abscess, inflammation, and edema surrounding the abscess can lead to increased intracranial pressure, resulting in neurological symptoms. Glucocorticoids help reduce edema by decreasing inflammation and may be adjunctive therapy alongside antimicrobial agents.

Initial approach in the management of raised intracranial pressure (ICP) includes airway protection, head elevation up 20-30° (reverse Trendelenburg positioning), mannitol bolus up to 1 g/kg for free water diuresis (the effect is delayed by 20 min), hypertonic saline (3% or 5%), maintaining fluid and electrolyte balance, short-term hyperventilation, seizure control, and sedation using a combination of opiates and barbiturates. Ventriculostomy and/or craniectomy may be needed for definitive decompression.

ICP normally varies between 4 and 14 mmHg. Sustained ICP levels above 25 mmHg can injure the brain. The goal of therapy in raised ICP is to maintain the ICP < 20 mmHg and cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) ≥ 60 mmHg.

Other options: 

Options B and D: There is no role of glucocorticoid administration in the management of ischemic stroke and hemorrhagic stroke with intracerebral hematoma because they haven't been shown to improve outcomes, and increase the risk of hyperglycemia and infections. Osmotic therapy with intravenous mannitol or hypertonic saline can be used if there are signs of raised ICP.

Option C: Steroids are not used to reduce ICP due to head trauma since they are associated with increased mortality.

questions.text: A young rice farmer presented with a high-grade fever, diarrhea, seizures, and vomiting. He is also found to have nuchal rigidity and signs of raised intracranial pressure. The physician suspects an illness transmitted by the mosquito shown below.  Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Pond herons can act as hosts

questions.solution:
The rice farmer presenting with features of acute encephalitis is likely to have Japanese encephalitis. Man is the incidental dead-end host.

The image shows the Culex mosquito. It can be identified by the presence of unspotted wings, hunched back, and the absence of stripes.  The Culex mosquitoes are vectors or carriers for Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, and viral arthritis. 

Japanese encephalitis (JE) is the most prevalent cause of viral encephalitis in Asia. It is a mosquito-borne zoonotic disease caused by Flavivirus. It is transmitted mainly by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically C. tritaeniorhynchus and C. vishnui (common in India) species.

JE is a zoonotic disease primarily affecting animals like pigs and ardeid birds (pond herons, cattle egret). Pigs are considered the major vertebrate hosts and amplifiers for the JE virus. Humans are the dead-end hosts for this virus. When a mosquito bites an infected pig, the virus is transmitted to the mosquito. The virus, in turn, is transferred to other pigs or humans due to mosquito bites and this cycle continues. Horses are the only known domestic animals that present with signs of JE infection.

The control measures include mosquito control by areal or ground fogging with ultra-low-volume insecticides such as malathion and fenitrothion, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings, and vaccinating pigs.

JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunisation Schedule.

questions.text: During a study, you are collecting, reviewing, and presenting information to answer a research question while making sure they meet specific inclusion and exclusion criteria. What is this process?
questions.solution:
The process of collecting, reviewing, and presenting information to answer a research question while making sure they meet specific inclusion and exclusion criteria is called a systematic review.

 Steps of a systematic review:

  • Formulate the review question
  • Define inclusion and exclusion criteria to choose studies
  • Select studies and extract data
  • Analyze and interpret data

Other options:

Option A: Cohort study is a prospective study that involves the follow-up of a cohort (a group of people) with risk factors to check if they develop an outcome or disease.

Option B: Meta-analysis is a quantitative method to study the previous research studies of a selected topic/ research question. It uses statistical methods to summarise results and its validity relies upon the quality of the studies used and reviewed.

Option C: A randomized control trial is an experimental study in which an intervention (maybe addition or omission of drug or actions) is given to a group of people participating in the study and compared to another group of individuals with similar characteristics who are not given that intervention to be studied.

Related Pearl: Meta-analysis in Research

  • Meta-analysis is a set of statistical techniques for combining quantitative results from multiple studies to produce a summary of empirical knowledge on a given topic.
  • It refers to a method of systematic review.
  • It is one of the most relevant methods in evidence-based medicine and ranks high on the evidence pyramid.
  • Limitations
    • When testing is done before hypothesis generation, spurious results are found.
    • Sample size may be misrepresentative.
    • Publication bias due to suppression of some important information leading to file drawer effect.
    • Heterogeneity of studies may force mashing together of disparate effects and lead to selection bias. This is also called apples and oranges effect.
    • Dissimilarities in control groups.
    • Its validity is dependent on the quality of the systematic review and the original data used.

Related Pearl: Evidence Pyramid in Research

The evidence pyramid gives the hierarchy or ranking of evidence from different types of methods used in research.

Animal research ranks the lowest, while meta-analysis ranks the highest and gives the best evidence.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 lady at 33 weeks with one previous vaginal delivery came to the labour room with complaints of pain in the abdomen. On examination, she was 25% effaced with 1 cm dilation and intact membranes. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a G2P1L1 lady at 33 weeks, who presented with pain abdomen and cervical examination revealing 25% effacement and 1 cm dilation with intact membranes, indicates that she is in the early stages of labor and glucocorticoids are administered to accelerate fetal lung maturity.

Premature birth can cause lung maturation issues in the fetus, so corticosteroid therapy is recommended. This treatment can help increase the likelihood of a successful vaginal delivery and reduce the risk of respiratory distress syndrome in newborns.

Intramuscular injection of either betamethasone or dexamethasone is given.

Dosage: 

  • Betamethasone (Betnesol): 2 doses of 12 mg each, given 24 hours apart.
  • Dexamethasone: 4 doses of 6 mg each, given every 12 hours.

Corticosteroid is administered when the pregnancy is less than 34 weeks. The steroid therapy is beneficial only when the delivery is delayed more than 48 hours after the first dose. This helps in fetal lung maturation and minimizes the incidence of Respiratory distress syndrome, intraventricular haemorrhage and necrotizing enterocolitis

The delay of delivery can be achieved with the use of tocolytics. Ultrasound is done to check for additional causes leading to preterm labor.

Other options:

Option A: Magnesium sulfate can be used for fetal neuroprotection before 31 weeks of gestation. However, use as a tocolytic has been associated with thinning of bones in fetuses and should be avoided after 32 weeks. 

Option B: There is no absolute indication to perform emergency LSCS in case of early stage of labor as the membranes are also intact.

Option D: Rescue or emergency cerclage is done when there is bulging or prolapse of membranes through a dilated cervix. Prophylactic cerclage is done for women with previous preterm birth and short cervix.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 was found to have a BP recording of 150/90 mm Hg at 28 weeks of gestation and she is started on antihypertensive therapy. At 32 weeks, her BP is 160/110 mm Hg and she now complains of persistent headaches not responding to treatment. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Administer single dose steroids and deliver immediately
Administer magnesium sulphate and wait till 34 weeks to deliver
Administer steroids and deliver after 48 hours
Administer steroids and wait till 34 weeks to deliver

questions.solution:
In a patient with severe pre-eclampsia, ie, systolic BP ≥ 160 mm Hg or diastolic ≥ 110 mm Hg, immediate delivery after single-dose steroids is indicated regardless of the period of gestation.

Pre-eclampsia is associated with a systolic BP ≥ 140 mm Hg or diastolic ≥ 90 mm Hg after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive woman, along with the presence of proteinuria. It is a pregnancy-specific syndrome with a multi-organ involvement and significant maternal as well as fetal risks. Termination of pregnancy (delivery) is considered the definitive treatment of pre-eclampsia.

Patients with pre-eclampsia may be expectantly managed up to 34 weeks of gestation. After 34 weeks pregnancy, may be prolonged up to 37 weeks if there is adequate BP control, and delivery is recommended at 37 weeks of gestation. However, in the following events, pregnancy is terminated regardless of the period of gestation:

  1. Uncontrolled severe hypertension
  2. Eclampsia
  3. Pulmonary edema
  4. HELLP Syndrome
  5. Renal dysfunction
  6. Coagulopathy (DIC)
  7. Abruption
  8. Fetal compromise

Other Options:

Option B: Prophylactic magnesium sulphate is recommended in all of the above mentioned complications, but delivery is not delayed 

Options C and D: If the gestational age is <34 weeks, a single dose of steroids is administered and delivery is not delayed. Delivery is rarely delayed by 48 hours for corticosteroid therapy, in events such as oligohydramnios, fetal growth restriction or reversed end-diastolic flow on doppler, but pregnancy is not allowed to continue to even 34 weeks.

questions.text: A 25-year-old young female came to the Dermatology OPD with non-acantholytic blisters. She was advised to get a histopathological examination of the lesion done which revealed the pathology shown in the image. The most likely diagnosis is ________
questions.solution:
Bullous Pemphigoid is characterized by subepidermal (as shown in the image) non-acantholytic blisters.

As the antibodies in bullous pemphigoid are directed against BPAg2 and BPAg1 present in the basement membrane zone, intercellular junctions are intact and acantholysis is not seen. Hence the blisters that form are non-acantholytic.

Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, leading to the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes. This results in the formation of intraepidermal clefts, vesicles, and bullae.

Acantholysis may be classified as:

Primary acantholysis: Due to direct injury to or defects seen in desmosomes, separation of keratinocytes occurs, resulting in circular acantholytic cells. Acantholysis is the primary event causing intraepidermal cavities. It is seen in conditions such as:

  • Pemphigus and its variants (Options C and D)
  • Acantholytic dermatosis
  • Darier's disease
  • Hailey Hailey disease
  • Warty dyskeratoma

Secondary acantholysis: Due to the damage or alteration to the keratinocytes, leading to the dissolution of desmosomes. This results in acantholysis that is seen in:

  • Viral disorders like herpes simplex infections (HSV 1 and 2), varicella zoster infections (chicken pox and shingles) (Option A)
  • Bullous impetigo
  • Solar keratoses
  • Squamous cell carcinoma - some forms like adenoid
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome 

Other options:

Option A: Varicella has intraepidermal blisters.

Option C: Pemphigus Vulgaris is characterized by intraepidermal acantholytic blisters.

Option D: Pemphigus foliaceus is characterized by subcorneal acantholytic blisters.

questions.text: Bronchoscopic examination of a 55-year-old non-smoker woman confirmed the presence of lung carcinoma. On biopsy, a lepidic pattern was observed. Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a non-smoker woman presenting with cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, and lung biopsy showing a lepidic pattern (butterfly on the fence) is suggestive of adenocarcinoma of the lung. The paraneoplastic syndromes associated with this include hypertrophic osteoarthropathy and migratory venous thrombophlebitis.

Migratory venous thrombophlebitis is a paraneoplastic syndrome also known as Trousseau’s syndrome or Trousseau's sign of malignancy. It is characterized by recurrent episodes of localized thrombosis of the superficial veins of limbs. It can lead to tender and erythematous rashes.

Migratory thrombophlebitis is seen in pancreatic cancer (most common), lung cancer, gastrointestinal cancer, ovarian cancer, prostate cancer, and in lymphomas. 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer seen in women and nonsmokers. Adenocarcinomas are usually located in the periphery compared to other lung tumors and are relatively smaller. Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia is a precursor lesion of adenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemical markers in adenocarcinoma lung are thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) and napsin A.

Microscopic examination shows a lepidic pattern of growth at the periphery of the tumor. The tumor cells appear to crawl along the normal-appearing alveolar septa, as shown in the image below.

Note: Trousseau’s sign is seen in hypocalcemia where there is an involuntary contraction of the muscles of the hand and wrist when a blood pressure cuff is placed on the arm and inflated to 20mm of Hg above systolic blood pressure.

Other options:

Option A: Lambert Eaton Syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome of small cell carcinoma. 

Option C: Hypercalcemia is a paraneoplastic syndrome of squamous cell carcinoma.

Option D: Cushing syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome of small cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A patient has been on warfarin therapy for the past 6 months after suffering from deep vein thrombosis. Administration of which of the following drugs would increase the risk of hemorrhage in this patient?
questions.solution:
The administration of ketoconazole would increase the risk of hemorrhage in a patient who is on warfarin. 

Warfarin is metabolized by a CYP2C9 cytochrome complex and ketoconazole is an enzyme inhibitor. Co-administration of these two drugs will result in decreased metabolism of warfarin leading to increased plasma concentration. This results in warfarin overdose and subsequent haemorrhagic symptoms. 

Other drugs that can enhance the risk of hemorrhage on co-administration with warfarin include amiodarone, cimetidine, metronidazole, clopidogrel, isoniazid, cotrimoxazole, etc.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of intense itching and redness in his groin. Lactophenol cotton blue mount of the skin scraping from the affected area is given below. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with intense itching and redness in the groin, and lactophenol cotton blue mount of the skin scraping showing club-shaped macroconidia in clusters with no microconidia is suggestive of tinea cruris caused by Epidermophyton floccusum.

Tinea cruris is a superficial fungal skin infection that affects the groin area. It is primarily caused by dermatophytes, such as Epidermophyton floccusum and Trichophyton rubrum. Typical symptoms include redness and inflammation in the groin region, accompanied by sensations of itching, burning, or stinging. The characteristic lesions exhibit raised borders surrounding a central clearing, thus imparting a ring-like appearance.

The culture of skin scrapings helps in the identification of the causative organism. Identification involves macroscopic and microscopic examination of the fungal colonies. Epidermophyton floccusum forms powdery and greenish-yellow colonies. Microscopic examination reveals absent microconidia and multicellular, pear-shaped macroconidia arranged in clusters.

questions.text:
A G2P1 Rh-negative woman presents at 32 weeks of gestational age. On examination, ICT is positive with a titer of 1:16. What is the next step in management?

ICT – Indirect Coombs test 

MCA – Middle cerebral artery
questions.solution:
In this Rh-negative patient with a positive indirect Coombs test titer of 1:16 further evaluation with MCA Doppler for fetal anemia is the next step of management.

The next step of management in an Rh-negative mother with suspected sensitization depends on the critical titer values. If the critical titer value is ≥ 1:16 It requires MCA Doppler. If it is <1:16 it requires repeating ICT every 2 weeks.  

MCA Doppler is used best to find fetal anemia. In MCA Doppler if peak systolic velocity (PSV) is ≥ 1.5 MoM (multiples of the median) it indicates significant anemia. 

The protocol for RH isoimmunisation is as follows:

The first step is to determine the blood group of the husband. If the husband's blood group is Rh-negative, routine antenatal care is given. If the husband's blood group is Rh-positive, an indirect Coomb's test is performed. 

If ICT is negative in a primigravida with no history of blood transfusion repeat ICT at 36 weeks. In a multigravida or previous history of affection repeat ICT at monthly intervals till 24 weeks and every 2 weeks thereafter.

The critical value of peak systolic velocity of the middle cerebral artery is 1.5 MoM (multiples of the median).

PSV of the Middle cerebral artery Management
< 1.5 MoM Deliver at 37 or 38 weeks of gestation
> 1.5 MoM

>34 weeks of gestation: Deliver

<34 weeks of gestation: Cordocentesis

Cordocentesis

  • Haematocrit (HCT) <30%: Intrauterine transfusion (Option C) is performed and labor is induced approximately three weeks after the last transfusion, typically at 37 or 38 weeks of gestation 
  • Haematocrit (HCT) >30%: Repeat weekly cordocentesis based on middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity. Deliver at 37 or 38 weeks of gestation.

Note: When ICT is positive there is no role of Anti-D.

Other options:

Option B: Cordocentesis is done when MCA PSV ≥1.5 at less than 34 weeks. Looking for the exact amount of fetal hemoglobin helps in assessing the need for intrauterine blood transfusion.

Option D: Termination of pregnancy is done when MCA PSV ≥1.5 at more than 34 weeks.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented to the casualty with severe upper abdominal pain and vomiting. A nasogastric tube insertion was tried but it was unsuccessful. Chest X-ray showed the following findings. Which of the following episodes of vomiting corresponds to this illness?

choices.text: Forceful vomiting against a closed glottis

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 30-year-old patient presenting with severe upper abdominal pain and vomiting with the inability to pass a nasogastric tube and a chest X-ray showing a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen is suggestive of gastric volvulus. It is associated with severe recurrent retching with the production of minimal vomitus.

Gastric volvulus is the rotation of the gastric fundus occurring on the longitudinal (organoaxial) or vertical (mesenteroaxial) axis of the stomach. This occurs due to the laxity in the peritoneal attachment of the stomach.

Patients present with the characteristic Borchardt's triad which comprises of:

  • Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with minimal vomitus
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube

Organoaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the longitudinal axis of the stomach It is the most common type and often occurs acutely. It is associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Mesenteroaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the vertical axis. It is partial (<180 degrees) and recurrent. It is not associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Chest X-ray shows a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen due to rotation of gastric fundus on the axis of the stomach. Gastric volvulus can be confirmed by a barium study. In barium study, the stomach may be inverted with greater curvature above the lesser curvature, or as the pylorus above the cardia. 

Emergency surgery is indicated for acute volvulus which includes decompression, reduction, and prevention of recurrence. The surgical intervention includes simple gastropexy with diaphragmatic hernia repair. 

Other options:

Option B: Forceful vomiting against a closed glottis is most commonly associated with Boerhaave's syndrome. It results in full-thickness perforation of the lower oesophagus.

Option C: Vomiting of undigested food particles is commonly seen in achalasia cardia which occurs as a result of impaired relaxation of the LES due to loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Patients usually present with the classic triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss.

Option D: Projectile non-bilious vomitus is seen in congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. He gives a history of consuming stale food the previous day. Organism isolated on stool culture showed tumbling motility at 25°C and was non-motile at 37°C. Which among the following is the selective media for the above causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an adult with symptoms of gastroenteritis, history of consumption of stale food, organism showing tumbling motility at 25°C is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Listeria monocytogenes. The selective media for Listeria monocytogenes is PALCAM agar.

The PALCAM agar is used to isolate Listeria monocytogenes. They show a grey-green with a black sunken center and a black halo on a cherry-red background. Stool culture is done in cold enrichment media. 

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus. It shows characteristic tumbling motility at 25°C and becomes non-motile at 37°C. The image below shows the tumbling motility of Listeria.

 

Listeria can overcome the food preservation process since it grows at 4°C, low pH, and high salt concentration. 

Listeriosis can present as gastroenteritis in healthy adults. It usually develops within 48 hours of ingestion of a large inoculum in contaminated food like raw sprouts, unpasturized milk or soft cheeses. It can also lead to the formation of abscess, pharyngitis, pneumonia, and endocarditis. It leads to neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and meningoencephalitis in the elderly and immunocompromised people. Listeriosis in pregnancy can lead to abortion and stillbirth.

The virulence factor produced by Listeria is called listeriolysin O. This helps the bacteria to escape and causes septicemia. They are catalase-positive, will not produce H2S, and shows beta hemolysis. This helps to differentiate Listeria from other gran positive bacilli.

It is treated with ampicillin and gentamicin.

Option C- PPLO broth is used to culture Mycoplasma pneumonia

Option D- Cary Blair medium is used as a transport medium of Vibrio cholera, and Campylobacter.

questions.text: The hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's disease is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
The hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's disease is due to increased serum levels of POMC (pro-opiomelanocortin).

Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), aldosterone (mineralocorticoid), and sex hormones. The most common cause of Addison's disease is autoimmune adrenalitis. 

Inadequate adrenal hormone secretion will result in positive feedback to the pituitary, leading to increased ACTH (adrenocorticotropic releasing hormone) secretion. ACTH happens to be derived from a precursor compound known as POMC (pro-opiomelanocortin). POMC breaks down to form ACTH and MSH (melanocyte-stimulating hormone). This MSH is responsible for the hyperpigmentation of sun-exposed areas seen in Addison's disease.

The clinical features of Addison’s disease include:

Fever (increased IL-1)
Depression
Postural hypotension
Hypoglycemia
Hyponatremia (loss of feedback inhibition of ADH)
Slightly increased TSH (loss of feedback inhibition)
Hypoandrogenism Loss of libido

The image below shows a woman before (right) and after (left) developing Addison's disease. You can see how she has lost weight, become anorexic, and developed hyperpigmentation of the sun-exposed skin-

 

The diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency can be made with the short cosyntropin test. Elevated ACTH levels help to differentiate it from secondary causes, which would show low ACTH levels. Primary adrenal insufficiency will also have a compensatory elevation in renin levels due to decreased aldosterone in the body.

Treatment is with a combination of glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and sex hormone replacement depending on the patient's symptoms and requirement.

Other options-

Option (B): GnRH has no relation to ACTH or MSH production.

Option (C): Cortisol levels will be low in Addison's disease. This is the cause for feedback elevation in ACTH, not the cause for hyperpigmentation.

Option (D): Aldosterone does not cause hyperpigmentation. Similar to option (C), the low aldosterone causes feedback elevation in the ACTH levels.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with sudden, wild flailing of the right side of the body. A lesion at which of the following sites is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Sudden, wild flailing of one side of the body suggests the movement disorder, hemiballismus, due to a lesion at the contralateral subthalamic nucleus.

Option D: Lesions in the substantia nigra would present with pill-rolling tremors of Parkinson's disease seen at rest. These tremors decrease upon intentional movement.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with fever, easy fatigability and weight loss. The bone marrow aspirate of the patient is shown below. Which of the following genetic aberrations is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
The image shows faggot cells (multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks) which is a feature of Acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APML) / AML-M3. The most common genetic aberration associated is the PML-RAR-α fusion gene.

AML is a hematopoietic progenitor malignancy that causes immature myeloblast accumulation in the bone marrow.  Incidence increases with age and peaks after 60 years of age. Occupational exposure to benzene leads to epoxide formation which in turn predisposes to the development of AML.

Clinically, the patients present with symptoms resulting from pancytopenia (anaemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia). There is generalized fatigue, bone pain, bleeding tendencies, and an increased risk of recurrent infections.

Bone marrow/ peripheral smear shows a large, uniform population of cells (myeloblasts) with prominent nucleoli. It shows the presence of primary cytoplasmic granules. Auer rods are needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes.

FAB classification of AML has 7 subtypes from AML-M1 to AML-M. AML-M3 has t(15:17) translocation. The most common complication associated with AML-M3 is disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Treatment of AML M3 is all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA).

Other options:

Option A: BCR-ABL fusion gene is seen in chronic myeloid leukaemia characterised by the presence of a Philadelphia chromosome resulting from reciprocal translocation of t(9;22).

Option C: CBFB-MYH11 is seen in AML with inv16 which comes in FAB AML-M4.

Option D: RUNX1-ETO is seen in AML with t(8:21) which comes in FAB AML-M

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with headaches, seizures, and focal neurologic deficits. MRI findings are shown in the image below. Considering the sign seen in the image, what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of headache, seizures, focal neurological deficits, and the MRI showing a dural tail sign are suggestive of meningioma.

The dural tail sign refers to a linear, contrast-enhancing tail-like extension from the tumour, along the dura matter. It is most commonly seen in meningioma (present in about 60% of the cases). However, it may also be seen in the following non-meningiomatous lesions such as schwannoma, sarcoidosis, primary CNS lymphoma, metastasis, and chloroma.

The image given below shows axial (A) and sagittal (B) contrast-enhanced MRI images of the brain. The arrows point towards the thickening and enhancements of the dura, tapering away from the mass and resembling a tail (dural tail sign).

Radiological features of meningioma:

  • Angiography may reveal a spoke wheel appearance, or a dense, homogeneous, and persistent blush representing meningeal blood supply to the tumor.
  • CT usually reveals a hyperdense extra-axial mass with or without calcification.
  • MRI may show capping cysts, vasogenic edema, and a dural tail sign.
  • PET shows high uptake of 68Ga-DOTATOC, a somatostatin receptor-targeted ligand.

Other options:

Option A: Extradural hematoma refers to the collection of blood between the skull and dura mater. It appears as a lenticular, biconvex lesion in acute cases or as a crescentic-shaped lesion in chronic cases.

Option B: Subdural hematoma refers to the collection of blood between the dura and arachnoid mater. It appears as a crescentic concave in acute cases or an elliptical lesion in chronic cases.

Option C: Craniopharyngioma is a benign suprasellar tumor arising from squamous epithelial remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is commonly located in the hypothalamic region. On MRI, it usually appears as a cystic lesion. It may also present as a mixed cystic or solid lesion. The solid components show intense contrast enhancement.

questions.text: A patient underwent abdominal hysterectomy. On the fourth post-operative day, she develops severe abdominal pain and distension. She can pass urine normally. Her blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg and heart rate is 62 bpm. On ultrasonography, fluid is found in the abdominal cavity. What is most likely the cause of the ultrasonography findings?
questions.solution:
A post-hysterectomy presenting with abdominal pain and distension is most likely due to injury to the ureter. The uterine artery crosses the ureter anteriorly (water under the bridge) so damage to the ureter is more likely at this site during hysterectomy. The injured ureter leaks out urine, thus leading to pain and distension of the abdomen. If untreated it can lead to chemical peritonitis. 

In patients with unilateral ureteral injury, urine output and ability to pass urine will be normal.

The sequence of clamping of structures in abdominal hysterectomy is as follows:

  • The first clamp includes the round ligament and infundibulopelvic ligament (when ovaries are to be removed)
  • The second clamp includes the uterine artery
  • The third clamp includes the cardinal ligament and uterosacral ligament

Other Options:

Options A, B: Both injuries to the round ligament and ovarian artery are unlikely in this patient as loss of blood would have led to a reduction in blood pressure due to exsanguination and a more acute presentation. However, this patient has normal blood pressure. The round ligament is the only ligament that receives a blood supply from the Sampson artery. If it is improperly clamped during the hysterectomy, it can result in hemoperitoneum.  

Option D: Injury to the urinary bladder is not probable here as bladder injuries present with pain and reduced micturition due to extravasation of the urine into the peritoneal cavity. This patient has no difficulty with passing urine.

questions.text:
During FESS, as the last step, the surgeon approaches the sphenoid sinus and accidentally damages the internal carotid artery. Which anatomical variant of paranasal sinuses is likely responsible for this occurrence?

FESS - Functional endoscopic sinus surgery
questions.solution:
The accidental damage to the internal carotid artery is likely due to the presence of the Onodi cell. 

The Onodi cell, also referred to as sphenoethmoid air cells, is the posterior-most ethmoidal cell positioned superiorly or laterally to the sphenoid sinus. It is an anatomical variant of the paranasal sinuses.

It lies very close to the optic nerve and internal carotid artery. Attempting endoscopic entry into the sphenoid sinus by traversing the posterior wall of the Onodi cell can pose a risk of potential damage to these vital structures.

The CT scan image below shows the Onodi cell:

Other options:

Option A: Haller cells are a type of anterior ethmoidal cells that are situated on the roof of the maxillary sinus. 

Option B: Agger nasi is another type of anterior ethmoidal cell that is present in the agger nasi ridge.

Option C: Bulla ethmoidalis is the ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process. It forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris.
