questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with fatigue, restlessness and confusion. Laboratory results reveal hyponatremia. Upon further investigation, the urine sodium concentration is found to be >20 mM. Which of the following would cause this pattern of findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this patient with hyponatremia and raised urine concentration of sodium most likely has hypervolemic hyponatremia. Chronic renal failure can cause this pattern of findings. 

Hyponatremia is identified by serum sodium levels below 135 mEq/L and can manifest as euvolemic, hypovolemic, or hypervolemic. Hypervolemic hyponatremia occurs when total body water (TBW) increases more than total body sodium.

In both acute and chronic renal failure, compromised renal function leads to inadequate excretion of free water. Combined with renal sodium losses (resulting in elevated urinary sodium levels > 20 mM), this scenario results in hypervolemic hyponatremia.

Conditions such as cardiac dysfunction, reduced arterial filling in congestive heart failure, hypoalbuminemia in nephrotic syndrome, and peripheral vasodilation in cirrhosis cause decreased effective blood volume. Impaired renal blood flow activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, leading to a more significant increase in total body water than total body sodium, resulting in dilutional hyponatremia. Urine sodium is typically low (< 10 mM).

Hypovolemic hyponatremia may arise from renal losses (diuretic toxicity, salt-losing syndromes, bicarbonaturia) or extra-renal losses (burns, pancreatitis, trauma, vomiting, diarrhea, fluid collection in third spaces).

Euvolemic hyponatremia can be caused by glucocorticoid deficiency, syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), thyroid disorders, and stress.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient with ulcerative colitis came to the OPD with the following findings. Which among the following drugs in his prescription is the most likely to cause this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The above radiological image is suggestive of toxic megacolon and the drug that can cause this adverse effect is loperamide.

Loperamide is an anti-diarrhoeal agent. It is majorly used for acute and chronic non-specific diarrhea and irritable bowel syndrome. 

When taken as an overdose it can cause toxic megacolon in patients suffering from inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis.

Other options:

Option A: Mesalamine (5-amino salicylic acid) is a salicylate that is used for local effects in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

Option C: Budesonide is a synthetic glucocorticoid. It exhibits greater affinity for the glucocorticoid receptor and acts on specific portions of the inflamed gut with minimal side effects.

Option D: Azathioprine is a purine analogue immunosuppressive agent used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, multiple sclerosis, and other autoimmune conditions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes with a history of a hip fracture which was treated surgically, four months ago. You observe him walking with the gait shown below. Injury to which of the following nerves is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of left superior gluteal nerve injury. 

The patient shows characteristic lurching gait/ Trendelenburg's gait (positive Trendelenburg's sign), which is seen in paralysis of gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. These muscles are supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. 

When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in the slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.

When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported (normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb.

In the given case, when the patient lifts up his right leg and tries to stand on the left leg, his right pelvis tilts down. This shows that the left side abduction mechanism is paralyzed and the right side is normal. Hence, the left superior gluteal nerve injury is present in this case.

The image given below shows the Trendelenberg test.

Note: Inferior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus maximus muscle.

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: An adolescent girl presents to you with lesions on her face. She confides in you that she frequently picks the real or imagined acne from her face and does this when she is under stress. The term used for this self-inflicted skin condition is called:
questions.solution:
Acne excoriée is a self-inflicted skin condition, in which the sufferer compulsively picks real or imagined acne lesions predominantly on the face. It is predominantly seen in adolescent girls. 

Other psychiatric disorders associated with acne are:

  • Body dysmorphic disorder: A small number of patients with BDD have acne as their prime symptom. The perceived acne is out of proportion to physical signs.
  • Eating disorders: Acne has been reported in anorexia nervosa. Acne itself may be a predisposing factor for anorexia in vulnerable teenage age groups who adopt a diet in an attempt to control their acne. 

Other options:

Option B: Acne mechanica: This term describes acneform lesions that occur at the site of repeated mechanical trauma and/or frictional obstruction of the pilosebaceous outlet. Examples include mechanical pressure from high‐necked jerseys, shoulder pads, seat backs in trucks, or adhesive plasters causing acneform folliculitis.

Option C: Acne conglobata: Acne conglobata represents a rare and severe form of acne characterized by multiple and extensive inflammatory papules, tender nodules, and abscesses which commonly coalesce to form malodorous draining sinus tracts.

Option D: Acne fulminans: Acne fulminans or acne maligna is a rare and severe destructive form of acne presenting primarily in adolescent males. It most frequently affects the trunk but can affect the face. It presents acutely in association with systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presented with abdominal pain and hematemesis. He has been taking antacids for heartburn for the last three years. He was stabilized. Endoscopy revealed a bleeding ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenum near the pylorus. Which of the following vessels is most likely to be the source of bleeding?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of upper gastrointestinal bleeding probably due to peptic ulcer disease. The vessel most likely to be the source of bleeding is the gastroduodenal artery.

Peptic ulcers include duodenal and gastric ulcers of which duodenal ulcers are more common. 

The common sites are the first part of the duodenum and the lesser curvature of the stomach especially incisura angularis respectively.

Risk factors include H.pylori infection, NSAID intake, and cigarette smoking.

Features of a duodenal ulcer include bleeding and perforation. Ulcers located in the posterior wall can erode the mucosa and the gastroduodenal artery, leading to hematemesis and melena. Perforation is common with anterior duodenal ulcers.

Gastric ulcer also tends to bleed and perforate. They are much larger than duodenal ulcers.

questions.text: A couple comes to a hospital for genetic counselling and upon further evaluation, the husband is found to have Marfan syndrome. The inheritance pattern and mutation associated with this condition are:

choices.text: Autosomal dominant, mutation in FBN-1 gene
Autosomal recessive, mutation in FBN-1 gene
Autosomal dominant, mutation in FBN-2 gene
Autosomal recessive, mutation in FBN-2 gene

questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern in Marfan syndrome is autosomal dominant and is associated with a mutation in FBN-1 gene.

Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder affecting connective tissues associated chiefly with cardiovascular, ocular, and musculoskeletal abnormalities, although involvement of other organ systems like the central nervous system, respiratory system and skin has also been observed. It results from an inherited defect in an extracellular glycoprotein called fibrillin-1.

Fibrillin occurs in two homologous forms, fibrillin-1 and fibrillin-2, encoded by two separate genes, FBN-1 and FBN-2, located on the long arms of chromosomes 15 and 5, respectively. Mutations of FBN-1 give rise to marfan syndrome while mutations of the related FBN-2 gene give rise to congenital contractural arachnodactyly, characterized by skeletal abnormalities, which is less common. 

Fibrillin-1 is a regulator of TGF-β which is responsible for inflammation, fibrosis, and activation of specific matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), particularly MMP-2 and MMP-9, which result in the loss of extracellular matrix.

Patients with Marfan syndrome are tall and have a decreased upper to lower segment ratio with long arms, hands, and fingers. Deformities of the chest wall, vertebral column, and foot arches may be present.

Associated cardiovascular abnormalities include mitral valve prolapse leading to mitral regurgitation and dilatation of aortic root/sinuses of Valsalva leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture.

Ocular features include ectopia lentis, retinal detachment, cataracts and refractive errors like myopia due to increased axial length.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a throbbing unilateral headache of severe intensity, which is aggravated by movement and is associated with photophobia. Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonists were found to be effective in the management of her headache. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of throbbing unilateral headache responsive to CGRP antagonists indicates a diagnosis of migraine headache.

Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches, after tension headaches. It is characterized by unilateral and throbbing headaches of moderate to severe intensity. Other features of migraine include deep-seated pain and sensitivity to environmental and sensory stimuli. The headache can be triggered by glares, bright lights, sounds, hunger, stress, physical exertion, hormonal fluctuations during menses, lack of or excess sleep, or alcohol.

Management of migraine includes nonpharmacologic management and pharmacologic measures. Triggers unique to the patient should be avoided. Lifestyle modifications to avoid excessive caffeine and alcohol, and to maintain a healthy sleep cycle are necessary. Triptans (Sumatriptan, Zolmitriptan) is used in the treatment of acute attacks. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can be useful if taken early after symptom onset. Other drugs include oral dopamine receptor antagonists and opioids. 

Migraine is associated with the release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) within the trigeminal nucleus. Hence, newer therapies under evaluation include CGRP antagonists and monoclonal antibodies to CGRP and its receptor. They are considered to be as effective as triptans and are better tolerated. 

Other options:

Option A - Cluster headaches are deep, retro-orbital, unilateral, excruciating headaches. They are characterized by attacks at the same time every day. 

Option B - Temporal arteritis or giant cell arteritis is a vasculitis. It affects medium to large-sized arteries. It is characterized by fever, anemia, high erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and headaches in people over the age of 50. 

Option D - Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by excruciating pain in the area of the trigeminal nerve. It lasts for a few seconds to a minute and can recur. 

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text:
A 4-year-old child presents with petechiae and generalized fatigue. He has a recent history of fever and diarrhea. Laboratory investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hemoglobin - 9.1 g/dL
Platelets - 35,000 /mm3
WBCs - 14,800 /mm3
Blood urea - 29 mg/dL
Creatinine - 2.1 mg/ dL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 4-year-old child, with a recent history of diarrheal illness, presenting with petechiae, generalized fatigue, and lab investigations revealing anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated blood urea and creatinine is suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). 

HUS is a condition characterized by the triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. It commonly affects children less than 5 years of age. The disease is often linked to a preceding gastrointestinal infection caused by Shiga toxin-producing strains like E. coli O157:H7 or Shigella dysenteriae.

There is widespread injury to small vessel endothelium, leading to thrombotic microangiopathy. The formation of these microthrombi causes a decrease in platelet count. There is associated destruction of RBCs causing hemolytic anemia. Renal vascular occlusion by microthrombi results in acute kidney injury.

Investigations will show a hemolytic blood picture with reticulocytosis and schistocytes on a peripheral smear. There will be reduced platelets and deranged renal function tests. Liver function tests will reveal an elevated indirect bilirubin.

Other options:

Option A: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura results in low platelets, usually following a bacterial or viral infection. It can present with bleeding diathesis like petechiae, purpura, or epistaxis. It is, however, not associated with low hemoglobin, or deranged renal function. 

Option B: IgA nephropathy usually presents with hematuria and low-grade fever following a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. It is associated with deranged renal function. However, it is not associated with low hemoglobin or low platelets. 

Option C: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis presents with hematuria (cola-colored urine), hypertension, and edema following prior infection with group A beta-hemolytic streptococci. It may be associated with low hemoglobin and deranged renal functions. However, thrombocytopenia is unlikely.

questions.text: A child is brought to your clinic with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain. The stool microscopy image is given below. Eggs were non-bile stained and floated in the saturated salt solution. What is the most likely organism implicated?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with a diarrheal illness and stool microscopy revealing characteristic eggs that are non-bile stained and float in the saturated salt solution implicates the most likely organism to be Hymenolepis nana.

Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the smallest tapeworm and man is the definite host. It occurs more commonly in children and the patient acquires this infection by ingesting food or water contaminated with its eggs. The adult worm resides in the small intestine. Patients are usually asymptomatic but in heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritability. Pruritus may also be present due to an allergic response.

Stool microscopy reveals eggs that are non-bile stained and float in the saturated salt solution. They have a thin colorless outer membrane and thread-like polar filaments.

A single dose of praziquantel (25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice for treatment.

The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana:

Other options:

Option A- The fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides are bile-stained and float in a saturated solution of salt water. They are round or oval in shape. The egg is surrounded by a thick smooth translucent shell having a coarsely mamillated translucent coat. In the middle of the egg, there is a large unsegmented ovum. It covers the entire area of the egg, except for the poles.

Unfertilized eggs do not float in the salt solution. They are long, narrow, and elliptical. They have thinner shells with irregular albumin coating and small atrophied ovum

Option B- The eggs of the Ancylostoma duodenale are non-bile stained and float in a saturated salt solution. It has a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane and a segmented ovum containing 4-8 blastomeres. The space between the hyaline shell and the ovum is clear. 

Option D- Eggs of Trichuris trichuria are brown, bile stained, and float in a saturated salt solution. They are barrel-shaped, with a mucus plug on either end.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with lepromatous leprosy was administered a 'transfer factor' containing competent lymphocytes to improve his immunity. Which of the following types of immunity is offered by this treatment?
questions.solution:
The administration of the transfer factor provides adoptive immunity, which is a special type of immunity.

Adoptive immunity is immunity in which immunologically competent lymphocytes are injected. The transfer factor is composed of these immunologically competent lymphocytes. It can passively transfer cell-mediated immunity against those antigens to which the donor is sensitive.

Adoptive immunity is different from adaptive immunity. 

Adaptive immunity/ active immunity is the resistance developed by an individual as a result of an antigenic stimulus. It is known as adaptive immunity as it represents the adaptive response of the host to a specific pathogen or another antigen.

Types of immunity: 

  • Natural active immunity: It results from either a clinical or an inapparent infection by a microbe. For e.g, A person who has recovered from an attack of measles develops natural active immunity against measles.
  • Artificial active immunity: It is the resistance induced by vaccines which are preparations of killed or attenuated microorganisms or their products. For e.g, the BCG vaccine induces immunity against TB
  • Natural passive immunity: It is the immunity passively transferred from mother to baby. In human infants, maternal antibodies are transmitted predominantly through the placenta, while in animals such as pigs, the transfer of antibodies occurs mainly through the colostrum. The human colostrum is also rich in lgA antibodies and gives protection to the neonate
  • Artificial passive immunity: It is the resistance passively transferred to a recipient by the administration of antibodies. Hyperimmune sera of animal or human origin, convalescent sera, pooled human immunoglobulin are used for this purpose. For e.g, anti-tetanus serum, anti-diphtherial serum.
  • Combined immunization: Sometimes a combination of the active and passive methods of immunization is used; Antisera and vaccine are given at the same time. For e.g, in the protection of a non-immune individual with a tetanus-prone wound, tetanus immunoglogulin (TIG) is injected in one arm, with a full course of tetanus toxoid in the other. This is followed by full course of tetanus toxoid vaccine. TIG provides the protection necessary till active immunity is able to take effect.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of fever, sore throat, redness, and irritation of the eyes. You suspect pharyngoconjunctival fever. Which of the following serotypes of adenovirus is likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Pharyngoconjunctival fever is associated with adenovirus serotypes 3, 4, 7, and 14. 

Pharyngoconjunctival fever is an acute infectious illness characterized by pharyngitis, tender pre-auricular lymphadenopathy, fever, and acute follicular conjunctivitis. It is highly contagious and can spread rapidly among individuals who live or work closely together.

Adenovirus is a non-enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus. They are associated with infections of the respiratory tract, eye, and intestines. Different serotypes are implicated as the causes of different clinical manifestations:

  • Serotypes 8, 19, 37 (option A) - epidemic keratoconjunctivitis
  • Serotypes 40, 41 (option C) - diarrheal disease in children
  • Serotypes 1, 2, 5 (option D), and 6 - respiratory diseases (pharyngitis and tonsillitis) in children
  • Serotypes 3 and 7 have also been implicated in more severe infections like pneumonia

questions.text: A 20-year-old female singer presents to you with a weakness of voice after having multiple recordings in the studio. Indirect laryngoscopy shows the following finding. This appearance of the glottis is due to the weakness of which of the following muscle(s)?
questions.solution:
The indirect laryngoscopy image shows a keyhole appearance which is seen in phonasthenia. It is caused by the weakness of both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid muscles.

Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of the laryngeal muscles. This leads to a phonatory gap visualized by indirect laryngoscopy. The shape of the gap depends on the muscles involved:

    • Thyroarytenoid alone: elliptical space
    • Interarytenoid alone: triangular space
    • Both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid: keyhole appearance

This condition is treated by voice rest and vocal hygiene.

Spasms of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle (option D) cause abductor dysphonia.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

questions.text: The following phonocardiogram of a patient presenting with a murmur at the left 5th intercostal space next to the sternum is shown below. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given phonocardiogram shows a holosystolic murmur. The tricuspid area is present just to the left of the sternum in the 5th intercostal space. The tricuspid valve is the most commonly involved in carcinoid syndrome, which causes tricuspid insufficiency. 

The right heart is more commonly affected than the left heart, with tricuspid involvement in more than 97% of patients. This is likely due to the effects of bradykinin and serotonin coming in contact with the tricuspid valve first. The pulmonary capillary bed degrades the metabolites and serves as a filter, relatively protecting the left side of the heart from fibrosis.

Carcinoid heart disease is characterized by the formation of fibrous plaques on the heart valves, chambers, and blood vessels. These plaques can distort the valves, leading to stenosis or regurgitation. Patients with obvious carcinoid symptoms, such as flushing, diarrhea, and bronchospasm, are more likely to have cardiac involvement. Physical examination may reveal a murmur and signs of right heart failure. 

The carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors arising from enterochromaffin cells that can occur anywhere in the GIT. The most common site is the appendix followed by the ileum and rectum. A tumor with liver metastasis is likely to produce carcinoid syndrome. 

The diagnosis is made by assessing 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) in a 24-hour urine sample. It is positive in larger tumors only if metastases are present. 

Ultrasonography, CT scan, and MRI may show the primary tumor and metastases. The best method for staging carcinoid tumors is by octreotide scan or somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS).

Somatostatin and its analogs are used in the symptomatic treatment of carcinoid syndrome. Surgery should be undertaken as soon as the diagnosis is made, even in the presence of liver metastases.

Other options:

Option B: The most common valves affected in rheumatic heart disease are the aortic and mitral valves. However since the given murmur is present in the tricuspid area, this makes carcinoid syndrome the likely cause. 

Option C: Tertiary syphilis involves mainly the aortic valve. However since the given murmur is present in the tricuspid area, this makes carcinoid syndrome the likely cause. 

Option D: Left heart failure causes a mitral regurgitation due to a stretch caused by the pooled blood which leads to separation of the mitral valve leaflets. However, it does not cause a tricuspid regurgitation. 

Note: The most common small intestine tumor is carcinoid.
The most common site of small intestine carcinoid is the ileum.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication of the device shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bone-anchored hearing aid (BAHA) which consists of three parts, an innermost titanium fixture in the bone, a middle abutment, and an outer hearing aid fixed to the abutment. It is indicated in congenital deformities of the external ear like canal atresia.

BAHA contains a sound processor which allows the bone to transfer sound to a functioning cochlea through direct bone conduction using the principle of osseointegration.

BAHA can be used for patients for whom conventional hearing aids are not suitable. The indications include:

  • Congenital or acquired deformities of the external ear not amendable to treatment (eg. canal atresia)
  • Chronic discharging ears
  • Otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis when surgery is contraindicated
  • Single side deafness

questions.text: Among the following, what is the initial fluid of choice for treating diarrhea in an infant who has normal weight for length with rotavirus infection?
questions.solution:
Low osmolarity ORS is the initial fluid of choice for treating diarrhea in an infant who has normal weight for length with rotavirus infection. 

The loss of sodium stool in rotavirus infection is around 50-70 mmol/L, which can be replenished by low osmolarity ORS with a sodium concentration of 75 mmol/L. It is also called WHO-reduced osmolarity ORS.

The low osmolarity of the ORS in the intestinal lumen as compared to the blood facilitate absorption of fluid and hence the electrolytes due to the solvent drag.

Studies have shown that low osmolarity ORS causes reduction in stool output, decrease in vomiting, and decrease in the use of unscheduled intravenous fluids without increasing the risk of hyponatremia.

ReSoMal is given to severely malnourished children.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with the diagnosis of mycosis fungoides. Which of the following features is not seen in the histopathological examination in this case?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Civatte bodies are a feature that is not seen in the histopathological study of this condition. Civatte bodies, also known as colloid bodies are a histopathological feature that is seen in lichen planus.

Civatte bodies (also known as colloid bodies) are damaged basal keratinocytes that have undergone apoptosis, consisting largely of keratin intermediate filaments and immunoglobulins. 

Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, characterized by polymorphic patches and plaques with fine scaling usually present on the limbs, breast, and buttocks. The lesions may be pruritic or even asymptomatic.

Histological hallmarks include:

  • Sézary-Lutzner cells - cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/ hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane) (Option A).
  • Pautrier's microabscesses - tumor cells invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters, forming a collection of atypical lymphocytes in the epidermis (Option D).
  • Epidermotropism - pronounced invasion of the tumor cells into the epidermis (Option B).

Image below showing erythematous plaques seen in mycosis fungoides

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with gout is asked to undergo the radiological test shown below. What is this imaging modality called?
questions.solution:
The above imaging modality is dual-energy CT (DECT).

Dual-energy CT allows for the analysis of energy-dependent variations in the attenuation of various materials by using two distinct X-ray spectra to obtain two image datasets of the same anatomic region. 

It enables material separation to distinguish uric acid crystals from calcium to determine the composition of urinary calculi and diagnose gout.

With the help of a DECT scan, the calcium crystals are coloured blue, while the uric acid crystals are coloured green, making gout diagnosis simple and non-invasive. DECT can also be used to quantify the overall tophus burden or volume of urate deposition without any user variability. This makes DECT an ideal tool for assessing any variation in tophus burden and enables follow-up to record treatment response.

Uses of DECT include:

  • Detection and quantification of urate crystals in gout
  • Characterization of renal stones, cysts and masses 
  • Identification of silicone leaks from breast implants.
  • Detection of bone marrow edema
  • Detection of pulmonary embolism
  • Detection of myocardial ischemia 

Gout is characterized by an inflammatory reaction that results in the formation of gouty tophi and arthropathy when monosodium urate (MSU) crystals are deposited in the soft tissue and joints. A definitive diagnosis necessitates the microscopic identification of MSU crystals through joint fluid aspiration, an invasive procedure that could yield false negative results.

Other options

Option B: Dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI refers to the serial MRI acquisitions following IV contrast agents.

Option C: Single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) is a nuclear medicine imaging technique that uses gamma-emitting radioisotopes(tracers) like technetium-99(99mTc) -hexamethylpropyleneamine oxime (HMPAO). These radiotracers are used to investigate cerebrovascular diseases and epilepsy. 

The image below shows a SPECT CT depicting hyperactivity of tibial physis in a growing child:


Option D: Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) is a variation of diffusion-weighted imaging, where the diffusion of the fluid, is assessed in six or more directions. It helps to identify the location, orientation, and anisotropy of the white matter tracts of the brain.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has left-sided CN III palsy and right-sided hemiplegia. Visual field testing reveals right homonymous hemianopia and Wernicke's hemianopic pupillary reaction. Which of the following represents the site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes Wernicke's hemianopic pupil reaction. The site of lesion in the Wernicke hemianopic pupil is the optic tract.

Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is an abnormal light reflex. Here, illumination of the blind half of the retina shows no pupillary reaction while illumination of the normal half of the retina shows a pupillary reaction. It is seen in lesions involving the optic tract.

Lesions of the optic tract cause blindness in half of the visual field, known as homonymous hemianopia. Homonymous hemianopia involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. Optic tract lesions also present with contralateral CN III palsy and ipsilateral hemiplegia, due to the proximity of the crus cerebri and CN III. 

Common causes of optic tract lesions- 

  • More commonly due to secondary lesions of the optic tract such as chordomas, pituitary adenomas, tentorial meningiomas, aneurysms, etc. 
  • Primary lesions of the optic tract such as syphilitic meningitis or gumma, tuberculosis or tumor of optic thalamus or temporospenoidal lobe

 

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the epidural technique of anesthesia

choices.text: Block can be given at any level of the vertebral column
It can be used for postoperative pain relief
Needle insertion is confirmed by the backflow of CSF

questions.solution:
Confirmation of needle insertion by backflow of CSF is a false statement about epidural anesthesia. This statement is true for spinal anesthesia.

In the epidural type of anesthesia, the needle is inserted into the epidural space, and the position of the needle is confirmed by a sudden loss of resistance (as the needle passes through the ligamentum flavum). But, in spinal anesthesia, the needle is advanced through the epidural space, and dura–subarachnoid membrane is penetrated. Here, the position of the needle is confirmed by freely flowing CSF. In epidural anesthesia, the needle does not penetrate the dura mater and hence this layer remains intact. Hence, besides option C, all other options are true features of epidural anesthesia.

Epidural techniques are widely used for surgical anesthesia, obstetric analgesia, postoperative pain control, and chronic pain management (with epidural infusion through the catheter). An epidural block can be performed at the lumbar, thoracic, or cervical levels.

Identification points:

  • It has a blunt, curved tip (Huber tip) that prevents accidental dural puncture.
  • The needle shaft is made of a flexible, radioopaque, calibrated plastic marked at 1 cm intervals so that the insertion depth can be identified.

Related Pearl: Differences between Spinal and Epidural anesthesia

Related Pearl: High yield points in epidural anaesthesia

  • Epidural space lies between dura and ligamentum flavum
  • Dura is not penetrated
  • The site of action of epidural anesthesia is nerve roots
  • Methods to identify epidural space:
    • Loss of resistance technique
    • Hanging drop technique – Gutierrez's sign (sudden sucking of a drop in epidural space)
  • Methods to confirm epidural anesthesia
    • Test dose with 3cc lidocaine with 15mcg adrenaline (1:2,00,000) - Intrathecal injection will produce spinal anesthesia (lidocaine) that should be rapidly apparent. Intravascular injection will produce significant tachycardia 20% above baseline (adrenaline).
    • Durant’s sign – rapid injection of the drug in epidural space causes an increase in rate and depth of respiration
    • Westpal sign – absence of knee-jerk after epidural anesthesia
  • Anesthetic of choice in epidural anesthesia during labor - Bupivacaine
  • Epidural narcotic preferred over epidural local anesthesia because of the absence of motor paralysis
  • Drugs used for epidural analgesia- Morphine, Fentanyl
  • Epidural opioids act on dorsal horn substantia gelatinosa. It may cause pruritis and respiratory depression
  • Drug not given in central neuraxial block or caudal block- Remifentanil
  • Walking epidural- Ultra low dose epidural used especially for labor (only sensory blockade)
  • Complication of Epidural anesthesia -Total spinal anesthesia
  • Not a complication of epidural anesthesia –DIC, Headache
  • During epidural anesthesia- sudden hypotension is due to the drug entering subarachnoid space

The most commonly used needle for epidural analgesia is a Tuohy needle (16-18G). It has a blunt bevel with a curve at the tip. The blunt bevel helps to push away the dura after passing through the ligamentum flavum instead of penetrating it. The curved tip decreases the incidences of dural puncture. The image below shows a Tuohy needle.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with complaints of difficulty in initiating and maintaining the stream of urination. Ultrasonography reveals an increase in prostate size. You start him on tamsulosin. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and tamsulosin acts by selective α1 receptor antagonism.

Tamsulosin is a uroselective α1 blocker that acts by decreasing the tone of prostatic/ bladder neck muscles. This reduces the dynamic obstruction and increases the urinary flow rate. It is used in the treatment of BPH and acute urinary retention. It is taken once a day and preferred in cases with postural hypotension as it has very little effect on BP. Retrograde ejaculation and floppy iris during cataract surgery are the side effects of this drug.

  Other α1 antagonists used in BPH include

  • Terazosin - Apoptosis promoting effect on prostate
  • Doxazosin - Apoptosis promoting effect on prostate
  • Alfuzosin - Specifically created for BHP, not used as an antihypertensive

Other uses of α1 receptor antagonists include the management of hypertension and short-term management of congestive heart failure.

Other options:

Option B:  Selective α1 receptor agonists such as phenylephrine are used as nasal decongestants and also as a mydriatic agent. Midodrine has been used to treat patients with autonomic insufficiency and postural hypotension. 

Option C: Nonselective α receptor antagonism can be seen in drugs such as phenoxybenzamine and phentolamine. They are administered prior to the surgical removal of pheochromocytoma to control the episodes of severe hypertension. They have also been used to manage the cheese reaction occurring in patients who take MAO inhibitors.

Option D: Selective α2 receptor agonists such as clonidine have been used in treating hypertension. 

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: During a direct examination, the prosecution witness gives a statement that contradicts what he told the police during the initial investigation. The prosecution lawyer asks him “You are lying because you have been paid money, yes or no?” Which of the following statements is true with regard to the question asked in this scenario?

choices.text: It can be asked by the prosecution lawyer during re-direct examination
Such questions are not allowed during cross-examination
It is permitted during direct examination to prove the hostility of the witness
The question asked in the above scenario is defined under Sec 191, IPC

questions.solution:
The question asked in the above scenario is a leading question that is permitted during direct examination only to prove the hostility of the witness. The witness is considered hostile as he gives a contrary statement in an attempt to conceal the truth or give false evidence.

As per section 141 of the Indian Evidence Act (Option D), leading questions are defined as questions that suggest the answer that the person asking the question wishes or expects to receive. They are not allowed during the direct examination (Examination-in-Chief) conducted by the summoning counsel. The only exception to this is if the judge is satisfied that the witness is hostile, leading questions may be allowed during direct examination. 

The sequence of examination in the recording of evidence is as follows -

Sequence of Examination Objective

Examination-in-chief/direct examination by the party that summoned the witness

 

To elicit the facts of the case from the witness.

Leading questions are not allowed.

Cross-examination by the defence lawyer

To elicit facts favorable to their case and test the reliability of the witness.

Leading questions are allowed. (Option B)

Re-examination by the party that summoned the witness

To resolve doubts that formed during cross-examination and re-emphasize the party's perspective.

Leading questions are not allowed. (Option A)

Other options:

Option D: Section 191 I.P.C deals with false evidence and is based upon recognition of the decline of moral values and erosion of the sanctity of oath or perjury. A person commits perjury by lying under oath. The punishment of perjury is dealt under IPC 193

questions.text: Smoky green urine is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Smoky green urine is a feature of phenol/carbolic acid poisoning because of oxidation of its metabolic end products hydroquinone and pyrocatechol. These products turn urine olive green or brown on standing and the phenomenon is called carboluria.

Carbolic acid or phenol is an organic acid that is used as a disinfectant and solvent. It has a characteristic phenolic odor. Poisoning by carbolic acid is called carbolism.

On exposure to the skin, carbolic acid coagulates the proteins and causes the formation of an eschar that will come off as slough later. It can damage the nerves and cause tingling and numbness.

On ingestion, a burning sensation may be felt, along with nausea and vomiting. Vomiting puts the patient at risk of aspiration pneumonia. The acid can also cause pulmonary and laryngeal edema, leading to difficulty breathing, and ultimately respiratory failure. Systemic features include headache, dizziness, syncope, and even coma.

Diagnosis of carbolic acid poisoning can be made by adding a few drops of 10% ferric chloride to the patient's urine sample. If the sample turns violet or blue, it indicates the presence of phenolic compounds. The urine sample would also reduce Benedict's and Fehling's solutions.

Treatment involves removing contaminated clothing and washing the skin. If the patient has ingested the poison, cautious gastric lavage with 20% alcohol, glycerol, or vegetable oil should be carried out. MgSO4 or liquid paraffin should be left in the stomach to remove surface phenol and prevent deep penetration. Parenteral saline can also be administered to correct the circulatory depression, dilute the carbolic acid content of the blood, and promote its excretion. Hemodialysis can be carried out if there is renal failure.

Other options: 

Option B: Smoky stool syndrome/luminescent stool is a feature of phosphorous poisoning. 

Option C and D: Arsenic and mercury poisoning are not associated with green urine. See pearls #2099 and #2100.

questions.text: A patient presents with diarrhea following prolonged antibiotic therapy. The colonoscopy image is shown below. What is the mechanism of action of the oral drug used for treatment of the given condition?

choices.text: Inhibits the transglycosylase enzyme to prevent cell wall synthesis
Inhibits protein synthesis by binding to 30S ribosome
Inhibit the transpeptidases enzymes to prevent cell wall synthesis

questions.solution:
The given case scenario of a patient developing diarrhea after a course of antibiotics with the colonoscopy showing multiple pseudomembranes most likely has developed pseudomembranous colitis caused by Clostridium difficile. Vancomycin is one of the first line drugs for this condition. It works by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide and inhibits the transglycosylase enzyme preventing elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking.

Clinical uses:

  • Parenteral vancomycin is given for bloodstream infections and endocarditis caused by Methicillin Resistant Staphylococcus Aureus (MRSA).
  • Vancomycin plus gentamicin is given as an alternative regimen for enterococcal endocarditis with penicillin allergy.
  • In combination with other agents for suspected meningitis or meningitis due to penicillin-resistant pneumococcus.
  • Oral vancomycin is given for Clostridium difficile colitis.

The other first-line drug used for the treatment of C. difficile colitis is Fidaxomicin, which belongs to the macrolide group of drugs and works by inhibiting the 50S ribosomal subunit. 

Option B: Tetracyclines (Eg. doxycycline, minocycline) and aminoglycosides (eg. gentamicin, tobramycin, amikacin) inhibit the protein synthesis by binding to the 30s subunit of the ribosomes of susceptible organisms.

Option C: Fluoroquinolones act by inhibiting the enzyme DNA gyrase.  

Option D: Beta-lactam antibiotics are also cell wall synthesis inhibitors. They inhibit the enzyme transpeptidase that is required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan chain.

  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy had persistent headaches,  gait disturbances and cognitive difficulties. CT scan revealed a cystic mass in the right cerebellar hemisphere which was resected. The biopsy of the specimen showed cells with long, hairlike processes that stained positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and histopathological findings showing cells with long hair-like processes positive for GFAP are suggestive of pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytoma is a benign (grade I) astrocytoma that typi­cally occurs in children and young adults. It is usually located in the cerebellum, optic nerves, brainstem and occasionally in the cerebral hemispheres.

Clinically, any brain tumour can present with some general symptoms like headaches, gait disturbances, and cognitive and personality changes. These symptoms may be a result of increased intracranial pressure due to tumour enlargement or edema which may result in hydrocephalus. Seizures usually occur in cases of metastasis. 

The imaging method of choice is cranial MRI with gadolinium contrast administration. It reveals a cystic and well-demarcated mass. The tumour is composed of bipolar cells with long, thin hair-like processes that are glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)-positive and form dense fibrillary meshwork. Rosenthal fibres (eosinophilic corkscrew-shaped inclusions) and eosinophilic granular bodies (mulberry-like inclusions) are characteristic findings. It has biphasic architecture, with both loose microcystic and compact fibrillary areas.

These tumours grow very slowly with limited brain invasion and can be treated by resection alone. The image below shows the histopathology of pilocytic astrocytoma, with characteristic bipolar cells with long hair-like processes.

 

Other options:

  • Option B: Hemangioblastoma is a fluid-filled cystic lesion that typically arises in the cerebellum and in the retina. It may be associated with polycythemia and von Hippel-Lindau disease.
  • Option C: Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumour occurring exclusively in the cerebellum. Rapid growth may occlude the flow of CSF, leading to hydrocephalus.
  • Option D: Ependymoma arises in proximity to the ependyma-lined ventricular system, typically on the floor of the fourth ventricle. 

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

Most common primary CNS tumor - glioma > meningioma

Most common primary CNS tumor in children - pilocytic astrocytoma

Most common primary CNS tumor in adults - astrocytoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in children - medulloblastoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in adults - glioblastoma

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with dry, scaly skin all over his body since childhood, as shown in the image. Which of the following findings will be seen on examination of the hands?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image show ichthyosis vulgaris, which is associated with findings of accentuated palmar creases on examination of the hands.

Ichthyosis vulgaris is an autosomal dominant condition that occurs due to mutation of filaggrin protein which results in impaired epidermal barrier formation and reduction of natural moisturizing factors which help in hydration of stratum corneum. 

Clinically they present with light grey scales involving extensor surfaces of extremities and the trunk, groin, and flexures are always spared. It is associated with:

  • Keratosis pilaris (hair follicle keratinization defect)
  • Hyperlinear palms (accentuated palmar creases)
  • Keratosis follicularis
  • Atopic eczema

Histology reveals orthohyperkeratosis with a decreased or absent granular layer.

Other options: 

Option A: Fibroplasia of subcutaneous palmar tissue is seen in Dupuytren's contracture.

Option C: Palmar erythema is seen in hyperestrogenic conditions such as cirrhosis of the liver due to dilation of cutaneous blood vessels.

Option D: Acanthosis palmaris or tripe palms, is a condition characterized by enhanced dermatoglyphics and thickened velvety palms. It is associated with bronchial carcinoma, genitourinary tumors, and breast cancer.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old child suffered a cut on his hand while playing. An anxious mother brought him to the hospital when she noticed that the bleeding from the wound did not stop even after half an hour. Lab investigation reports are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Platelet count- normal
Fibrinogen levels- normal
Prothrombin time- normal
Activated partial thromboplastin time- prolonged
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of profuse bleeding from minor wounds, prolonged APTT, with normal PT and platelet count suggests Von Willebrand disease as the most probable diagnosis.

Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder which occurs due to deficiency of or defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is stored in endothelial cells and in platelet Weibel-Palade bodies. It has two important functions:

  • Adhesion of the platelets to injured subendothelium
  • Carrier protein for factor VIII and preventing its degradation

Clinical features include spontaneous bleeding from mucous membranes (epistaxis), excessive bleeding from wounds, or menorrhagia, after dental extractions and surgeries including tonsillectomies. Most individuals are asymptomatic otherwise. Type 3 VWD is the most severe form and presents with symptoms like joint bleeds, similar to those seen in mild hemophilia.

Diagnosis

  • Normal platelet count
  • Prolonged BT
  • Normal PT
  • Prolonged aPTT

Factor VIII is found bound to the Von-Willebrand factor(vWF) in the blood. Deficiency of vWF results in Factor VIII deficiency and prolongation of aPTT in this disease. Prolonged BT is due to abnormal platelet-mediated hemostasis.

Classification

Three types are recognized, with phenotypic variations:

Type 1 and type 3 von Willebrand disease are associated with quantitative defects in vWF.

Type 1 is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a mild to moderate vWF deficiency, accounting for about 70% of all cases. 

Type 3 disease is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting in little to no vWF synthesis. Because vWF stabilizes factor VIII in the circulation, factor VIII levels are also reduced in type 3 disease and the associated bleeding disorder is often severe.

Type 2 von Willebrand disease is characterized by qualitative defects in vWF. Type 2A is the most common. It is inherited as an autosomal dominant disorder.

Treatment: Desmopressin for type 1 vWD stimulates the release of vWF and Factor VIII from the endothelial stores. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) concentrates in cases of type 2 and type 3 von Willebrand disease.

Other options-

Options A and B: Bernard–Soulier syndrome and Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia are caused due to deficiency of Gp Ib-IX receptor and deficiency Gp IIb/IIIa receptor respectively. In both these conditions, PTT is normal, with only an increase in bleeding time.

Option C: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is characterized by the pentad of fever, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, abnormal renal function, and central nervous system (CNS). Occurs due to deficiency of ADAMTS13.

questions.text: What is the DNA damage caused by UV radiation that is corrected by nucleotide excision repair?
questions.solution:
The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects pyrimidine dimerization in DNA (mostly T-T) caused by UV radiation. 

Xeroderma pigmentosum is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair. There is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

Other options:

Option A: Base alteration is corrected by base excision repair.

Option B: Double-strand breaks are caused by ionizing radiation and are corrected by nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ).

Option C: Mismatched bases are corrected by mismatch repair.

questions.text:
A patient presented the clinical finding shown in the image. His lipid profile showed serum cholesterol levels to be 283 mg/dL and serum LDL to be 202 mg/dL. His triglyceride levels are found to be within normal limits. What is most likely defective in this patient?

LDL: Low density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas and elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and elevated serum cholesterol points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia( type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia). This is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors.

This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk to develop atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Features of FH: 

  • Painful polyarthritis and tendinitis are common.
  • Physical findings seen are corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas over the Achilles tendon and the dorsum of the hands. Xanthomas are tumorous masses produced by foamy cell clusters (lipid-laden macrophages) found in the connective tissue of the skin and in tendons.

Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with 

  • LDL >190 mg/dl, 
  • Family history of hypercholesterolemia and/or
  • Premature coronary artery disease.

Treatment includes lifestyle changes, restriction of a fatty diet, and pharmacotherapy with statins in heterozygous FH patients.

Recent drugs for specific treatment of homozygous FH are:

  • Lomitapide, a microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) inhibitor, and
  • Mipomersen, an antisense oligonucleotide against apoB.

 A plain lateral radiograph of both ankles shows bilateral symmetrical swellings (arrows) superior to the calcaneum.

Other options

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. There is an increased risk of atherosclerosis.

The image below shows enlarged yellow-orange colored tonsils in Tangier's disease.

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes type I hyperlipoproteinemia due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk of coronary disease. Instead, patients have an increased risk of acute pancreatitis. This is due to very high triglyceride levels. It can also cause a milky appearance of plasma.

Option D: Acid lipase deficiency can lead to Wolman's disease which is a lysosomal storage disease. Pathognomic feature of this condition is adrenal calcification. So patients generally present with adrenal insufficiency and are neonates.

questions.text: A patient with sepsis was transferred to another hospital. Airing and sunning of his room and furniture were done by the hospital staff after the patient left. Which of the following methods was used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, terminal cleaning is used as a cleaning method.

Terminal cleaning is the process of airing and sunning the rooms, furniture, and bedding of a patient who has died or has been shifted to another hospital or after cessation of isolation. The room is cleaned with a detergent or enzyme cleaner by the hospital staff so that a new patient can be admitted to that room. Currently, this method is used in place of terminal disinfection and is considered adequate. 

Routine cleaning is the cleaning of inpatient areas while the patient is staying in the hospital. This aims to provide a visibly clean environment and reduce microbial contamination.

Types of disinfection are:

  • Terminal disinfection is the application of disinfection measures after the patient has died or has been shifted to another hospital or after cessation of isolation. It is rarely done now and has been replaced by terminal cleaning.
  • Concurrent disinfection is the application of disinfection methods after the discharge of infectious material from the body of an infected person or soiling.
  • Precurrent/prophylactic disinfection is the application of preventive measures like pasteurization of milk, chlorination of water, and handwashing.

Disinfection refers to the thermal or chemical destruction of the most recognized pathogenic microorganisms, but not necessarily all microbial forms like bacterial spores.

Cleaning refers to the removal of adherent visible debris from the surfaces, instruments and equipment by a manual or mechanical process to render it safe from further decontamination.

Sodium hypochlorite(0.5-5%) is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. Hydrogen peroxide can be used for disinfection or sterilization which has largely replaced fumigation. It is also used in plasma sterilization.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with yellowish discoloration of the eyes and abdominal pain. On examination, there is tender hepatomegaly. Histopathological examination of the liver revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies in hepatocytes composed of intermediate filaments. Identify the inclusion bodies.
questions.solution:
Mallory hyaline bodies are the inclusion bodies in hepatocytes present in this patient.

The clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic presenting with jaundice, abdominal pain, and tender hepatomegaly is suggestive of alcoholic hepatitis. In this condition, there are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions called Mallory Denk bodies and they contain intermediate filaments. 

The liver undergoes inflammation and fibrosis in alcoholic hepatitis. This leads to injured and swollen hepatocytes with cleared-out cytoplasm and cytoskeletal damage. These hepatocytes are called ballooned hepatocytes. When the cytoskeletal damage is extensive, there is the formation of Mallory Denk/ Mallory hyaline bodies. These are remnants of partially degraded intermediate filaments and are composed of keratin 8 and keratin 18.

Mallory hyaline bodies are seen in:

  • Alcoholic steatohepatitis
  • Wilson disease
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis(NASH)
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma

The given image shows intracytoplasmic eosinophilic Mallory bodies. 

Other options:

Option B- Hepatocyte rosettes are seen in autoimmune hepatitis where the regenerated hepatocytes are arranged in the circular fashion in the form of rosettes around the dilated canaliculus. 

Option C- Councilman bodies are seen in yellow fever. They are apoptotic hepatocytes that are deeply eosinophilic stained. In other conditions like acute and chronic hepatitis, these are called acidophil bodies.

The given image shows the Councilman bodies in hepatocytes.

Option D- Ground glass hepatocytes are seen in chronic hepatitis B due to swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum of the swollen hepatocytes and filling with HbsAg.

The given image shows the ground glass hepatocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of tractional retinal detachment?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of tractional retinal detachment is proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

Retinal detachment is the separation of the neurosensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). Retinal detachment is classified into the following types

  • Rhegmatogenous/primary retinal detachment
  • Tractional
  • Exudative

Tractional RD occurs when the vitreous has an abnormally strong attachment to the retina. With vitreous liquefaction and subsequent contraction, the retina is pulled away from the retinal pigment epithelium without a retinal break.

Causes include proliferative diabetic retinopathy, retinopathy of prematurity, and Eales' disease.

Characteristic signs of tractional RD include a concave configuration of the detached retina with no breaks seen.

questions.text: A farmer while working in the field had a minor cut injury to the right foot. Following this, he developed rashes in the limbs. A few days later he presents with a dry unproductive cough. Laboratory investigations showed eosinophilia and chest X-ray showed patchy pneumonitis. All of the following parasites can be responsible for this condition, except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenarios of a farmer developing a dry unproductive cough following a cut in the foot, along with eosinophilia, and chest X-ray showing patchy pneumonitis is suggestive of Loeffler’s syndrome. Of the listed parasites, Enterobius vermicularis does not cause Loeffler’s syndrome. 

Development of rash after injury indicates skin penetration by larvae of the hookworms Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus, and the roundworm Strongyloides stercoralis. After penetrating the skin, larvae migrate within a day or two via the bloodstream into the lungs. When passing through the lungs, the patient may develop Loeffler syndrome.

Loeffler's syndrome is a disease in which eosinophils accumulate in the lung in response to a parasitic infection. It is associated with pneumonia characterized by dry cough, low-grade fever, wheezing, urticaria, and eosinophilia.

Parasites causing Loeffler’s syndrome:

  • Migrating larva of
    • Strongyloides stercoralis
    • Hookworms (Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus)
    • Ascaris 
  • Echinococcus granulosus
  • Cryptosporidium parvum
  • Eggs of Paragonimus westermani
  • Entamoeba histolytica

questions.text: An 8-month-old child was brought for evaluation after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures lasting for 5 minutes. The examination is positive for a fever of 103°F and otitis media. Neurological findings are normal.  Which of the following factors increases the risk of recurrence of this condition?

choices.text: High serum sodium at the time of presentation

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an 8-month-old child presenting with generalized tonic-clonic seizures lasting for 5 minutes along with high-grade fever and otitis media in a neurologically healthy state suggests febrile seizure. The age of the child less than 1 year increases its risk of recurrence. 

Febrile seizures occur in children of the age of 6-60 months with a high-grade fever of 38°C (100.4 F) or higher without underlying CNS infections, metabolic abnormality, or prior afebrile seizures.

Risk factors for febrile seizures:

Major Minor
Age < 1 year Family history of epilepsy or febrile seizures
Duration of fever < 24 hours Complex febrile seizure (Option A)
Fever range: 38-39°C (100.4-102.2°F) Male gender (Option B)
  Lower serum sodium levels at the time of presentation (Option D)

Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months of age to exclude meningitis. Electroencephalogram and neuroimaging are advised for children with suspected epilepsy or neurological abnormalities.

Acute treatment of febrile seizures includes lorazepam and midazolam for seizures lasting more than 5 minutes. Rectal diazepam is prescribed to use at home as rescue medication if febrile seizures last more than 5 minutes. The use of antipyretics can decrease the discomfort of the child but does not reduce the risk of having a recurrent febrile seizure.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a history of liver cirrhosis presents with increasing shortness of breath on exertion. His echocardiogram shows evidence of pulmonary hypertension. Which of the following findings would be seen in this condition?

PVR: Pulmonary vascular resistance

PCWP: Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of portopulmonary hypertension, which is pulmonary arterial hypertension in patients with portal hypertension from cirrhosis. It is characterized by elevated pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) and normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP). 

Portal hypertension in cirrhosis results in the production of substances causing vascular remodeling and vasoconstriction in pulmonary arterioles causing elevation of pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR). However, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP), which reflects left atrial pressure, remains normal.

Patients can be asymptomatic initially but may progress to dyspnea on exertion and fatigue. Diagnosis involves echocardiogram findings suggestive of elevated pulmonary artery pressure, later confirmed by right heart catheterization demonstrating elevated mean pulmonary artery pressure and pulmonary vascular resistance, with normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. Prognosis is poor, but liver transplantation following effective reduction of pulmonary artery pressure with vasodilators can be beneficial.

questions.text: A post-stapedectomy patient complains of sudden onset of vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating deafness. The symptoms aggravate on performing Valsalva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient suddenly developing vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating deafness post-stapedectomy, and worsening of symptoms with Valsalva is suggestive of perilymph fistula. 

A perilymph fistula is an abnormal connection between the inner and middle ear, leading to the leakage of perilymph from the cochlea or vestibule. This typically happens through the round or oval window. It can be caused by iatrogenic factors (eg. post-stapedectomy or ear surgery with stapes dislocation), as well as by head trauma and inner ear injuries resulting from forceful Valsalva maneuvers or barotrauma.

Patients with perilymph fistula typically present with intermittent vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in the ear. Symptoms can be triggered by the fistula test (intermittent pressure over the tragus) and the Valsalva maneuver. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of the temporal bone is used for diagnosis.

Other options:

Option A: Hemotympanum is the presence of blood in the middle ear. It can present with hearing loss, pain, and a feeling of fullness inside the ear. It is commonly associated with temporal bone fractures. 

Option C: Meniere disease can also present with vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating deafness. However, an iatrogenic history of post-stapedectomy makes perilymph fistula the more likely diagnosis. 

Option D: Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome results from an abnormal connection between the semicircular canal and the brain. It occurs due to an abnormal thinness or incomplete closure of the bony canals in the inner ear. Patients can present with vertigo, tinnitus, autophony, and hearing loss. The iatrogenic history makes it unlikely in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following inhibitors is incorrectly matched with the corresponding enzyme?
questions.solution:
Arsenite inhibits alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in the TCA cycle. Arsenate inhibits phosphoglycerate kinase in glycolysis. 

Inhibitors of glycolytic enzymes are :

  • Iodoacetate: It inhibits glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. Thus conversion of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate to 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate is inhibited.
  • Arsenate: It inhibits phosphoglycerate kinase. It converts 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate to 3 phosphoglycerate. Arsenite competes with inorganic phosphate (Pi) in this reaction to give 1-arseno-3-phosphoglycerate which undergoes spontaneous hydrolysis to 3-phosphoglycerate without forming ATP.
  • Sodium fluoride (NaF):  It inhibits the enolase enzyme which is responsible for the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate.

Inhibitors of TCA cycle:

  • Arsenite: It inhibits Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. Thus conversion of alpha-ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA is inhibited.
  • Malonate: It inhibits Succinate dehydrogenase. Thus the conversion of succinate to fumarate is inhibited.
  • Fluoroacetate: It inhibits aconitase. Thus conversion of citrate to aconitate is inhibited.
