questions.text: A man is brought to the emergency with a head injury following a motorcycle accident.  His wife reports he was unconscious for around 5 minutes and vomited thrice. On examination, he is drowsy with a fixed and dilated pupil. CT scan of the head revealed a lenticular hemorrhage. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery

questions.solution:
The given scenario of a man with a head injury, unconsciousness, vomiting, dilated and fixed pupils, and the CT finding of a lenticular hemorrhage is characteristic of an extradural or epidural hemorrhage. The most likely cause is a rupture of the middle meningeal artery.

Epidural hemorrhage or hematoma is an intracranial hemorrhage in which the hemorrhage is between the dura and the skull. It classically occurs due to a tear of the middle meningeal artery following a fracture of the temporal bone. 

Clinically, patients with an extradural hemorrhage typically present with an initial transient loss of consciousness. A lucid interval is then seen, which may be minutes to hours during which the patient usually presents. Neurological deterioration then occurs following the lucid interval as the hematoma expands. Reduced consciousness, pupillary dilatation, and hemiparesis can be seen. 

CT scan shows a characteristic hyperdense biconvex or lenticular-shaped hematoma. Management is by surgical evacuation of the hematoma or by ligation of the damaged middle meningeal artery. 

Other options:

Option B: Shearing of the bridging veins is seen in chronic subdural hemorrhage (SDH). SDH is a type of intracranial hemorrhage that occurs between the dura and the arachnoid and appears as a crescentic clot on a CT scan. Symptoms like drowsiness, headache, confusion, or mild hemiparesis occur days or weeks after the injury.

Options C and D: Rupture of small cortical arteries or veins due to trauma and the rupture of saccular aneurysms can be seen in subarachnoid hemorrhage. Clinically, patients present with sudden and severe headaches, commonly called thunderclap headaches. It can be associated with seizures, unresponsiveness, and vomiting. The CT scan shows blood in basal cisterns and rounded lesions suggest aneurysms.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a recent history of Colles fracture treated with cast application presents with swelling and tenderness of the wrist and finger joints. Examination of the hand reveals altered temperature sensitivity, allodynia, and marbling of the skin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A patient with symptoms of swelling and tenderness of the wrist and finger joints, along with altered temperature sensitivity, allodynia, and marbling of skin over the hand is suggestive of Sudeck's atrophy. 

Sudeck's atrophy or complex regional pain syndrome or reflex sympathetic atrophy is an early complication of Colles fracture, which may lead to swelling and tenderness of the wrist and finger joints, and vasomotor changes such as marbling of the skin, altered sweating, and temperature sensitivity.  These clinical symptoms can be reduced by finger exercises, avoiding tight dressings, and taking high doses of vitamin C. 

X-rays classically show spotty or patchy rarefaction. Earlier recognition and treatment initiation makes the prognosis relatively better. Long-term physiotherapy together with analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs form the mainstay of treatment. Ganglion blockers in resistant cases can improve the condition.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of vomiting, abdominal distension, and obstipation. On examination, high-pitched bowel sounds were heard. An  X-ray erect abdomen is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an X-ray showing gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia) and multiple air-fluid levels indicating small bowel obstruction is suggestive of gallstone ileus.

Gallstone ileus is a condition caused by the obstruction of the intestinal lumen by a gallstone, leading to a mechanical blockage. Big gallstones will not be able to pass through the normal cystic duct. This causes inflammation of the gallbladder and results in pressure necrosis. This in turn leads to biliary-enteric fistula formation. The condition is characterized by a triad of features known as Rigler’s triad. It comprises small bowel obstruction, pneumobilia, and atypical mineral shadow on the abdominal radiographs (ectopic gall stone).

Penumobilia refers to the presence of air within the biliary tree which suggest that there is an abnormal communication between the intestine and the biliary tract. Other conditions associated with pneumobilia include incompetent sphincter of Oddi and biliary-enteric anastomosis.

CT scan is helpful in the diagnosis.

Gall stone ileus is managed by

  • Milking the stone proximally away from the site of impaction
  • Crushing the stone
  • Removal of the stone.\

The surgical procedures that can be performed are: simple enterolithotomy, enterolithotomy, cholecystectomy, and fistula closure (one-stage procedure) and enterolithotomy with cholecystectomy performed later (two-stage procedure).

Given below is a plain X-ray of the erect abdomen showing air in the biliary tract (pneumobilia).

Option A: Cecal volvulus presents with features of obstruction. Ischaemia can be seen and the midline or a left-sided swelling can be present. On radiograph, it will show a dilated and air-filled cecum. Other clinical features such as dilated small bowel and absence of gas in the distal colon are seen. 

Option B: In large bowel obstruction, the presence of haustrations is a feature. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

Option C: Crohn's disease on small bowel enema shows narrowing of involved areas and is often irregular. Features include colicky postprandial abdominal pain, diarrhea, and palpable and tender right iliac fossa mass. Other less common features like fever, anemia and weight loss can be seen.

questions.text: As an epidemiologist, you are assigned to calculate an index for the recent transmission of malaria in your locality. Which of the following is the most sensitive index, and for how many years will you calculate this to consider the area free of malaria transmission?
questions.solution:
The infant parasite rate is regarded as the most sensitive index for recent transmission of malaria in a locality and the transmission is considered absent if the infant parasite rate is zero for 3 consecutive years in a locality (even though the Anopheline vectors responsible for the previous transmission may remain).

It is defined as the % of infants showing malarial parasites in their blood films.

The slide positivity rate represents the proportion of slides that test positive for malarial parasites, regardless of the specific species. It provides information on the trend of malaria transmission.

questions.text: Which of the following non-opioid pain medications is associated with significant weight loss as a side effect?
questions.solution:
Topiramate, a non-opioid pain medication, is associated with significant weight loss of up to 7% as a side effect.

Topiramate has multiple mechanisms of action like blocking voltage-sensitive sodium channels, potentiating GABA inhibitory action, blocking voltage-sensitive calcium channels, inhibiting subtypes of glutamate receptors (non-MDA receptors) and a weak carbonic anhydrase inhibitor.

As a side effect, topiramate can cause significant weight loss (up to 7%), which may be advantageous for certain patient groups with chronic pain conditions. At 400 mg or more per day, topiramate reduces body weight, enhances sleep quality, and lessens neuropathic pain.

It is FDA-approved for generalized tonic-clonic seizures, Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and migraine prevention and is used off-label as an adjunct therapy for chronic weight management.

Other options:

Option A: Lamotrigine acts by blocking both sodium and calcium channels. It is effective in treating trigeminal neuralgia, HIV neuropathy-related pain, and neuralgia following nerve section. Side effects mainly include mild dizziness, somnolence, nausea, and constipation. 10% of patients may develop rashes. It is not associated with weight loss.

Option C: Oxcarbazepine, an analogue of carbamazepine, acts as a sodium channel blocker and stabilizes neuronal membranes. It has been used to treat intractable trigeminal neuralgia refractory to other anticonvulsants. The most frequent side effects include dizziness, drowsiness, hypotension, and asymptomatic mild hyponatremia. It is not associated with weight loss.

Option D: Mexiletine, an oral lidocaine analogue, is used to treat painful diabetic neuropathy that is not responsive to other forms of treatment. Phantom pain and pain following spinal cord injury have both been treated with mexiletine. It is not associated with weight loss.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman was diagnosed with a twin pregnancy at 12 weeks of gestation. She has a 3-year-old child who was born at term and also had 1 first trimester abortion previously. Which of the given options correctly determines her obstetric score?
questions.solution:
The obstetric score according to the GPAL system is G3P1A1L1.

The obstetric score is used to summarize the past obstetric history of a pregnant woman.

GPAL system - 

  • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one.
  • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability, which is 28 weeks in India.
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths.
    • The current pregnancy is not included.
    • Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. 
  • A - Abortion - the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason before 20 weeks of gestation. This includes induced abortions, spontaneous miscarriages, ectopic or molar pregnancy.
  • L - Living children at present.

Therefore in this patient,

  • G - 3 (The patient has 3 pregnancies in total, including the present pregnancy).
  • P - 1 (The patient has 1 pregnancy that crossed 28 weeks, excluding the present pregnancy).
  • A - 1 (The patient has 1 abortion).
  • L - 1 (The patient has 1 living child currently).

GTPAL system is also used which is as follows -

  • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one.
  • T - Term delivery, any delivery that happens at or beyond 37 weeks.
  • P - Preterm delivery, number of deliveries that happen between 20 to 36 weeks+6 days. Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and term/preterm.
  • A - Abortion - any pregnancy loss that occurs before 20 weeks.
  • L - Living children at present.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs promote weight loss by increasing satiety?
questions.solution:
Lorcaserin acts as an agonist on 5HT2C receptor and causes weight loss by increasing satiety and decreasing food consumption.

Other options:

  • Option 1 : Orlistat acts in the gastrointestinal system inhibiting intestinal lipase and hence reducing fat absorption.
  • Option 3 : Alosetron acts on 5HT3 receptor and act as an antiemetic.
  • Option 4 : Zolmitriptan acts on 5HT1B/1D and is used in the treatment of migraine.

questions.text:
A male patient with a history of hepatitis B infection for a year presents with worsening confusion for 2 days and yellowing of the eyes for the past 5 days. Examination reveals flapping tremors and ascites. The lab findings are given below. Which of the following is the best step in the management of this patient?

Prothrombin time: 30 sec

HBsAg: Positive

HDV RNA: Positive

Serum bilirubin: 10 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with ascites, encephalopathy, jaundice and prolonged prothrombin time (PT) in the setting of superinfection with hepatitis D virus is suggestive of fulminant hepatic failure. A liver transplant is the best step in the management of this patient.

Fulminant hepatitis /massive hepatic necrosis is a rare complication of viral hepatitis. It is seen primarily in hepatitis B, D, and E. Hepatitis B accounts for more than half of fulminant cases of viral hepatitis and can be associated with HDV infection and underlying chronic hepatitis C. Hepatitis E causes fulminant hepatitis in pregnant women.

This patient's history with clinical signs of confusion along with jaundice and ascites suggests hepatic failure with encephalopathy. The liver is usually shrunken. Cerebral edema is commonly seen. Brainstem compression, gastrointestinal bleeding, sepsis, respiratory failure, cardiovascular collapse, and renal failure are complications that can be fatal. 

The mortality rate is extremely high but patients who survive may have a complete recovery. Liver transplantation is lifesaving in affected patients.

Other Options:

Option A: N-acetylcysteine therapy is indicated in acetaminophen overdose. 

Option B: Glucocorticoid therapy is the mainstay of management in autoimmune hepatitis. 

Option C: Parenteral administration of vitamin K will not correct prolonged prothrombin time in cases of severe hepatocellular injury,

questions.text: A physiologist studies normal pressure-volume changes during the cardiac cycle using the graph shown below. The occurrence of the first heart sound (S1)  would correspond to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Mitral valve closure is responsible for S1 heart sound, which corresponds to point B; it marks the beginning of the isovolumetric contraction phase.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop:

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

  • In the given diagram, the period of filling lasts from point A to point B.
  • At point A, the volume of blood present in the left ventricle is the end-systolic volume, which corresponds to about 50 mL. It is at this point that the mitral valve opens and the venous blood flows into the left ventricle from the left atrium.
  • At point B—the end of the period of filling—the amount of blood present in the left ventricle is called the end-diastolic volume, which corresponds to about 120 mL. This is the point at which the mitral valve closes.
  • Diastolic pressure rises to about 5 to 7 mmHg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

  • In the given diagram, the period of isovolumic contraction lasts from point B to point C.
  • A point B, the mitral valve closes and the volume of the ventricle does not change as all the valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle continues to rise.
  • At point C, the ventricular pressure increases to become equal to the pressure in the aorta (80 mmHg), and then, the aortic valve opens.

Phase III: Period of ejection

  • In the given diagram, the period of ejection lasts from point C to point D.
  • At point C, the aortic valve opens and the volume of the ventricle decreases as the blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.
  • The systolic pressure continues to rise as the ventricle contracts.
  • At point D, the aortic valve closes.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

  • In the given diagram, the period of isovolumic relaxation lasts from point D to point A.
  • At point D, the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. 
  • This decrease in intraventricular pressure occurs without any change in volume.
  • At point A, the ventricle now has an end-systolic volume of 50 mL of blood similar to the beginning of the cycle.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman presents with irregular cycles and an inability to conceive. On examination, she has facial acne and dense black hair on her upper lip. The ultrasound image of her ovaries is given below. Which of the following is not an endocrinal change seen in her?

AMH: Anti-Mullerian hormone
LH: Luteinizing hormone
FSH: Follicle stimulating hormone
SHBG: Steroid hormone binding globulin
questions.solution:
The ultrasound shows multiple cysts in the ovaries, and along with the given clinical symptoms, it suggests a diagnosis of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The endocrinal change not present in PCOS is increased steroid hormone–binding globulin (SHBG) levels.

Insulin is increased in PCOS due to insulin resistance. This increase in insulin suppresses SHBG synthesis. Apart from this, increased levels of androgens, cortisol, progestins, and growth hormone also suppress SHBG.

Other endocrinal changes seen in PCOS are as follows:

  • Increased LH due to altered gonadotrophin-releasing hormone (GnRH) pulsatility
  • Increased LH: FSH ratio (>2:1) due to an increase in LH 
  • Increased androgens such as DHEAS, testosterone, and androstenedione
  • Increased AMH due to an increase in the number of follicles
  • Decreased SHBG due to suppression by insulin
  • Increased insulin

PCOS is characterized by multiple small cysts in the ovaries usually of a diameter of 2–9 mm.

The Rotterdam criteria for the diagnosis of PCOS is the presence of two out of the following three:

  • Oligo and/or anovulation
  • Clinical and/or biochemical signs of hyperandrogenism
  • Polycystic ovaries by ultrasound - ≧12 follicles in either ovary measuring 2-9 mm and/or ovarian volume > 10mL

questions.text:
Which electron microscopic finding is incorrectly matched with the associated glomerular disease?

MPGN: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
questions.solution:
MPGN type II has dense deposits that are intramembranous and subendothelial deposits are generally absent. Subendothelial deposits are generally seen in MPGN type I.

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is immune-mediated glomerulonephritis characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) with mesangio-proliferative changes.

Type I MPGN is commonly associated with persistent hepatitis C infections, autoimmune diseases like SLE or cryoglobulinemia, or neoplastic diseases of the lung, breast, and ovary.

On light microscopy, type I MPGN will show the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. At some points, the GBM splits showing the tram track appearance. Electron microscopy will show the presence of subendothelial deposits. Immunofluorescence shows IgG and C3 and early complement components(C1q and C4) deposited in a granular pattern.

Type II and type III are mediated by the complement pathways. Type II MPGN can also have GBM thickening and splitting. The glomerular tuft has a lobular appearance. On electron microscopy, it shows intramembranous dense deposits. Subendothelial deposits are generally absent. Immunofluorescence shows C3 deposition in irregular granular or linear foci in the basement membranes on either side but not within the dense deposits.

Type III MPGN is rare and shows focal mesangial proliferation.

Other options:

Option A: Immunofluorescence of membraneous nephropathy demonstrates that the granular deposits contain both immunoglobulins and complement. Electron microscopy will show the presence of subepithelial deposits.

Option C: Lupus nephritis shows immunofluorescence staining of the kidney biopsy specimen shows positive staining for fibrinogen, IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, λ chain, and k light chain. This is known as a full-house effect. Electron microscopy will show the presence of subendothelial deposits 

Option D: Henoch Schonlein Purpura is the most common small vessel vasculitis of childhood. It is characterized by purpuric rash and is commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain. It is mediated by IgA deposition in glomeruli. Electron microscopy will show the presence of mesangial deposits.

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling increases in size on coughing and on performing Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the swelling, a gurgling sound is heard. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hoarseness of voice, cough, neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/ Valsalva maneuver, and a gurgling sound heard on pressing the swelling is suggestive of laryngocele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling in the neck due to dilatation of the saccule. It is more commonly seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to a raised transglottic air pressure in these people. It can be classified into internal, external, or combined types of laryngocele.

  • Internal laryngocele is limited within the larynx and appears as distension of the false cord and aryepiglottic fold
  • External laryngocele has a distended saccule that herniates through the thyrohyoid membrane and appears as a swelling in the neck
  • Combined or mixed laryngocele has both internal and external laryngoceles as its components

Given below is a diagrammatic representation of laryngocele:

Laryngocele presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and airway obstruction (if large). External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck that increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the neck swelling, a gurgling sound is heard, indicating a positive Bryce's sign. Adult laryngoceles can be associated with carcinoma.

Diagnosis is based on an indirect laryngoscopy and CT scan. Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and external laryngocele is managed by a surgical excision through an external neck incision.

Other options:

Option A: Branchial cyst develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft. It presents as a swelling in the neck beneath the anterior border of the upper third of the sternomastoid muscle. It is smooth, soft, fluctuant, and often transilluminate. The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst.

Option C: Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum in which the pharyngeal mucosa is herniated through the Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between the 2 parts of the inferior constrictor). It usually occurs due to the uncoordinated contraction or the spasm of the cricopharyngeal sphincter during deglutition. Dysphagia is the predominant feature with a gurgling sound produced on swallowing.

The below image shows Zenker's diverticulum on barium swallow:

Option D: Cystic hygroma occurs due to obstruction of the jugular lymph sac. It is most commonly seen in the posterior triangle of the neck. More than 90% of the cases occur before the age of 2 years. It can result in stridor, respiratory difficulty, or feeding problems. It is partially compressible and brilliantly transilluminant.

questions.text: According to the Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA), what colour sticker will be placed on the Mother and Child Protection (MCP) Card of a primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation, who presents with pedal edema and a blood pressure value of 150/100 mmHg?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a primigravida presenting with elevated blood pressure ( SBP ≥ 140 mmHg and DBP ≥ 90 mmHg ) along with pedal edema is suggestive of pregnancy-induced hypertension and a blue sticker will be placed on this patient's MCP card according to the PMSMA.

Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA) program aims to provide assured, comprehensive, and quality antenatal care, free of cost, to all pregnant women on the 9th of every month. This is undertaken as part of the Reproductive, Maternal, Neonatal, Child Plus Adolescent Health (RMNCH+A) strategy.

Under PMSMA, a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check-up in her second or third trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, on the 9th of every month.

After routine examination, pregnant women are categorized according to the risk factors, and different colored stickers are given as follows:

  • Green- For women with no detected risk factor
  • Red- For women with detected risk factor
  • Blue- for women with pregnancy-induced hypertension
  • Yellow- pregnancy with co-morbid conditions such as diabetes, hypothyroidism, STIs

questions.text: A 55-year-old man was trapped under a 40-meter landslide for 7 hours. Upon admission to the ER, his left leg was painful as shown in the image below and his renal parameters were deranged. Which of the following is not done in treating this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient trapped in a landslide with a painful leg and deranged renal parameters is suggestive of crush syndrome. In these patients, an early fasciotomy is preferred over a late fasciotomy as it can decompress muscle compartments and thereby reduce the need for amputation. 

A late fasciotomy can lead to a massive release of myoglobin and also lead to infection of the dead tissue. It is best not to perform fasciotomy where the patient has been entrapped for more than 12 hours as muscles of the compartment are likely to be dead and can lead to massive release of vasoactive mediators during debridement.

Crush syndrome occurs due to prolonged compression of a limb leading to myonecrosis and decreased perfusion. When the limb is freed, vasoactive mediators and myoglobin are released. There is associated renal vasoconstriction and ischemia which can lead to renal failure.

Management of crush syndrome includes:

  • Aggressive fluid resuscitation, ideally until myoglobin is not detectable in urine (Option A)
  • The bladder should be catheterized to measure urine output
  • Administration of mannitol may reduce the reperfusion component (Option D) 
  • Renal hemofiltration if there is oliguria or renal failure(Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following features is seen in Chauffeur's fracture?

choices.text: Caused by forced ulnar deviation of wrist

questions.solution:
Chauffeur's fracture is the fracture of the radial styloid process. It is commonly associated with scaphoid fracture.

Chauffeur's fracture, which can happen as a result of a fall, is caused by forced radial deviation of the wrist (Option A). The fracture line is transverse or oblique (Option C), extending laterally from the articular surface of the radius. In many cases, the bone fragment remains in its original position without displacement (Option D). This injury is often accompanied by injury to the carpal ligaments, a fracture of the scaphoid bone, and a tear in the scapholunate ligament.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented to the emergency with complaints of severe pain associated with sweating and giddiness. His JVP is elevated. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following drugs are a part of his therapeutic plan?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the ECG showing ST-segment elevation in Leads II, III, and aVF are suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Out of the options listed, IV fluids, aspirin, and statins are the only drugs safe to use in this condition. 

This patient's elevated jugular venous pressure indicates a probable right ventricular dysfunction secondary to the inferior wall MI. The efficient management in this situation would be a brisk administration of fluids to combat the cardiogenic shock that would set in, if untreated. Additionally, he should be given the other drugs given in the routine management of an inferior wall MI which are aspirin and statins.

Morphine and nitrates are contraindicated in an inferior wall MI due to the risk of further impairing the right ventricular preload. Beta blockers are generally not recommended either, due to the risk of the MI involving the AV node. Beta blockers can block the AV node which can lead to further AV blocks. 

Inferior wall MI mainly occurs due to blockage of the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery. While anterior wall infarction shows sympathetic nervous system hyperactivity (tachycardia and hypertension), the inferior wall MI shows parasympathetic hyperactivity (bradycardia and hypotension).

In the setting of inferior wall infarction, signs of cardiogenic shock should prompt the suspicion of a right ventricular infarction. And the same can be evidenced by ST elevation in the right precordial leads (V4R, V5R, V6R). The diagnosis of right ventricular MI is suspected in patients with inferior-wall MI, clear lung fields (no added sounds on auscultation), and shock. If a right ventricular infarction is suspected, avoid nitrates and increase volume to ensure adequate preload. The right ventricle has less myocardium than the left and relies on adequate preload to function properly. If the right ventricle is damaged, preload reduction from nitrates may result in significant hypotension.

NOTE: Recent trials have shown that ivabradine can be used instead of beta blockers in inferior wall infarctions.

questions.text:
A patient with DIC develops skin necrosis on his arms and back. He is diagnosed to have purpura fulminans. Which of the following is likely associated with this condition?

DIC-Disseminated intravascular coagulation
questions.solution:
This patient has developed a complication of DIC known as purpura fulminans characterized by widespread skin necrosis. This condition is associated with a congenital protein C deficiency. 

This process is similar to how warfarin-mediated skin necrosis occurs. The lack of protein C leads to increased susceptibility to clotting as it is an anticoagulant factor and suppresses coagulation. 

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acquired syndrome characterized by the widespread activation of blood clotting factors within blood vessels, resulting in a loss of clotting control. The primary mechanism of DIC involves the uncontrolled generation of thrombin through multiple pathways which leads to sustained coagulation activation, the formation of fibrin, and the consumption of clotting factors and platelets.

Infections are the most frequent cause of DIC.

Laboratory investigations in DIC are

  • Decreased platelet count 
  • Prolonged PT/TT
  • Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)
  • Decreased fibrinogen
  • Elevated fibrin degradation products (D-dimers)
  • Peripheral smear: microangiopathic hemolytic anemia in DIC with schistocytes (fragmented red blood cells) 

The treatment involves platelet transfusion when platelet counts are below 10,000-20,000/μL. Replacement of fibrinogen and coagulation factors is with fresh frozen plasma (FFP) along with cryoprecipitate or fibrinogen concentrate.

In cases of low-grade DIC associated with solid tumors or acute promyelocytic leukemia low doses of continuous-infusion heparin has been effective.

questions.text: A chronic bedridden patient with spinal cord injury presents with the following finding. What is the minimum external pressure required for this ulcer to form?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and given image point toward the diagnosis of pressure sore or decubitus ulcer. The blood flow stops if external pressure exceeds the capillary occlusive pressure over 30 mmHg leading to tissue anoxia, necrosis, and ulceration.

Pressure sores can be defined as tissue necrosis with ulceration due to prolonged pressure. The common sites are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral than medial) and occiput 

The prevention and management includes:

  • Good skincare
  • Special pressure dispersion cushions or foams
  • Use of low air loss and air-fluidized beds and urinary or fecal diversion in selected cases.
  • The bed-bound patient should be turned at least every 2 hours, with the wheelchair-bound patient being taught to lift themselves off their seat for 10 seconds every 10 minutes.
  • Preoperative management of the pressure sore involves adequate debridement, and the use of vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) may help to provide a suitable wound for surgical closure
  • The aim is to fill the dead space and to provide durable sensate skin. Large skin flaps that include muscle are best and, occasionally, an intact sensory innervated area can be included (e.g. extensor fascia lata flap with the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh)

questions.text: Given below are the four causes of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) with the corresponding class of a PALM-COEIN classification. Which is incorrectly matched?
questions.solution:
Polycystic ovarian disease is an ovarian cause of abnormal uterine bleeding which comes under AUB-O, in the PALM-COEIN classification.

AUB in the reproductive age group was previously known as dysfunctional uterine bleeding, however, that term is now obsolete. AUB can be acute or chronic:

  • Acute AUB - it can start sporadically or be superimposed on chronic AUB
  • Chronic AUB - it lasts for 6 months (3 months minimum)

PALM-COEIN classification of AUB:

  • Polyp (AUB-P):
    • Endometrial polyps
    • Endocervical polyps
  • Adenomyosis (AUB-A)
  • Leiomyoma (AUB-L). Fibroids are further classified as:
    • Submucosal (SM)
    • Other (O)
  • Malignancy and hyperplasia (AUB-M) 
    • Endometrial hyperplasia 
    • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Coagulopathy (AUB-C)
    • von Willebrand's disease
    • Hemophilias
  • Ovarian causes (AUB-O)
    • PCOD
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hyperprolactinemia.  
  • Endometrial causes (AUB-E)
    • Tubercular or chlamydial endometritis 
  • Iatrogenic causes (AUB-I)
    • Intrauterine contraceptive devices
    • Anticoagulants
    • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Not yet classified (AUB-N) includes rare causes such as
    • Arteriovenous malformations 
    • Myometrial hypertrophy

questions.text: A 5-year-old child who has never received a vaccination for pertussis is brought by her parents. As per the IAP guidelines, what should you advise?

choices.text: Tdap, Td, and Td at 0, 1, and 6 months
Tdap, and Td at 0, and 6 months

questions.solution:
DTwP/DTaP at 0, 1, and 6 months is advised for catch-up vaccination in children below 7 years of age. 

DPT is a combined vaccine given for immunization against the three diseases: diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus.

Routine vaccination:

  • Three primary doses at 6, 10, and 14 weeks and two boosters at 15–18 months and 4–5 years
  • Minimum age: 6 weeks
  • The first booster (4th dose) may be administered as early as age 12 months, provided at least 6 months have elapsed since the third dose
  • DTaP or DTwP vaccine/combination may be used for the primary immunization series

 Catch-up vaccination:

questions.text: During an ophthalmological evaluation of a patient, the Schirmer's test at the end of 5 minutes revealed filter paper wetting of <10 mm. All of the following could have led to this finding, except:
questions.solution:
<10 mm of wetting at the end of 5 minutes on Schirmer's test is suggestive of dry eye disease. All of the above can lead to this finding, except dacryocystitis. 

Dry eye disease occurs as a result of inadequate tear volume and function which results In unstable tear film and ocular surface disease. The causes are: 

  • Sjögren syndrome
  • Ocular rosacea
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Follicular conjunctivitis
  • Age-related dry eye 
  • Wearing contact lenses 
  • Trachoma

Schirmer's test is used for the assessment of aqueous tear production by measuring the amount of wetting of a special filter paper(no. 41 Whatman). <10 mm of wetting after 5 minutes without anesthesia is considered abnormal. However, a single Schirmer test should not be used as the sole criterion for diagnosing dry eye. 

Dacryocystitis is the infection of the lacrimal sac caused secondary to nasolacrimal duct obstruction. The clinical features are excessive tearing (epiphora), recurrent conjunctivitis, pain, and swelling in the medial canthus. 

The image below is an illustration of a Shirmer's test being performed:


Other options: 

Option B: Vitamin A deficiency - Dry eye associated with vitamin A deficiency is called xerophthalmia. Night blindness, discomfort and loss of vision are the symptoms. Retinoic acid is the active form of vitamin A. Bitots spots which are triangular patches of foamy keratinized epithelium are seen in the conjunctiva.

The image below shows Bitots spots:


Option C: Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry mouth, dry eyes, and parotid gland enlargement. 

Option D: Ocular rosacea is a manifestation of acne rosacea which is a chronic idiopathic dermatosis. Symptoms are irritation, telegenctasia, blepharitis, etc.

  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: A patient developed generalized pruritis and swelling of the face, lips, and tongue after having dinner at a new restaurant. He also complained of difficulty in breathing. Which of the following is incorrect about the immunoglobulin causing this reaction?

choices.text: It is the only heat stable antibody
Levels are raised in helminthic infections
It does not pass the placental barrier
It has a half-life of 1-5 days

questions.solution:
This is an example of an IgE-mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction. It is also known as a type I hypersensitivity reaction. IgE immunoglobulin is the only heat-labile antibody.

The primary mediators of type 1 hypersensitivity reactions are histamine and serotonin. The secondary mediators are prostaglandins and leukotrienes. The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mild rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.

IgE:

  • Half-life: 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat-labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.
  • It does not pass the placental barrier or fix complement.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is Döhle body. Döhle bodies are patches of dilated endoplasmic reticulum seen in reactive neutrophils that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic puddles.

Döhle bodies, toxic granulations, and cytoplasmic vacuoles are some of the morphologic changes in neutrophils during sepsis, severe inflammatory disorders (eg: Kawasaki disease), and myelodysplastic syndromes.


Other options:

Option B: Russell bodies are eosinophilic, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing cytoplasmic inclusions found in a plasma cell with an excessive synthesis of immunoglobulin. They are seen in multiple myeloma.

Option A: Howell-jolly bodies are small nuclear remnants present in RBCs. Splenic macrophages are responsible for the excision of Howell-jolly bodies. Hence, they are seen in patients with asplenia and sickle cell anemia.

Option C: Heinz bodies are inclusion bodies in red blood cells composed of denatured hemoglobin. They are seen in glucose-6-phosphate deficiency.

questions.text: A patient firmly believes that his wife has been replaced by a body double with completely identical characteristics. What is the term used to describe this particular delusion?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient firmly believes that his wife has been replaced by a body double with completely identical characteristics. The term used to describe this particular delusion is Capgras syndrome.

Capgras syndrome is a type of delusion of misidentification. In this syndrome, the patients believe that a familiar person or significant other has been replaced by an imposter.

Delusions are firm, false beliefs that persist despite the presence of objective evidence and clear demonstration of their falsity.

Other options:

Option A: Folie a deux is a mental illness where two individuals share a common delusion. They may be a spouse, a child, or any other household member. 

Option C: Persecution is a delusion wherein the patient believes that plans are being made to harm them by close relatives such as a spouse, children, or parents. This delusion may lead the person to harm themselves or the alleged family members.

Option D: Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient complains of fatigue and weight loss for the past 1 year. Examination revealed massive splenomegaly. Chromosomal analysis was done and the defect is shown below. Which is the most sensitive test to detect this type of defect?
questions.solution:
The given image shows t(9:22) and BCR-ABL fusion, along with features of fatigue, weight loss, and massive splenomegaly suggesting a diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). The most sensitive investigation to detect this translocation defect is spectral karyotyping (SKY) or multicolor FISH. 

CML is a myeloproliferative neoplasm that presents as fatigue, anemia, splenomegaly, weight loss, and anorexia. The image demonstrates the Philadelphia chromosome, a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. BCR-ABL gene created by this reciprocal (9;22) (q34;q11) translocation is characteristic of CML. It is detected using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) or PCR.

Fluorescent in Situ Hybridisation (FISH) is a technique for the detection of specific genetic information on morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes. It uses DNA probes that recognize sequences specific to particular chromosomal regions. Multicolor FISH uses 23 distinct fluorescent colors, thus each chromosome is identified by a unique color, and translocations are detected easily.

G banding (Option A) is a method used for karyotyping and chromosomal identification using Geimsa stain. It cannot detect small translocations but is used for detecting aneuploidies.

Southern blotting(Option C) is used to detect specific  DNA sequences using complementary DNA probes and is not used for the diagnosis of CML.

DNA sequencing(Option D) is used to detect Mendelian disorders, cancers, acute myeloid leukemia, etc. It is the sequencing of the whole genome and is done using Sangers sequencing or Next Generation Sequencing. It is not employed for the diagnosis of CML in patients.

Image of a multicolor FISH/Spectral Karyotyping:

Related Pearl: Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)

It is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on a morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes.

The fluorescent probes are added to cells usually arrested in the metaphase stage of cell division (when every chromosome is separately).

Types of FISH:

1) Chromosomal painting: Each chromosome is identified by using a different colour of the fluorescent probe, however, each chromosome does not have a unique colour. Since the fluorescent dyes are limited.

2) Multicolour FISH: 23 distinct fluorescent colours made by mixing 5 fluorophores. Thus each chromosome is identified by a unique colour. It is also known as spectral karyotyping (SKY). It offers various advantages such as

  • Detects structural and numeric abnormalities in chromosomes.
  • Detects gene amplification and subtle microdeletions
  • Maps a newly isolated gene to its correct chromosomal loci

However, this process requires prior knowledge of the genes and chromosomes.

3) Interphase FISH: It is a rapid procedure of FISH, wherein growing cells are not needed. It is used in prenatal diagnosis and in tumour diagnosis.

The image shown is of a Multicolor FISH also known as Spectral karyotyping with a unique colour to each chromosome pair.

questions.text: A middle-aged sedentary male was diagnosed with essential hypertension. While presenting the case history of the patient, a final year MBBS student was asked about the 'Rule of halves' pertaining to hypertension. What does it mean?

choices.text: 50% of the hypertensive patients of general population are aware of having the condition.
50% of the hypertensive patients of general population are treated for the condition.
50% of the hypertensive patients of general population are adequately treated for the condition.
50% of the hypertensive patients of general population are aware of the complications of hypertension.

questions.solution:
The rule of halves pertaining to hypertension means only 50% of the hypertensive patients of the general population are aware of having the condition (option A).

The rule of halves depicts that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries were aware of the condition and only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated. 

Other options-

Option B- 50% of the hypertensive patients of the general population who are diagnosed/aware of the condition are treated for it.

Option C- 50% of hypertensive patients who are under treatment are adequately treated for the condition.

Option D- 50% of the hypertensive patients of the general population are aware of the complications of hypertension is a wrong statement. There is no mention of the complications of hypertension in the rule of halves.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male patient presented with dysphagia and regurgitation. Barium swallow showed the following picture. Weakness of which of the following muscles predisposes to the given condition​?

choices.text: Transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus and oblique fibers of the palatopharyngeus.
Transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus and oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus.
Oblique fibers of the cricopharyngeus and transverse fibers of the thyropharyngeus.
Oblique fibers of the cricopharyngeus and transverse fibers of the palatopharyngeus.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a pulsion diverticulum on the barium swallow is suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. Weakness of transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus and oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus predispose to this condition.

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

questions.text: A young male patient presents with sudden onset of pleuritic chest pain, breathlessness, and cramping pain in the right leg. He reports to have had deep vein thrombosis in the right leg 1 year ago. His BP was 128/88 mmHg and his pulse was 110 bpm. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pulmonary embolism (PE). The investigation of choice for the diagnosis of this condition is CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA).

PE and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) are part of the same spectrum of venous thromboembolism. PE occurs due to obstruction of the pulmonary arterial circulation by deep venous thrombi that detach from their site of formation and embolize to the vena cava, right atrium, and right ventricle.

Virchow’s triad of venous stasis, hypercoagulability, and endothelial injury, leading to recruitment of activated platelets, provides the ideal environment for thrombus formation.

PE can be classified as:

  • High-risk massive PE (extensive thrombosis affecting at least half of the pulmonary vasculature): Characterised by dyspnea, syncope, hypotension, cyanosis, cardiogenic shock, multisystem organ failure
  • Intermediate-risk submassive PE: Characterised by right ventricular (RV) dysfunction with normal systemic arterial pressure.
  • Low-risk PE: Shows excellent prognosis

Symptoms of PE are nonspecific, the most common among them being unexplained breathlessness.

Well's criteria is used to assess the likelihood of PE in a patient. For a patient with low-to-moderate likelihood of PE, the initial investigation is measurement of D-dimer levels. Whereas, for a patient with high likelihood of PE, the choice of investigation is CTPA. 

In the given patient, clinical signs of DVT, past history of DVT, heart rate >100 bpm, and a diagnosis other than PE being less likely contribute to the high likelihood of PE according to Well's criteria.

A normal D-dimer test helps to rule out PE. However, increased D-dimer levels are nonspecific as they can be seen in patients with other systemic illnesses including myocardial infarction (MI), pneumonia, sepsis, and cancer.

CTPA, also known as CT chest angiogram with contrast, is performed in patients with high probability of PE or those with low-to-moderate probability but elevated D-dimer levels. It is highly specific and sensitive, and a positive CTPA showing a filling defect confirms the diagnosis of PE.

The arrows in the image below show a large pulmonary embolism at the bifurcation of the pulmonary artery (saddle embolism):

Other options:

Option A: Echocardiography is not reliable because most patients with PE have normal echocardiograms. However, it can be used for detecting conditions that mimic PE like acute MI, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection. The best indirect sign of PE on transthoracic echo is McConnell’s sign (hypokinesis of the RV free wall with normal or hyperkinetic motion of the RV apex).

Option C: Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scanning is a second-line diagnostic test that detects absent or decreased blood flow due to PE. It is performed when CTPA is contraindicated or inconclusive and additional testing is required.

Option D: MR pulmonary angiography may detect large proximal PE but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE. 

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Well's criteria Score

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.
